Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment: Please revisit how we have to sign up for Medicare A and B at age 65 or face a life long penalty. most of us are NOT retiring but have to jump thru hoops to sign up for a health insurance that we DO NOT WANT or NEED at 65. Save yourself some $$ and have us sign up when we are ready to retire. I now have Medicare A as a secondary insurance but our private insurance from work is our primary. Make is simple. Set it up like the Jitterbug phone and not like the iPhone. as we age, we loose our patience so much more easily. we loose our ability to filter our thoughts so we are more easily ticked off for the mandatory need for something that we do not need. As a life long geriatric nurse / MDS coordinator for Medicare reimbursement, I am seeing the other side of this aging coin and why all of those families were so frustrated with your whole system. Just let us sign up for Medicare A and B when we are ready or in need of it. You wonder why your system is overloaded? Unnecessary garbage in it like my Medicare A and B (B that I cancelled. was not paying for that monthly in addition to my private insurance from work!) The fine that is put on the seniors and disabled cause they signed up for Medicare A and or B late, is well over $100 monthly. that is a lot of grocery, medication, or heat resource that they need monthly. Did I say a MONTHLY fine! I actually have had seniors tell me that tuna cat food was cheaper than a brand name for people. Eggs are their main cheap source of protein intake. Thank you for lowering those prices. Medication prices cause them to have cyclic admissions into the hospital and skilled nursing centers as they cannot afford both medications, housing, and food. Housing and food are more important to them. Your Medicare advantage plans are not working as they should. they take away Medicare entitled care and that is what I did. I fought with the advantage plans to get those patients what they earned, what they deserved, what they worked for. Now of retirement age, my plan is to visit senior centers in towns and challenge those advantage plans that to preying on seniors who are alone, vulnerable, possibly cognitively impaired by telling them lies on what their medicare plans offer for them then deny coverage. True story: a friend that lives out of state called me as her mom, who resided in a dementia care unit in a SNF, fell and broke her hip. their medicare advantage plan denied her skilled care and physical therapy due to her dementia. I asked her if she was ambulatory prior to her fall and she was. I directed her to the steps to appeal their decision and they won but....care was a few days delayed. Please, in your technology foundation, make it easy to use. use picture icons if needed. If the patient is on medicare, their spouse / significant other is approximately the same age and as they age into their 80's, their children become of medicare age making it more difficult to manage both generations at the same time. can you consider the use of webinars to educate the patient / responsible party of their rights in place of the hundreds of pages of the medicare manual or even the annual medicare book that I now receive annually. You would be surprised to know that the number of medicare recipients misunderstood that annual book that was sent to them. Again, their aging brain just looses their ability to concentrate and comprehend what you are trying to tell them. some learn better by watching or talking with someone that by reading all of those pages. Make it kid friendly. Again, just let up sign up for medicare A and B when we are ready and make it easier. I had to spend a few hours at social security to verify medicare A of which they said they would need to cancel as I have a HSA being contributed to but they never cancelled. they did cancel part B as I was still working. but all the information I read, we had to sign up at age 65, so I did and I have the cards to prove it should you decide to fine me monthly for signing up late when my husband retires and our private work insurance ends. I have not issues appealing medicare as I have done this for decades for others.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
PR-1:
We commend CMS’s efforts to encourage providers, including those in rural areas, to leverage approved digital health products. As the developer of Behaivior Recovery (www.behaivior.com), a predictive digital health platform using wearable devices and designed for behavioral health recovery, we highlight the importance of predictive tools that detect early signals of return-to-use and crisis risk, enabling timely interventions that improve sustained recovery outcomes.

PR-1a:
Current obstacles include lack of reimbursement pathways, limited integration with existing EHR systems, inconsistent interoperability standards across varied data formats, and provider burden related to documentation and workflow disruptions. Rural providers also face infrastructure and staffing limitations.

PR-2:
Development and deployment obstacles include fragmented data standards, lack of standardized APIs supporting full data spectrum (structured and unstructured), and administrative burdens. These could be mitigated by CMS promoting open, standards-based APIs like FHIR, and supporting bulk data access for efficient quality measurement reporting.

PR-3:
Full accessibility of all EHR data formats (including scanned documents, free-text notes, and sensor data) is crucial for comprehensive care. Technical barriers and privacy concerns must be addressed via policy incentives and infrastructure support. The priority of achieving interoperability across all formats should remain high to enable better patient outcomes.

PR-4:
Allowing third-party digital health products secure access to administrative workflows—such as auto-populating intake forms, viewing provider schedules, and managing appointments—can significantly reduce friction in care delivery and improve patient/provider experiences.

PC-1 & PC-3:
Behaivior Recovery (www.behaivior.com/solutions) exemplifies a digital health product supporting individuals and providers across care settings  by leveraging AI and wearable integration to provide predictive health insights. This device-agnostic platform empowers patients, providers, and caregivers to proactively manage mental health and addiction recovery and reduce health crisis risk, such as relapse, aligning with CMS’s goals of improved health outcomes and provider burden reduction.

PC-5:
CMS can encourage adoption through clear and comprehensive reimbursement incentives, education, and reimbursement parity for digital behavioral health tools. 

Wearables and Reimbursement:
Many digital health products, including Behaivior Recovery, rely on data from wearable sensors to detect early physiological and behavioral changes. However, lack of clear reimbursement pathways and coverage policies for wearables remains a significant barrier to provider adoption and patient access. CMS’s leadership in establishing reimbursement frameworks for wearable devices and their integration into clinical care would greatly accelerate the deployment and utility of predictive digital health tools. 

TD-1 & TD-2:
To stimulate developer interest, CMS should expand APIs to include richer data types (e.g., clinical notes, sensor data), enhance API usability, and reduce data access obstacles. Supporting non-CMS data sources that complement claims data can unleash further innovation.

TD-9 & TD-10:
Revising certification criteria to prioritize comprehensive API-enabled data access and consistent data exchange across all patient record elements would reduce provider burden and improve care coordination.

VB-1:
Value-based care models can accelerate digital health adoption by integrating predictive tools like Behaivior Recovery into care pathways, supported by aligned incentives and technical standards.

Summary:
We urge CMS to adopt policies fostering reimbursement, interoperability, provider education, and infrastructure support to unlock the full potential of predictive behavioral health digital tools. These steps will drive improved patient outcomes, lower wasted costs, increase access to care at home, and facilitate value-based care delivery.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide input.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Docket ID: CMS-0042-NC
Comment Category: Health Information Technology

I am Dr. Niraj Patel, DO MBA, CEO & co-founder of Wavital, a U.S. Class I MDDS platform that streams 300 Hz physiologic waveforms and continuous vitals from multi-vendor bedside monitors into Bulk FHIR pipelines in real time. Each patient-day yields ~26 million data points that can avert ICU transfers, but today zero of them flow through CMS-mandated APIs. I appreciate the chance to comment on the Health Technology Ecosystem RFI.

CMS and ONC should unlock bedside data, stop warranty-based information blocking, and create a voluntary AI-safety label. These actions will reduce nurse workload, lower VBP/HRRP penalties, and catalyze safer AI at the bedside, especially for rural hospitals.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. USCDI-Vitals = Add continuous waveforms & ≥1 Hz vitals to USCDI and TEFCA by CY 2027, using IEEE 11073 terminology & HL7 v2 MDM. [TD-7, PC-10]  
2. IEEE 11073 SDC transport = Require basic SDC “plug-and-trust” discovery/time-sync in the 2028 CEHRT update to eliminate vendor-proprietary serial links. [TD-4, PR-5]  
3. Bulk FHIR sandbox = Fund a pilot that posts de-identified streaming vitals + claims (“Physiology-at-Scale”) for AI/ML R&D. [TD-15, VB-3]  
4. Clinical AI Safety Label = Add a voluntary ONC certification track with provenance metadata, model-version logging, and drift reporting. [TD-8, TD-10]  
5. Alert endpoints = Tie the 2024 Provider-Access API rule to alert channels so Shock-Index>1 can hit the EHR inbox with one-click acknowledgement. [PR-4]  
6. DRG-neutral add-on = Create a payment add-on for continuous physiologic surveillance (analogous to EEG/tele-ICU) to fund MDDS-level streaming + validated AI CDS. [VB-1, PA-5]  
7. Ban license-tying warranties = Declare OEM clauses that void warranty or demand “unlock-fees” for raw data as *per se* information blocking under PHSA §3022(a)(1); add a “warranty-neutral data access” attestation to CEHRT and coordinate with FTC on Section 5 enforcement. [TD-4, TD-18(a)]

WHY THIS MATTERS:
- Clinical impact = Deep-learning early-warning systems using high-resolution data reach AUROC 0.86 vs 0.68 for MEWS and cut alarm counts > 50 % (Cho 2020; Pimentel 2021).  
- Economic impact = A 500-bed hospital can save \$12–24 M over 5 years in VBP/HRRP penalties; OEM “unlock-keys” cost up to \$8 k/bed/yr today.  
- Feasibility = Wavital plans to normalize > 40 proprietary packet formats, bridges IEEE 11073 SDC to Bulk FHIR NDJSON, and tracks model lineage; proof that all seven recommendations are technically achievable without new bedside hardware.

REQUEST:
Please (1) incorporate these seven items in the forthcoming proposed rule, (2) list warranty-based data blocking as a high-priority OIG enforcement example, and (3) convene a real-time data sub-workgroup under the Digital Health Policy Committee.

Respectfully submitted,

Niraj Patel, DO MBA
https://linkedin.com/in/nirajcpatel

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Organization Name: Goliath Engineering Technology dba Goliath Eng Technology (SAM)
Comment:
Goliath Engineering Technology is pleased to submit a response to CMS-0042-NC proposing a blockchain-powered, patient-centric health data infrastructure aligned with CMS goals for interoperability, TEFCA adoption, and digital health equity.

Our attached framework integrates secure identity management, real-time smart contract validation, and FHIR/Blue Button 2.0 APIs to enable seamless, permissioned data exchange across patients, providers, and payers — all while preventing fraud, waste, and abuse at the point of transaction.

Conservative modeling shows this system could generate $3–$15 billion in annual savings by eliminating duplicate claims, ghost billing, and improper payments — while dramatically reducing compliance and administrative burdens.

CMS asked the right questions in this RFI. The attached solution delivers the architecture to answer them — and the opportunity to pilot a scalable, standards-aligned model that empowers patients and protects taxpayer dollars.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Response to CMS-0042-NC: Request for Information on Health Technology Ecosystem

Submitted by: Matthew Ingalls, Founder & CEO, One & Done Smart Bids
Date: May 16th, 2025
File Code: CMS-0042-NC

One & Done Smart Bids is a patent-pending platform optimizing Medicare Advantage (MA) plan selection, saving $104 billion annually for 35.7 million enrollees ($2,922 average per MA plan annually; $3,846 per MA-PD plan annually). We thank CMS and ASTP/ONC for this RFI and offer insights to advance a patient-centric digital health ecosystem, aligning with CMMI’s value-based care (VBC) goals.

PC-1, PC-4: Health Management Apps
One & Done Smart Bids empowers seniors with one-click plan optimization, analyzing claims and health data to recommend plans saving $3,846 annually for MA-PD enrollees ($2,922 overall MA average). Its patent-pending technology enables real-time cost comparisons and care navigation integration, features absent in current apps. CMS could enable these via standardized MA data APIs.

PC-5, TD-1: Encouraging Adoption
We propose a no-cost CMMI pilot to test One & Done Smart Bids, building on 117,100 scenarios showing $3,846 annual savings for MA-PD enrollees. CMS could certify apps for efficacy (e.g., consumer savings, user satisfaction) and promote them via Medicare.gov. A 7-minute video demo https://youtu.be/18aNziPgBps showcases our interface and savings.

PC-6: Accessibility
Our one-click interface, jargon-free onboarding, and auto-reshopping ensure seniors reach results in <2 minutes, ideal for low-tech users.

PC-9, TD-2: Blue Button 2.0 Enhancements
Expand Blue Button 2.0 to include:
Real-time MA claims and health data (for plan optimization).
Dental, vision, hearing, and formulary details.
Social determinants of health.
Delays and proprietary payer APIs hinder access; CMS could mandate FHIR-based APIs via TEFCA.

PC-12: Competition Use Cases
One & Done Smart Bids enhances beneficiary choice by optimizing cost-effective MA plans, modestly diversifying insurer selection (e.g., UnitedHealthcare 25.95% vs. ~29% market share, Wellcare 19.17% vs. ~12%) and including smaller insurers (e.g., Devoted Health, 1.40%). It does not favor regional plans (0.05% Regional PPO). CMS could support choice via provider directories with FHIR endpoints (PA-4), enabling better plan-provider matching.

TD-18: Information Blocking
Payer delays in sharing MA claims and health data (e.g., 6-month lags) limit plan optimization. CMS should enforce real-time sharing and penalize non-compliance.

VB-1, VB-4: VBC Incentives
Incentivize Accountable Care Organizations (ACOs) in the Medicare Shared Savings Program to adopt One & Done Smart Bids via shared savings bonuses, leveraging its risk stratification and $104B annual savings. Its plan selections (30% HMO, 12% SNP) align with ACOs’ coordinated care models, enhancing cost efficiency and quality. Real-time claims and health data are critical for VBC success.

Conclusion
One & Done Smart Bids, with its patent-pending technology, aligns with CMS’s cost reduction, choice, and patient empowerment goals. We seek a CMMI pilot to scale our impact.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Response to CMS RFI: Health Technology Ecosystem
Dear CMS Team,

Thank you for the opportunity to provide input on the Health Technology Ecosystem. I appreciate CMS's efforts to enhance digital health solutions for Medicare beneficiaries.

1. Addressing the Digital Divide Among Seniors
While digital health technologies offer significant benefits, it's crucial to recognize that many seniors face challenges in adopting these tools. Factors such as limited digital literacy, cognitive impairments, and physical disabilities can hinder their ability to effectively use health technologies. To ensure equitable access, CMS should consider:
- Implementing user-friendly interfaces tailored for seniors
- Providing training programs to enhance digital literacy
- Ensuring availability of alternative support channels, such as telephonic assistance
Additionally, I recommend establishing a test group that includes both seniors and younger individuals, alongside medical staff, to evaluate the usability and effectiveness of health technology applications. This diverse testing group can provide valuable feedback on real-world functionality, accessibility, and clarity. Ensuring input from people who actually use and support these tools will improve design, reduce frustration, and increase adoption.
2. Shortage of Endocrinologists and Diabetes Nurse Educators
The increasing prevalence of diabetes among the aging population underscores the need for specialized care. However, there's a notable shortage of endocrinologists and diabetes nurse educators, which can impede effective disease management. CMS might explore:
- Incentivizing training programs to increase the workforce in these specialties
- Leveraging telehealth to extend the reach of existing specialists
- Integrating community health workers to provide localized support
3. Enhancing Access to Health Records
Empowering patients with access to their health records is a commendable step. However, without adequate professional support, interpreting and acting upon this information can be challenging for many seniors. To bridge this gap:
- CMS could support the development of tools that translate complex medical data into understandable insights
- Facilitate collaborations between patients and care coordinators to interpret health information effectively
As someone living with Type 1 Diabetes for nearly 70 years, I am acutely aware of how vital it is to have access to accurate, up-to-date health records. I currently use multiple health record applications, which can become confusing—especially when different practices use different platforms. That said, I want to commend Trinity Health for doing an excellent job with integrating and maintaining my records.
I’d also like to suggest a cost-saving improvement for Medicare: discontinue the routine requirement for redundant blood tests to reconfirm a long-established Type 1 Diabetes diagnosis during the transition to Medicare. These tests increase costs without offering any additional clinical benefit, especially for individuals who have managed T1D for decades. Medicare could instead reference the individual's pre-existing medical records, which often clearly document the diagnosis well before they become a Medicare primary recipient.
This would also help hospitals and nursing homes quickly determine whether someone has Type 1 or Type 2 Diabetes and whether they are insulin-dependent, so that adherence to ADA guidelines for treatment can be addressed and improved.
4. Preparing for the Needs of the Baby Boomer Generation
The Baby Boomer generation is entering a phase where chronic conditions become more prevalent. To meet their healthcare needs:
- CMS should consider expanding programs that focus on chronic disease management
- Invest in preventive care initiatives to reduce the onset of chronic conditions
- Encourage the development of technologies that support aging in place
In conclusion, while technology holds promise for enhancing healthcare delivery, it's essential to ensure that solutions are inclusive, accessible, and supported by a robust healthcare workforce.

Thank you for considering these perspectives.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Psychiatry & Psychology Have Embraced the Entrepreneurial Spirit

Entrepreneur: One who organizes, manages, and assumes the risks of a business or enterprise, often with an additional connotation of far-sightedness and innovation with boldness and energy.
[French, from Old French, from entreprendre to undertake; entre- between  (from Latin: inter-) + prendre to take (from Latin: prehendere to grasp)]

The U.S. government funded training for substance abuse researchers in entrepreneurship at Yale, so they could learn how to get more funding for their health care startups about substance abuse.

Scholarly articles have been published about "The Psychology of Entrepreneurship". One such study we noticed focused on industrial and organizational psychology (it has its own abbreviation, I/O); many of its key conclusions were to plead for more research in that area. We think that one of the primary goals of this kind of psychobabble is to set the stage for getting more research funds, rather than coming up with anything truly useful.

Another news article in the Washington Post "noticed that entrepreneurs seem inclined to have mental health issues." There are any number of news reports about "the problems entrepreneurs with mental illness often face," and "managing your mental health as an entrepreneur," and yet again "the psychological price of entrepreneurship."

So it seems that psychiatry and psychology have latched onto entrepreneurs as a new category of those needing "help," a new pool of potential customers. Entrepreneurs have been targeted by the mental health industry both as a new customer pool and a new way to do business. The competition for government funding and grants to address the problems of entrepreneurship is heating up, and the psychobabble is deafening.

Research also confirms that minorities are more likely to be misdiagnosed as having serious psychiatric problems, leading to the psychiatric targeting of  entrepreneurial minorities. 

And, like any entrepreneur, psychiatrists are looking to the future. Since they have never been required to cure anyone, they continually come up with new disorders, new drugs, and new treatments which they can apply to new communities of potential patients.

The news is full of these "miracle" treatments -- marijuana, cannabidiol, electric shock (yes, they still do this, and it is a big money-maker), MDMA (Ecstasy), trauma-informed therapy, Ketamine, cognitive-behavioral therapy, transcranial magnetic stimulation, assisted suicide (yes, this is considered a "treatment"), deep brain stimulation, involuntary commitment, vagus nerve stimulation, addiction therapy (ignoring the fact that psychiatric drugs are addictive), and one drug after another -- each new one designed to combat the adverse side effects of the one before.

Not to mention the profusion of new mental health related applications for your mobile device and the startups that create these. Not to mention this recent headline: "Entrepreneur Teams Up with Leading Psychiatrist to Address Depression, Anxiety, and Suicide". Not to mention that the producers of "Shark Tank" mandated that "all entrepreneurs meet with a psychiatrist after giving their pitch, regardless of the outcome."

The news is devoid, however, of one thing -- actual cures for mental trauma.

Go here for more information about fraud and abuse in the mental health industry: https://www.cchrstl.org/
Read about how Full Informed Consent can help: https://www.cchrstl.org/truth.shtml

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment: I strongly support the expansion of high-quality, evidence-based digital health solutions, including remote patient monitoring (RPM), telehealth platforms, wearable devices, and AI-driven decision-support tools that empower beneficiaries to make informed health decisions and actively participate in their care. To maximize the potential of digital health, I support Seamless Data Interoperability and continued adherence to and expansion of FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) standards to ensure secure, real-time data exchange between providers, payers, and patients. In addition, Investment in cloud-based platforms and APIs that enable scalable help secure integration of digital health tools into already existing workflows. We urge policymakers and industry leaders to expand Medicare coverage for clinically validated digital health products, ensuring affordability and accessibility, simplify reimbursement pathways for providers adopting digital health solutions, promote patient-centered design in digital tools to improve usability and engagement among older adults and support AI and predictive analytics to deliver personalized, proactive care recommendations.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Currently every Home Health, Hospice, Hospital, Clinic, Specialty Clinic has their own Electronic Medical Record (EMR) Software program.  For our small home care agency in Iowa the cost of the EMR is very expensive approximately 20% of my revenue is spent on software license and support.  Imagine if CMS Provided one EMR for all Provider Types.  One patient may have 4 different doctors, two different hospital or clinic systems, a pharmacy, and Medicare, Medicaid and VA benefits.  Imagine the improved care outcomes and decrease in hospitalization we would have if all Clinicians had the "whole" picture and we "all" had the same data.  No matter where the patient is served we all have the entire medication list and the full list of diagnosis.  Imagine how much money we could save if we were not running duplicate lab tests.  HIPPA can be maintained by the patient who would grant access with a temporary 6 digit pin given to a provider (access granted for one year and at admission and discharge).  Reports could show who had access to information.  Clinicians could work together messaging within the system.  Clinician's getting timely physician orders and pharmacy getting meds to the patient faster.  Requesting authorization for services would be streamlined because the payer would have direct access to all clinical data with out waiting for documentation (also opening up for data breech sharing information this way).  Imagine if CMS wanted to use AI to complete audits for fraud, waste and abuse.  CMS can do desk audits before going on site to a facility.  Providers could focus on actual care instead of all the duplicate data coming in from all different provider types.  OASIS, MDS, QAPI data would all be available to CMS with out requesting information.  Claims could be paid easily or recouped with the use of AI.  This would streamline data and provide efficiencies.  This would put clinicians back at the bed side.  All the extra data that we are gathering and paper pushing has just pulled talented positions into "DATA Management" roles.  One EMR managed by CMS would provide huge cost savings, streamline, and provide so much better outcomes for patients.  And the efficiencies with streamlining would also increase early response to issues that would result in decreasing ER visits and hospitalization.  If you would like to discuss more information.  I can be reached at dtaylorfhhc@gmail.com - let's cut the red tape, cut the cost, and streamline care its the year 2025 and we are still exchanging data at a snail speed.  

Thank You, Diana Price RN

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
As a healthcare consumer, technologist, and patient advocate, I am writing in strong support of regulatory action that would require healthcare systems to provide patients with transparent, real-time access to audit logs showing who has accessed their electronic health records (EHRs), when, and for what purpose. This request is not only ethically urgent—it is technically feasible and fully aligned with the capabilities of the FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) standard already adopted across the U.S. healthcare ecosystem.

Under the HL7 FHIR specification, the AuditEvent resource is explicitly designed to capture detailed information about access to protected health information (PHI), including the identity of the user, the action taken, the timestamp, and the purpose of access. This functionality is already a required component of internal logging for most health systems. However, while FHIR-compliant APIs are mandated under the 21st Century Cures Act and the ONC’s 2020 Cures Act Final Rule for patient-facing access to clinical data, no such requirement exists for exposing AuditEvent resources to patients themselves.

This is a critical shortcoming. In my own experience, despite being the subject of the record, I was denied meaningful access to audit logs when I requested information about who had viewed my file. I have also personally witnessed healthcare professionals—family members and friends—speak casually about accessing patient records out of curiosity, social interest, or personal bias, with no expectation of consequences. The lack of transparency makes such behavior difficult to detect, let alone deter or penalize.

The infrastructure exists. The FHIR AuditEvent standard provides a structured, interoperable format that could be exposed to patients through the same APIs currently used to access clinical notes, medications, and test results. What is missing is the regulatory requirement and enforcement mechanism to do so.

I therefore urge CMS and ONC to go further than current policy by explicitly requiring:

1. Patient-facing access to FHIR AuditEvent logs via the same API and portal systems used for accessing USCDI data elements.

2.Standardized labeling of access reasons (e.g., treatment, billing, quality review) using the AuditEvent.purposeOfEvent field, with defaults defined for national consistency.

3. Notification systems that alert patients to unusual or high-risk access, modeled after tools used in the financial services industry.

4. Time-bound response mandates for health systems to respond to audit log requests, just as they must with record requests under HIPAA.

These reforms would not only bring EHR systems into full compliance with the spirit of the Cures Act—they would also operationalize patient-centered care, strengthen data integrity, and rebuild public trust in healthcare institutions. HIPAA grants patients the right to access their health information; it is time to extend that principle to the metadata that tells them who is viewing it.

This is a rare case where the technical standard (FHIR) is already ahead of policy. Now the regulation must catch up.

Respectfully,

Anthony Leo
425 Champing Pl
Grosse Pointe Farms, MI 48236

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
I am submitting a formal response to CMS-0042-NC titled “Interoperability Is Not Privilege: A Patient’s Fight to Rebuild Healthcare.”

I never set out to fix healthcare—I just wanted to survive it. But like too many patients, I was misdiagnosed, delayed, and dismissed—because the system was too fragmented to see the full picture. What should have been a simple pharmacogenomic test became a years-long journey through silos, policy gaps, and out-of-pocket costs. That experience nearly broke me—but it also gave me purpose.

My submission calls for the creation of a National Safe Harbor for Real-World Interoperability Testing—not as another pilot, but as permanent infrastructure to validate the connections that patients, providers, and pharmacists actually depend on: PGx, ePA, RTBC, DTx, and pharmacy-centered workflows. I believe we need to stop asking patients to stitch their care together—and start building a system that’s unified by design.

I’ve included supporting materials, including a pharmacy interoperability white paper, a precision medicine executive summary I coauthored, and personal commentaries on data access, trust, and patient equity. These aren’t theoretical papers—they reflect lived challenges and the real cost of inaction.

My goal isn’t to critique what’s been done—it’s to urge us to do better. To center patients, include pharmacy, and align health tech with outcomes, not optics. Because people aren’t dying from lack of technology—they’re dying from a lack of connection.

Thank you for your leadership—and for listening.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment: See attached file(s) We applaud CMS for seeking solutions to help people manage what we affectionately refer to as the shitshow of managing health information - the information that consumers store in notes on their phones, in pictures (of everything from rashes to discharge procedures), emails, screenshots from their very secure patient portals which are then added to family text threads, and even folders and 3 ring binders.  That's the frustrating, fragmented and insecure “human solution" to the overwhelming deluge of health information that was supposedly solved through thousands of siloed patient portals and decades of non-portable personal health records.  We have more access to care than ever in our lives, but we’re crushing consumers with the weight of managing it.  Twenty years ago, most of us had a primary care doctor, a hospital and a local pharmacy.  Today, we have telemedicine, urgent care, psychiatrists, psychologists, digital solutions for musculoskeletal, gastroenterological and other needs, acupuncture, pain management and so much more.  And the ONLY place all of that information comes together is with the human at the center of that journey – or the loved one who is managing that information.  We’ve become the general contractors of our own bodies but have none of the tools for the job.  Our healthcare system has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on health technology for the practitioners and the consumer has a smart phone, a portal and a three-ring binder.   It’s time to tip the scales and get that consumer – and their chosen family and friends – the right information at the right place at the right time.  Health is a team sport and siloed, one-to-one solutions don’t solve the problem of the individual – whether that’s the caregiver or care recipient – of needing available, understandable and actionable information all in one place to be better consumers of healthcare and more impactful advocates for the people we care FOR and ABOUT.    The name of our company is Kith + Kin (an old-fashioned term for friends and family) and our app is the KinKeeper (because most people don’t refer to themselves as caregivers).  A KinKeeper is the person playing air traffic control for all the appointments and reminders and central intelligence, making sure everyone knows what they need to know – when they need to know it.  Those KinKeepers are the lynchpin to all of the care that happens outside the walls of a traditional healthcare delivery model and are critical to the long-term health of the people they’re caring for.  And whether we’re managing health information for ourselves or others, we need to be able to import, organize, manage and share WHAT we want, WITH WHOM we want, WHEN we want – at our fingertips and in our control.  That’s why we exist and why we’re thrilled that CMS is  looking at this through the lens of a consumer market and through the eyes of an individual who needs a way to take back some control of a situation that often feels anything BUT.  We look forward to responding to the RFP.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
iPill is the first medical device to prevent abuse, diversion and accidental overdose while also physically and remotely monitor medication adherence in the home. Only the prescription holder can access pills at the scheduled time. Simply taking patients word for it is not adequate. We can detect a daily missed dose and remediate it within hours instead of at the next pharmacy fill or  physician appointment 30 days from now. At the end of 30 days or if tampered we destroy unused pills. 

Best
John Hsu MD
John@iPilldispenser.com

Brief info about the iPill : 

iPill addresses the lack of medication adherence as an FDA Class II breakthrough designated product.  

iPill animation  https://docsend.com/view/5afanwprd49jixdt

iPill deck https://docsend.com/view/7t5vhu37ic4tw2se

Problem
The end-user dispensing pharmacy and end-user prescribing physician have endless regulations to follow when prescribing opioids, but the final user patient has no rules or regulations at home and can easily misuse, divert, actually overdose on the opioid they are prescribed. 

That is the reason 75% of patients don’t take their prescribed medications correctly which results in 125,000 deaths annually and $290 billion per year in additional healthcare expenditures because of higher rates of hospital admissions, suboptimal health outcomes, and higher morbidity/mortality for chronic conditions.
 
With opioids, opioid use disorder (OUD) and overdose death can occur.  In 2023, there were 110,000 opioid overdose deaths at a cost of $2.7 trillion in medical expenses, unemployment, homelessness and crime.   We have medications to treat OUD and reduce opioid overdose deaths by 50% but only 11% of patients can get these medications due to significant barriers to access care, including lack of transportation, lack of childcare, lack of healthcare literacy, stigma, healthcare inequities, geographical disparities, health disparities, and reduction of social determinants of health. 

Each overdose death costs $24.545 million.  ($2.7 trillion/110,000)

Solution 
iPill technology brings holistic care to patients with pill and patient monitoring.  

iPill provides : 
    * secure home delivery and storage 
    * biometric precise dispensing of medications only to the prescription 
       holder at only the prescribed schedule.
    * destruction of unused pills at 30 days and immediately if tampered
    * remote medication adherence monitoring to detect/remediate missed daily doses
    * notification alerts to family, friends, and caregivers for missed doses,
    * data Integration sync with Electronic Health Records (EHRs) and Superscripts 
    * capture of vital signs via faceprint AI 
    * psychosocial support via telehealth

Need
There is an immediate need for the iPill to increase patient access to treatment.  iPill’s versatility stems from the ability to securely and precisely dispense medications of varying shapes and sizes so opioids, opioid use disorder medications, sedatives, stimulants, tranquilizers, HIV drugs, specialty, and oncologic drugs can be used in the iPill dispenser.

65% of the jail population has OUD.  The detainees are not treated for OUD in jail and after release, have a 129 times higher chance of overdose death in the 2 weeks after release, a 75% higher risk of relapse, a 75% higher risk of recidivism, and a 50% chance of re-incarceration.  iPill could be made a mandatory part of early parole requiring 12 months of continuous treatment at an OUD clinic, Paid for with opioid litigation settlement funds and reimbursement from remote patient monitoring code remote therapeutic monitoring codes, iPill could improve treatment retention, reduce relapse, and save money and and lives.  

In the Veterans administration, there are 208 OUD clinics in the VA system treating 6,500 vets but 418,000 American Veterans need treatment but are unable to get treatment.  The result has been 44 veterans dying a day from suicide and overdoses.  iPill could be used to securely delivery, store, and dispense medications and deliver care with a virtual doctor and nurse in their homes.  iPill could be used to save veterans lives.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
On behalf of CareAtlas, thank you for the opportunity to comment on RFI CMS-0042-NC. We applaud HHS for advancing digital health and interoperability. As a technology-enabled care management provider, CareAtlas sees firsthand the opportunity to transform Medicare beneficiary care—especially by integrating nutrition, sleep, diet, and mental health into digital care models.
CareAtlas helps keep patients “Healthy and Happy at Home” by partnering with providers to deliver Remote Patient Monitoring (RPM) and Chronic Care Management (CCM). We use home devices for real-time tracking, provide regular check-ins, medication reminders, diet and lifestyle coaching, and coordinate care to reduce hospitalizations and support independent living. Our team-based approach ensures patients, doctors, and caregivers stay connected between visits⁠
⁠⁠
⁠.
Despite clear benefits, current digital health infrastructure and reimbursement are not sufficient to support robust, evidence-based services in nutrition, sleep, and mental health. While CareAtlas offers basic diet and lifestyle support, policy and technology barriers limit our ability to deliver comprehensive nutrition interventions. The same is true for sleep and behavioral health—critical domains for chronic disease prevention and management that are not yet fully integrated into Medicare digital health workflows⁠
⁠.
We urge CMS and ASTP/ONC to:
Expand Medicare coverage and demonstration projects for virtual nutrition, sleep, and mental health services, including preventive coaching.
Prioritize these domains in USCDI and FHIR standards, enabling seamless integration with care management platforms⁠
⁠.
Incentivize digital tools that bridge clinical care with daily health behaviors, and ensure accessibility for older adults and underserved populations.
Fund research and pilots to evaluate the impact of integrated services on outcomes and costs, and streamline regulatory pathways for innovative digital health products⁠
⁠.
CareAtlas stands ready to be a catalyst for this next phase of patient-centered care. We urge HHS to prioritize investment and standards development in nutrition, sleep, diet, and mental health, enabling digital health companies to deliver whole-person care for Medicare beneficiaries.
Thank you for your leadership and consideration.
Respectfully,
CareAtlas
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to provide input on the Health Technology Ecosystem RFI. I commend CMS for its forward-thinking approach to modernizing digital health infrastructure and promoting equitable access to innovation. I would like to offer comments on two critical areas: Innovation and Reimbursement, and Digital Divide and Health Equity.
1. Innovation and Reimbursement
While the digital health sector is rapidly evolving, reimbursement models have not kept pace with the innovation landscape. Many promising technologies—such as remote monitoring tools, AI-driven diagnostics, and digital therapeutics—face significant barriers to adoption due to unclear or inconsistent reimbursement pathways.
Recommendations:
	• Establish clear, scalable reimbursement frameworks for digital health tools that demonstrate clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness.
	• Expand coverage with evidence development (CED) models to support emerging technologies while data is being collected.
	• Encourage value-based payment models that reward outcomes achieved through digital interventions, not just traditional in-person care.
Without these changes, innovators may be discouraged from developing tools for Medicare populations, and providers may hesitate to adopt them due to financial uncertainty.
2. Digital Divide and Health Equity
The promise of digital health will remain unfulfilled if it does not reach the populations who need it most. Many Medicare beneficiaries—particularly those in rural areas, low-income households, or with limited digital literacy—face barriers to accessing and using health technologies.
Recommendations:
	• Invest in broadband infrastructure and device access for underserved communities.
	• Support digital literacy programs tailored to older adults and caregivers.
	• Require that CMS-funded digital tools meet accessibility and usability standards for diverse populations, including those with disabilities or limited English proficiency.
Equity must be a foundational principle in the design and deployment of digital health solutions. Otherwise, we risk widening existing disparities in care and outcomes.

Thank you for your leadership in shaping a more inclusive, innovative, and patient-centered health technology ecosystem. I look forward to seeing how CMS incorporates public input into future policy development.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

You’ve asked the right question.

How can CMS evolve policy to meet the realities of modern healthcare delivery, particularly where digital infrastructure is no longer auxiliary, but foundational?

Out of the multitude we should consider, here’s one clear opportunity:

Reimburse Distributed Clinical Logic.

Across the system today, we’re seeing software (not people) making real-time decisions that directly impact care:

• Routing a patient from surgery to physical therapy
• Escalating behavioral risk based on pattern decompensation
• Titrating medication timing based on dynamic context
• Detecting social need and auto-triggering intervention

These aren’t administrative workflows.
They’re clinical decisions, executed with speed, consistency, and scalability no human can match.

Unfortunately, none of this is billable.

Not under FFS. Not under most APMs. Not under most value-based tech carveouts.

As a result, systems that think, that coordinate, escalate, and guide care with clinical-grade intelligence are treated as cost centers. 

And not because they lack value, but because the reimbursement system doesn’t yet recognize intelligence as infrastructure.

I’m proposing that it should.

What is Distributed Clinical Logic (DCL)?

It’s a framework for understanding how real-time, rule-based or AI-enabled decision engines guide care delivery across the system.

Not in one place, but everywhere care happens.
Not with one person, but as a persistent, embedded substrate of coordination.

It is:

• Deterministic when it needs to be
• Probabilistic when it must be
• Clinically governed always

It doesn’t replace clinicians.
It frees them from what doesn’t require their expertise, so they can focus on where it does.

And it scales quality.

⸻

Why Now?

Because this logic is already here, inside RPM dashboards, prior auth platforms, population health tools, and care management engines.

But none of it’s incentivized the right way.
And the opportunity cost of not acting is enormous.

I believe CMS could lead the industry in reframing this layernot as “tech,” not as “admin,” but as billable, clinical infrastructure.

A subtle change in definition. A massive shift in what becomes possible.

I have a  proposed framework for how this model could work. Including use cases, reimbursement structures, stakeholder benefits, and implementation tiers.

I welcome the opportunity to collaborate further.

With respect and urgency,
Joseph Nalley

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
I am a US-licensed cardiologist with 50 years of clinical experience and over 30 years of involvement in digital health. I suggest that your quest for an interoperable infrastructure be a value-added proposition for all stakeholders. 

A healthy lifestyle is recognized as the bedrock for managing almost every serious chronic medical condition. Yet, it is sparsely adopted by patients and poorly taught by providers. There is a ready solution that would also serve your infrastructure quest. 

Almost every senior uses a smartphone. Offer all a credible and effective lifestyle coaching mobile app as a free download from Medicare. Daily, sensible, delightful, updated, science-based prompts, nudges, microsteps, and information nuggets will do what sporadic clinic visits can never achieve. Seniors and providers alike would welcome it because they know they need it. 

Medicare can contract with vetted healthcare entities that offer such a healthcare mobile app on the condition that the patients’ health information on it is transmitted to a Medicare data bank.  

With confidentiality ensured by Medicare, such a mobile app can track seniors’ biometrics, such as weight, blood pressure, pulse rate, exercise times, sleep patterns, and others. This bio-info bank is invaluable for Medicare’s public health purposes and any healthcare system’s planning. 

One such health management application already in use is the “Metacardio Healing Habits” app. But there must be others. I welcome Medicare or its designated healthcare enterprises to adopt my Metacardio lifestyle coaching app. With relatively minor modifications, this iOS app can be developed into a personal health record tracker that is interoperable across the entire ecosystem. 

I will not charge Medicare any fees. I only want to be of service as a retiring medical professional. For more information, please visit www.metacardio.org, my non-monetized website.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
One of the biggest issues with this shift to digital health and interoperability has to be loose definitions and ability for all parties to share data with others even 3rd party entities and especially awful is without the consent. Also the technology must be scrutinized and hardened to the point that it passes a test making hacking almost impossible. I am so sick of being forced by companies to go digital only to hear they have been hacked and your data is potentially out in the open. What do the individuals get a free credit report, the best part is that is usually sent as a physical letter in the mail to notify!!!! For the rights of Americans I urge whomever concerned in developing this to have a backbone and really stop the lawyer language and loopholes. The peoples health identifiable information should and must stay private. Under no circumstance should it be shared with any party without the consent of the individual this information need to be able to be audited by the individual as well. For example if a patient uses their visa atm card to pay a co-pay under no circumstance should the Dr. office be sharing anything with visa or experian/tranunion etc or anyone. Another example: If records for a specialty doctor are needed only the specialist should be provided the info and ONLY after the patient has authorized the disclosure. It's actually very simple just follow the ethos of least privilege. This is the section that MUST be cleaned up, simplified, and not open for interpretation.... 

2020 privacy act section From Justice dot Gov: 
Of the twelve exceptions discussed in this section, the most significant and frequently litigated exceptions are the “need to know” exception, disclosures required under FOIA, and the “routine use” exception.  The twelve exceptions are discussed here in turn. 
https://www.justice.gov/opcl/overview-privacy-act-1974-2020-edition/disclosures-third-parties

MyChart has a very user friendly front end as well as the ability for primary care doctors to review referrals and Rx. It could be a nice base.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
Executive Summary
Summit Voice AI is a HIPAA-compliant, end-to-end voice intelligence platform designed to deliver empathetic, human-like interactions that simplify and personalize the Medicare experience. Our AI assistant empowers beneficiaries through every step of their healthcare journey—from comparing plans and enrolling, to scheduling care, managing chronic conditions, and resolving concerns through a personalized, compassionate approach to complaints and appeals.

By integrating with payer and provider systems, Summit Voice AI operates as a real-time, always-on companion—bridging technology and human touch to support Medicare beneficiaries at scale.

Alignment with CMS Objectives
1. Empowering Beneficiaries through Intelligent, Conversational Tools

Summit Voice AI acts as a trusted, conversational guide for Medicare beneficiaries, helping them:

Find My Perfect Plan: Recommends plans based on unique needs—location, prescriptions, providers, and personal preferences.
Enroll in Coverage: Walks members through the application process, answering questions in plain language and confirming completion.
Access & Manage Care:
Schedule and manage visits, labs, and screenings.
Receive medication reminders and chronic disease management tips.
Track benefits, deductible status, and provider availability.
Voice AI-Powered Complaints & Appeals Handling:
Our platform uses emotional intelligence models and context-aware prompts to:
Empathize with the member’s concern using calm, validating language.
Guide the member step-by-step through submitting a formal complaint or appeal.
Automatically log, categorize, and route issues to the appropriate internal departments.
Provide real-time updates on complaint or appeal status using natural, reassuring language.
Escalate urgent or unresolved issues to a live agent while preserving the full conversation history for continuity.
This helps build trust and ensures Medicare beneficiaries feel heard, respected, and supported throughout the resolution process.
2. Reducing Administrative Burden and Increasing Operational Efficiency

By automating high-volume, repetitive interactions, Summit Voice AI reduces the workload on healthcare teams while maintaining quality and compassion:

Automates appointment calls, eligibility checks, reminders, and follow-ups.
Collects and updates member-reported information directly into care and CRM systems.
Handles common inquiries and guides members through processes like filing grievances and understanding their rights—freeing up human staff for complex needs.
3. Improving Care Coordination, Continuity, and Interoperability

Summit Voice AI integrates seamlessly with Electronic Health Records (EHRs), payer systems, and contact center CRMs:

Supports real-time care coordination across multi-disciplinary teams.
Ensures complaint and appeal documentation is accessible across all member touchpoints.
Provides AI-driven insights from engagement patterns to inform care plans and operational improvements.
Use Case: A Continuous, Compassionate Companion Across the Medicare Journey
In a pilot with a Medicare Advantage plan, Summit Voice AI served as a personalized companion for beneficiaries throughout their healthcare journey:

Plan Navigation & Enrollment: 82% completed enrollment with voice AI support.
Care Access: 35% reduction in missed appointments.
Medication Adherence: 25% increase in adherence through conversational nudges.
Call Deflection: 40% reduction in volume for routine inquiries.
Appeals Support: 97% of members filing appeals via the AI assistant reported feeling “respected” and “well-guided,” with a 30% reduction in appeal processing time due to automated logging and tracking.
Privacy, Security, and Compliance
Summit Voice AI is built on a foundation of trust and compliance:

End-to-end encryption for all voice and data interactions.
Role-based access controls and real-time audit logging.
Adherence to HIPAA, CMS complaint tracking guidelines, and applicable federal standards for beneficiary rights and protections.
Conclusion
Summit Voice AI embodies CMS’s vision for a patient-centered, digitally empowered healthcare future. With human-like empathy, intelligent automation, and personalized support—including for the most sensitive processes like complaints and appeals—our platform ensures Medicare beneficiaries are informed, supported, and treated with dignity at every step.

We welcome the opportunity to collaborate with CMS to demonstrate how Summit Voice AI can transform the Medicare experience and improve outcomes for all.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
CMS-0042-NC
I am a caregiver for my 87 year old mother, who moved from her home to assisted living in November 2024. I am also the Director of Health Information for a residential special hospital in NJ. It has been quite a task to gather and share my mother's medical records, as not all providers use Epic in their practices. For those who do, I have set up sharing to enhance the exchange of information. My mother, having dementia, cannot navigate the use of MyChart, and has never used it even before she was diagnosed.

I see a tremendous gap in communication with the assited living facility, which does not seem to have an EMR that is able to be shared with families/caregivers. There is also a gap in practice because I, as someone in the HIM field for 40+ years, note that the agency does have someone knowledgable about patient registration and the importance of sharing accurate information across the care continuum. For example, my mother's facesheet lists 3 primary care physicians, one of whom was apparently assigned by the rehab facility without conversation with her or me. i have asked more than once for a correction, to remove those who are not her primary from that facesheet.

Prescriptions for medications have gotten lost along the way between transfers from acute care to rehab to ALU. Even with my knowledge and experience, it's been difficult to get that straightened out, so I see the challenge for those with less knowledge and patience.

Seniors and caregivers need something that is easy to navigate, and that promotes the exchange of information between many providers. Knowledge gaps and language barriers only add to the challenge.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
Agilian Government Solutions (AGS) welcomes this RFI and urges CMS to prioritize bold, actionable policy steps that reduce administrative waste and improve beneficiary experience—particularly in the context of Medicaid and Medicare renewals.

As policymakers consider moving from annual to semi-annual redeterminations, we see an urgent need to replace outdated, paper-based processes with automated, AI-enhanced, digital-first solutions that leverage existing infrastructure and commercial innovations.

Policy Recommendations: Make Renewal Smarter, Not Just More Frequent
1. Fund automation and AI-driven renewal workflows

CMS should encourage and fund solutions that:
•	Auto-populate renewal forms with existing eligibility data (e.g., SNAP, 
        TANF, SSA);
•	Use AI to guide users through complex renewal questions in plain 
        language;
•	Deploy intelligent reminders via SMS, email, or app notification;
•	Flag incomplete renewals in real-time and nudge users with next steps.

AI-enabled digital assistants can reduce error rates, minimize friction, and support beneficiaries with low literacy or limited tech experience—at scale.

2. Leverage and extend existing infrastructure investments

CMS and states have already invested heavily in Medicaid Enterprise Systems (MES), the Federal Data Services Hub, and Blue Button 2.0. CMS should:

•	Provide integration standards and reusable APIs for digital renewals;
•	Incentivize states to build renewal tools that plug into existing 
        eligibility engines;
•	Promote platform-agnostic architectures that can scale across states.

Let’s stop reinventing the wheel. Use what’s already built—and make it smarter.

3. Promote interoperability with commercial digital products

Digital health shouldn’t start from scratch. CMS should identify leading-edge commercial products—think mobile apps, identity credentialing platforms, chatbot frameworks—and encourage states to partner with them, not compete against them.

•	These tools are already HIPAA-compliant, user-tested, and cloud-native.
•	Open standards like FHIR and SMART on FHIR can facilitate secure data 
        exchange and integration.
•	CMS can curate a list of pre-qualified vendors and reusable components to 
        streamline procurement.

4. Support equity with a "Digital Participation Fund"

As we digitize, we must not leave vulnerable communities behind. CMS should create a competitive grant program for states to:

•	Provide mobile-friendly renewal support in multiple languages;
•	Ensure compatibility with assistive technologies;
•	Offer public-private partnerships for mobile data subsidies, broadband, 
        and device access.

Access isn’t just about the software—it’s about getting the software into people’s hands.

5. Quantify the cost of inaction

To strengthen the policy case, CMS should analyze and publish the national cost of paper-based redeterminations—factoring in printing, postage, returned mail, call center volume, and avoidable churn. Model this against the cost of deploying scalable digital tools.

We suspect the return on investment will be clear and compelling.

Final Word

Administrative churn is not an inevitable cost of doing business—it’s a fixable policy failure. CMS has the authority, tools, and partners to lead a transition from legacy mailing cycles to automated, intelligent, digital renewal systems that reduce waste and improve access to care.

Let’s treat this not as a technology problem, but as an equity and efficiency opportunity.

Sincerely,
Agilian Government Solutions

 Addison Care – AI-Powered Electronic Caregiver (ECG)

3D Avatar Interface: A lifelike, interactive virtual caregiver that communicates with users in a friendly, engaging way.

This system is especially valuable for:

Seniors living alone

Family caregivers needing remote support

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Organization Name: cnmi growers association / panopticon group ww
Comment:
PUBLIC COMMENT RE: CMS-0042-NC – Health Technology Ecosystem

To whom it may concern:

We at CNMIGA.ORG are submitting this comment in response to the Request for Information (RFI) CMS-0042-NC regarding digital health products, interoperability, and patient data access.

We urgently raise a matter of national and ethical concern in the U.S. territory of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI), specifically regarding operations at the Commonwealth Healthcare Corporation (CHCC), located at 1178 Hinemlu Street, Garapan, Saipan, MP 96950.

Over 90% of CHCC’s medical staff are foreign nationals/non-American citizens. While we support workforce diversity and international expertise, we cannot ignore the alarming frequency of reported medical malpractice incidents and documented instances of identity theft. These incidents threaten not only patient safety but also national data integrity, especially given the sensitive health data managed under HIPAA protections.

In light of these systemic issues, CNMIGA.ORG urgently calls for the following mandatory safeguards to be adopted into CMS and ONC rulemaking and enforced at all medical facilities, especially those operating in U.S. territories:

https://www.cnmiga.org/post/chcc-grand-larceny-and-medical-malpractice-in-the-marianas-a-clarion-call-for-america-first-actio

Absolute Protection of HIPAA Data:

No non-American citizens should be granted access to protected health information (PHI), unless they are U.S.-licensed and bonded professionals with malpractice insurance and subject to U.S. HIPAA enforcement jurisdiction. This applies equally to third-party software vendors, translators, medical assistants, and foreign-trained doctors.

Mandated Medical Malpractice and Liability Insurance Coverage:

All healthcare facilities—particularly those relying on foreign labor—must be required to carry U.S.-regulated malpractice and liability insurance. This requirement must be universal, with no exceptions, to ensure accountability in cases of malpractice, fraud, or data breaches.

Given CMS’s increasing emphasis on digital interoperability, it is imperative that trust frameworks and data exchanges like TEFCA not allow health data to be accessed or stored by non-U.S. entities or unauthorized individuals. We ask that the HHS and CMS enforce strict digital identity credentialing and limit PHI access strictly to credentialed U.S. citizens working under direct U.S. jurisdiction.

Failure to enact these protections risks further erosion of patient trust and presents a cybersecurity, privacy, and national security threat in U.S. territories like the CNMI.

Respectfully submitted,
Zaji Zajradhara
Program Director, CNMIGA.ORG
Saipan, CNMI

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
1. Medicare beneficiaries and clinical practices, especially in community settings will need help to exploit the power of the information age and digital/virtual healthcare.  None of the various efforts by the private and public sectors has succeeded at making healthcare more efficient, more satisfying, and easier to receive and provide. A major reason is the lack of assistance to change-- practices and patient behaviors.  

2. Available for immediate exploitation is a national "Health Extension Service" modeled after the agriculture extension service--credited with transforming agriculture and rural communities for more than a century--a famous American contribution to the entire world.  The translation of agriculture's experience into healthcare has been nurtured in multiple states in creative public/private partnerships since the 1990's and is poised for scaling.  The idea is simple:  establish locally dwelling community members who know the local terrain and situation, unite them into a statewide system with connections to new knowledge and technology, and let them establish personal, direct relationships with practices and community organizations. The successful models have been organized and sustained for decades through federal, state, private partnerships.  

3. Right now, 39 states have submitted proposals in response to a call for proposals by the Agency for Healthcare Quality and Research to expand their initial "health extension" efforts throughout their states to help practices IMPLEMENT changes that are practical and useful to patients.  Two big changes are trying to happen and need facilitation-- use of digital platforms for care everywhere- and- integration of primary care practices with mental and public health. These submitted proposals build from years of experimentation and invention of health extension agents (new job) and are awaiting staffing for review now. Funded by the PCOR trust fund, this is an easy, shovel-ready opportunity to exploit to enable the challenging work of a major transformation of health care--moving medicine and the rest of healthcare into the information age by providing practical, local help.  It is like a hammer--it can be used to build a lot of things.  It is like cell phone, it can serve multiple purposes that shift and morph over time. Unlike so much of healthcare it engages local communities in an affordable way--neighbors helping neighbors, under the existing circumstances.

CMS can lead this into full funtionality now.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on RFI CMS-0042-NC regarding digital health, interoperability, and patient-centered data exchange. I am providing input as a stakeholder interested in improving patient access, provider efficiency, and the digital health ecosystem.

I. General Observations

CMS and ONC have made progress in building a standards-based, interoperable health data ecosystem through initiatives like Blue Button 2.0, FHIR APIs, and TEFCA. However, challenges remain in achieving seamless, patient-centric access, reducing provider burden, and fostering digital health innovation.

A. Patients and Caregivers
PC-1 & PC-2: Health Management and Access

Patients need integrated health apps to:

View all data (claims, notes, imaging, labs) in one place.

Schedule appointments, get reminders, access cost estimates.

Share data securely with caregivers and providers.

Fragmented portals force patients to manage multiple logins, impeding care coordination.

PC-4 & PC-5: Missing Features and CMS Role

Key missing features include:

Universal data aggregation across payers/providers.

Real-time provider availability.

Personalized health guidance.

CMS could:

Promote open standards and certify digital health products for usability and accessibility.

Enhance beneficiary education on digital tools.

Support reimbursement for digital engagement.

PC-6: Accessibility

Digital health products should prioritize:

Simple interfaces.

Multilingual support and assistive tech.

Low digital literacy requirements and robust support.

PC-9: Blue Button 2.0 API Improvements

Expanding data beyond claims to include clinical notes, imaging, and social determinants would increase value.

Simplifying authentication and enabling third-party integrations would foster innovation.

B. Providers
PR-1 & PR-2: Digital Health Adoption

Barriers include workflow disruption, lack of EHR integration, and insufficient incentives.

CMS can help by:

Streamlining certification for digital products.

Providing technical help, especially in rural settings.

Aligning digital health with value-based care.

PR-3: Interoperability of All Data

Making all EHR data (including scanned docs and free text) interoperable is critical but challenging.

Prioritize structured data exchange while developing standards for unstructured data.

PR-8: Quality Data Reporting

Bulk FHIR exports could reduce reporting burden if CMS handles quality metric calculations.

C. Payers
PA-2 & PA-3: API Implementation and Digital Identity

CMS should incentivize open APIs for data sharing.

Encouraging standardized digital identity credentials would improve security and access.

D. Technology Vendors and Data Providers
TD-1 & TD-2: Stimulating Developer Interest

CMS can stimulate innovation by:

Expanding available data sets.

Offering clear APIs and sandbox environments.

Reducing regulatory uncertainty.

TD-4 & TD-5: Open Standards and Provider Directory

Require open, standards-based APIs.

A nationwide, public FHIR endpoint directory would facilitate secure data exchange.

E. Value-Based Care Organizations
VB-1 & VB-3: Digital Health in APMs

Value-based organizations need interoperable tools for care planning and quality measurement.

CMS should tailor requirements to support these needs, with flexibility for smaller providers.

F. Information Blocking and Digital Identity
PC-13, PR-12, TD-18: Information Blocking

CMS should simplify the process for submitting information blocking complaints.

Stronger enforcement and clear disincentives are needed.

PC-14, PR-9, TD-3: Digital Identity

Standardized digital identity credentials would streamline access and enhance security.

CMS should work with providers and developers to encourage adoption.

G. Recommendations
Expand Data Access: Broaden API data to include clinical notes, imaging, and social determinants.

Promote Open Standards: Mandate open APIs and a national FHIR endpoint directory.

Simplify User Experience: Invest in user-friendly interfaces and digital literacy support.

Support Provider Adoption: Align digital health with value-based care and reduce reporting burden.

Foster Innovation: Provide clear guidance and technical support.

Strengthen Oversight: Enhance enforcement against information blocking and promote digital identity credentials.

Thank you for considering these comments. I look forward to continued progress toward a more connected, patient-centric, and innovative digital health ecosystem.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031

They jump from pediatrician to maybe a doctor in college, then attempt to find primary care doctors in new locations as their career progresses. This has been my experience. Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As a practicing physician and founder of multiple digital health platforms focused on aging and chronic care, I strongly support CMS's goal to modernize digital infrastructure and empower Medicare beneficiaries with accessible, patient-centered tools.

One critical opportunity is to better support family caregivers- the invisible frontline of elder care. These are the people making decisions at 9 PM, in Spanish, after their loved one has been discharged, with no case manager in sight.

I urge CMS to recognize and fund technologies that:

Use AI and voice interfaces to guide caregivers in real time,

Explain plan benefits (like meals, rides, home care) clearly and in multiple languages, available after work hours and on weekends,

Track benefit usage to meet required CMS reporting and Star Rating needs,

Give caregivers tools to access benefits without turning them into providers.

If CMS is serious about meeting people where they are, then modern tools must be multilingual, accessible after hours, and built around trusted family relationships, not just patient portals.

Please ensure that future digital health policy supports non-clinical, trustworthy AI-powered tools that help caregivers navigate the system to support their aging loved ones.

Thank you for your commitment to building a smarter, more equitable future for Medicare.

— Dr. Renee Dua
Los Angeles, CA

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
iPill is the first medical device to prevent abuse, diversion and accidental overdose while also remotely monitoring medication adherence in the home. Only the prescription holder can access pills at the scheduled time. We detect a daily missed dose and remediate it within hours instead of at the next pharmacy fill or  physician appointment 30 days from now. At the end of 30 days or if tampered we destroy unused pills. 

Best
John Hsu MD
John@iPilldispenser.com

Brief info about the iPill : 

iPill addresses the lack of medication adherence as an FDA Class II breakthrough designated product.  

iPill animation  https://docsend.com/view/5afanwprd49jixdt

iPill deck https://docsend.com/view/7t5vhu37ic4tw2se

Problem
The end-user dispensing pharmacy and end-user prescribing physician have endless regulations to follow when prescribing opioids, but the final user patient has no rules or regulations at home and can easily misuse, divert, actually overdose on the opioid they are prescribed. 

That is the reason 75% of patients don’t take their prescribed medications correctly which results in 125,000 deaths annually and $290 billion per year in additional healthcare expenditures because of higher rates of hospital admissions, suboptimal health outcomes, and higher morbidity/mortality for chronic conditions.
 
With opioids, opioid use disorder (OUD) and overdose death can occur.  In 2023, there were 110,000 opioid overdose deaths at a cost of $2.7 trillion in medical expenses, unemployment, homelessness and crime.   We have medications to treat OUD and reduce opioid overdose deaths by 50% but only 11% of patients can get these medications due to significant barriers to access care, including lack of transportation, lack of childcare, lack of healthcare literacy, stigma, healthcare inequities, geographical disparities, health disparities, and reduction of social determinants of health. 

Each overdose death costs $24.545 million.  ($2.7 trillion/110,000)

Solution 
iPill technology brings holistic care to patients with pill and patient monitoring.  

iPill provides : 
    * secure home delivery and storage 
    * biometric precise dispensing of medications only to the prescription 
       holder at only the prescribed schedule.
    * destruction of unused pills at 30 days and immediately if tampered
    * remote medication adherence monitoring to detect/remediate missed daily doses
    * notification alerts to family, friends, and caregivers for missed doses,
    * data Integration sync with Electronic Health Records (EHRs) and Superscripts 
    * capture of vital signs via faceprint AI 
    * psychosocial support via telehealth

Need
There is an immediate need for the iPill to increase patient access to treatment.  iPill’s versatility stems from the ability to securely and precisely dispense medications of varying shapes and sizes so opioids, opioid use disorder medications, sedatives, stimulants, tranquilizers, HIV drugs, specialty, and oncologic drugs can be used in the iPill dispenser.

65% of the jail population has OUD.  The detainees are not treated for OUD in jail and after release, have a 129 times higher chance of overdose death in the 2 weeks after release, a 75% higher risk of relapse, a 75% higher risk of recidivism, and a 50% chance of re-incarceration.  iPill could be made a mandatory part of early parole requiring 12 months of continuous treatment at an OUD clinic, Paid for with opioid litigation settlement funds and reimbursement from remote patient monitoring code remote therapeutic monitoring codes, iPill could improve treatment retention, reduce relapse, and save money and and lives.  

In the Veterans administration, there are 208 OUD clinics in the VA system treating 6,500 vets but 418,000 American Veterans need treatment but are unable to get treatment.  The result has been 44 veterans dying a day from suicide and overdoses.  iPill could be used to securely delivery, store, and dispense medications and deliver care with a virtual doctor and nurse in their homes.  iPill could be used to save veterans lives.
