Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Submitted by Kbrax, Developers of the CompleteCare Platform
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this critical RFI. Kbrax is a health technology company committed to advancing equitable, whole-person care for Medicare beneficiaries and underserved populations through interoperable, intelligent tools. Our work is grounded in the pillars of access to care, quality of care, cost efficiency, and care innovation.
We built the CompleteCarePlatform to unify care coordination, behavioral health, and AI-driven insights into one scalable solution that empowers both patients and care teams. Including:
•             CareNavigator: a care coordination platform that enables advocates and navigators to track care journeys, close gaps, and respond to risk signals in real-time.
•             MindPure: a patient-facing mobile app that promotes mental health, self-awareness, and proactive engagement, especially for seniors and those facing stigma around behavioral health.
•             State-driven AI engine: an intelligent prioritization layer that personalizes outreach, assigns tasks, and integrates behavioral, medical, and social data to support timely intervention.
Our platform equips care advocates to shepherd Medicare members to appropriate, high-quality, cost-effective, and culturally relevant care, regardless of geography, digital literacy, or socioeconomic status. We’ve designed our tools to be low-friction and inclusive, supporting care in the home, community settings, and remote areas.
Kbrax strongly supports CMS and ONC’s leadership in promoting FHIR-based APIs, TEFCA connectivity, and open data access. Our platform is interoperability-ready and already integrates ADT events, claims, and patient-generated health data. We encourage CMS to further expand access to behavioral, social, and historical provider notes through APIs, such as Blue Button 2.0.
We also support efforts to enhance digital identity management, minimize information blocking, and align CEHRT requirements with the actual needs of value-based care providers. Future certification criteria should include coordination and navigation tools, such as CareNavigator, in addition to traditional Electronic Health Records (EHRs).
Above all, technology must humanize care. Every feature we build centers on the patient’s story, whether it’s tracking social needs, detecting silent deterioration in behavioral health, or ensuring a timely follow-up after discharge. We believe patients deserve not just access to care but access to care that is personalized, proactive, and compassionate.
We have attached a more extended version of this comment, including detailed responses and examples of how CompleteCarePlatform supports CMS goals and public health transformation. We welcome the opportunity to partner with CMS and ONC on future pilots, innovation initiatives, or advisory input.
With gratitude for your leadership and shared commitment to equitable, innovative care,
The Kbrax Team

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Tennr, an intelligent automation platform for healthcare, is dedicated to streamlining clinical and operational tasks by precisely reading and interpreting complex medical documents with over 99.8% data entry accuracy, powered by its flagship RaeLM (TM) machine learning model. This response highlights how Tennr's comprehensive system is crucial for improving patient outcomes, reducing care delays, and, critically, for assisting CMS in effectively managing and scaling its oversight responsibilities, particularly concerning the increasingly rigorous Risk Adjustment Data Validation (RADV) audits.

With CMS significantly strengthening RADV audits through annual reviews, increased record sampling, and extrapolation of findings to entire contracts, the need for robust documentation integrity at scale is paramount. Tennr proposes to provide its Qualifications product and ICD-10 code extraction model directly to the CMS RADV audit team. This technology can enable CMS to proactively identify and validate diagnoses at scale, efficiently review audits by automating medical record validation, enhance financial integrity by ensuring accurate documentation for billed diagnoses, and complement CMS's own enhanced technology and growing medical coder team.

Tennr's Qualifications product leverages machine learning to determine if medical necessity is met for HCPCS codes ordered against corresponding Medicare LCD’s and NCD’s, while RaeLM (TM) accurately extracts and transforms complex narrative descriptions into standardized ICD-10 codes. This capability ensures that diagnoses are fully supported by medical records, mitigating the risk of unsupported codes and facilitating the generation of comprehensive "proof packets" for audits. By integrating Tennr's high-confidence automation, CMS can streamline its audit processes, reduce manual review burdens, and ultimately protect the Medicare Trust Fund from improper payments.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As CMS explores opportunities to modernize and improve technology for Medicare beneficiaries, I urge the agency to address one of the most significant—and fixable—disparities in our healthcare ecosystem: the lack of open access to Medicare plan data and the disproportionate control insurance carriers have over plan distribution.

Unlike the Affordable Care Act Marketplace, Medicare is a Closed System—And That’s Hurting Beneficiaries

In the Marketplace, consumers can easily compare every available plan thanks to public APIs and federally maintained exchanges. Private innovators can build tools and experiences that improve transparency and ease of enrollment. Brokers are empowered to serve clients by showing all their options without artificial restrictions from insurers.

In stark contrast, the Medicare ecosystem is closed and highly restricted. Plan data is not accessible via APIs. Carriers selectively decide which brokers or e-brokers can represent their plans, granting or revoking access at their discretion—often based on commercial favoritism, not consumer interest.

This creates a perverse dynamic: brokers, who should serve as unbiased advisors, are functionally captive to the whims of carriers. I’ve personally experienced—and can verify—that a broker's ability to represent plans can be revoked arbitrarily, for reasons unrelated to compliance or ethics. It’s a shadowy gatekeeping structure that undermines the entire promise of informed choice in Medicare.

Medicare Must Embrace Open Infrastructure—Modeled After Healthcare.gov

CMS should mandate open access to Medicare Advantage and Part D plan data through public APIs. This would empower developers, FMOs, agencies, and consumer-facing platforms to build comparison tools that reflect the full market—not just the subset a carrier allows them to display.

This would also:

Foster innovation: Open data allows third-party tools, consumer apps, and nonprofit organizations to build decision support systems tailored to different populations—rural, multilingual, low-income, etc.

Promote transparency: Beneficiaries deserve to see all their options, not just those tied to certain marketing agreements.

Level the playing field: Carriers should not be allowed to block brokers who are otherwise fully certified and compliant with CMS rules. Centralized credentialing and certification—administered by CMS, not carriers—would protect consumer interests.

Carrier-Driven Oversight Is Undermining Broker Neutrality

Brokers should be accountable to CMS, not beholden to each carrier’s internal compliance department. Today, carriers exploit marketing rules to enforce loyalty or punish dissent. These opaque enforcement mechanisms create a culture of fear and bias among brokers—precisely what CMS has said it wants to avoid.

If we want brokers to be unbiased advocates for the consumer, we must remove the perverse incentives created by the current contracting system.

Recommendations for CMS Consideration:

Create Public APIs for Medicare Advantage and Part D plan data, modeled after Healthcare.gov’s approach, enabling both public and private plan-finder platforms to flourish.

Implement centralized, CMS-controlled certification and contracting for brokers—eliminating carrier-specific restrictions that limit consumer access and distort broker incentives.

Prohibit carriers from selectively approving or terminating broker relationships without cause or due process. Broker eligibility should be based on CMS compliance and training alone.

Modernize Medicare marketing rules to reflect a platform-neutral, data-driven ecosystem that fosters innovation while safeguarding consumers.

We need a Medicare system that is transparent, fair, and technologically open—where brokers serve as true fiduciaries for the beneficiaries they represent. CMS has a rare opportunity to create infrastructure parity between the ACA Marketplace and Medicare. Let’s not waste it.

Respectfully,
Calvin Bagley
Founder, Nuvo Health
Las Vegas, Nevada

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Public Comment Submission to CMS: RFI on Health Technology Ecosystem – Medicare Modernization

As a licensed Medicare agent who has spent years guiding retirees and near-retirees through their Medicare options, I strongly support modernizing the Medicare enrollment and plan comparison experience. Our current system is outdated, opaque, and burdensome—not just for brokers, but for the very individuals Medicare is supposed to protect.

Unlike the ACA Marketplace, Medicare lacks a centralized, transparent platform for plan comparison and enrollment. Brokers are forced to navigate restrictive and fragmented carrier relationships, where access to plan data and enrollment tools is tightly controlled and can be revoked without cause. This leaves consumers at a disadvantage and undermines the goal of offering unbiased, comprehensive support.

I respectfully urge CMS to consider the following:

Develop public APIs for Medicare plan data to allow third parties and developers to build robust, consumer-friendly tools.

Centralize and streamline broker certification and contracting under CMS rather than individual carriers.

Implement protections against arbitrary de-appointment of brokers who are licensed, certified, and compliant.

Allow technology-driven innovation in Medicare plan comparison tools, similar to the ACA model.

Revise marketing rules in a way that balances consumer protections with the freedom to provide educational, transparent outreach.

If CMS is committed to empowering Medicare beneficiaries, the system must prioritize accessibility, neutrality, and accountability—not corporate gatekeeping.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment and advocate for a more transparent and consumer-friendly Medicare system.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Submission to CMS/ONC Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem
File Code: CMS-0042-NC
RIN: 0938-AV68
Submitted by: Syntax Health
Date: June 3, 2025
Submitted via: https://www.regulations.gov/commenton/CMS-2025-0050-0031
Subject: Public Comment on Digital Infrastructure Needs to Support Value-Based Care

To the CMS and ONC teams,

Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the Request for Information on modernizing the Medicare health technology ecosystem. As a company working closely with independent provider organizations—particularly Community Health Centers (CHCs), provider-led ACOs, and regional CINs—we deeply support CMS’s vision of improving care coordination, transparency, and equity through digital infrastructure.

We write today to respond specifically to the section of the RFI focused on Value-Based Care (VBC) and the role that digital infrastructure plays in advancing its success.

⸻

Key Recommendations for VBC Enablement

1. Create enforceable data standards that ensure real-time, two-way data exchange between payers and providers.
Providers in VBC arrangements often lack timely access to the very data they are measured on—claims, attribution, quality results, and benchmark performance. One CHC partner of ours, participating in both Medicaid MCO and MSSP programs, experienced a 90-day delay in receiving performance data, only to learn they had missed an incentive opportunity due to outdated rosters and unaccounted exclusions. These gaps aren’t just frustrating—they are financially and operationally damaging.

We recommend CMS:
	•	Establish minimum standards for structured, real-time data exchange in VBC programs
	•	Incentivize or require payers to share quality and financial performance data at monthly or quarterly intervals
	•	Include provider-facing APIs and flat file formats that do not require EHR customization or additional licenses

2. Prioritize CHC and safety-net provider needs in digital health infrastructure investments.
CHCs serve over 30 million patients—yet they’re often excluded from interoperability discussions due to limited resources or vendor support. Several of our CHC clients struggle with inconsistent payer file formats, missing risk scores, or performance logic that can’t be independently validated.

CMS should:
	•	Fund and promote shared data infrastructure at the regional or PCA/HCCN level
	•	Encourage open performance scoring methodologies to reduce dependence on opaque vendor tools
	•	Promote “plug-and-play” tooling for small and mid-sized organizations to analyze and act on data

Note: Syntax Health currently supports several provider organizations—including CHCs, academic faculty practices, and ACO-aligned networks—with actuarial modeling, contract performance tools, and actionable analytics that simplify VBC execution. This work has demonstrated that when providers have access to timely, interpretable data, they can renegotiate contracts, avoid missed incentives, and improve outcomes—all without increasing administrative burden.

3. Reduce administrative burden by supporting integrated VBC tooling.
Digital infrastructure should not add to the reporting burden—it should reduce it. We see provider organizations managing VBC contracts in dozens of spreadsheets and PDFs, leading to errors and missed opportunities.

We recommend CMS:
	•	Recognize or certify tools that integrate contracting, performance measurement, and financial reconciliation
	•	Encourage modular infrastructure that supports providers of all sizes—not just IDNs with in-house tech teams
	•	Consider demonstration projects that validate how digital tools improve provider experience and outcomes in VBC

4. Center equity and transparency in VBC data infrastructure.
Medicare’s digital health transformation must serve all providers and patients. This includes:
	•	Publishing benchmarks and scoring algorithms used to determine shared savings
	•	Ensuring attribution logic and risk adjustment are accessible, explainable, and updatable
	•	Supporting VBC enablement for providers serving rural and underserved populations, including CHCs, tribal clinics, and Medicaid-focused ACOs

⸻

Closing Thoughts

Radical change requires practical people. We urge CMS and ONC to design this modernization effort with real-world providers in mind—especially those serving high-need populations. A more transparent, timely, and equitable digital ecosystem is not just a technology issue—it’s foundational to Medicare’s success in value-based care.

We are grateful for your leadership and would welcome future opportunities to collaborate.

Sincerely,
Syntax Health
rachael@meetsyntax.com | www.meetsyntax.com

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Organization Name: South Carolina Primary Health Care Association
Comment:
Advancing a Patient-Centered Digital Health Infrastructure

As a stakeholder engaged in health IT transformation for Community Health Centers, I appreciate the opportunity to provide the following comments and recommendations aligned with the RFI’s key focus areas:

Patients & Caregivers
CMS should collaborate with digital literacy initiatives to ensure digital tools are accessible to seniors, low-income populations, and marginalized communities. I recommend that CMS fund pilot programs to support the development of “navigation-first” digital health apps that prioritize ease of use for appointment scheduling, care team communication, and personal health goal tracking.

Providers
The administrative burden on providers related to quality reporting and interoperability compliance remains significant. CMS should consider allowing EHR vendors to transmit aggregated, risk-adjusted quality metrics directly to CMS using Bulk FHIR APIs, which would reduce manual reporting and improve workflow efficiency.

Payers
Many payers still lack standardized APIs for data exchange. CMS should align payer expectations with Blue Button and Data at Point of Care initiatives, and link payer participation in CMS programs to demonstrable progress in adopting digital identity standards and FHIR-based APIs.

Technology Vendors & Networks
ONC certification pathways continue to be complex for developers, particularly those building innovative or non-traditional applications. I recommend the creation of a “Digital Health Innovation Certification Track” focused on real-world usability testing and API functionality, rather than traditional modular certification.

Value-Based Care (VBC) Organizations
For VBC models to succeed, timely access to data is critical. However, delays in data transmission and the lack of longitudinal insights hinder care coordination. CMS should incentivize technology vendors to natively support event notifications, accurate patient matching, and care planning APIs in VBC-certified platforms.

Cross-Cutting Recommendations

Centralized Digital Health Resource Hub: CMS should establish a national resource center for developers that includes access to sandbox environments, interoperability toolkits, data standards documentation, and patient-centered design feedback mechanisms.

Metrics-Driven Evaluation Framework: CMS should adopt a digital maturity model to evaluate the uptake of APIs, patient access/utilization, care coordination improvements, and digital health app performance.

Expand Blue Button Beyond Medicare: I encourage CMS to broaden the scope of Blue Button 2.0 to include Medicaid and dual-eligible populations, which would improve access and support innovation for underserved communities.

These recommendations are grounded in the realities of community-based care delivery and are intended to support a more inclusive, interoperable, and outcomes-driven digital health infrastructure.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My son lost Medicaid coverage during radiation treatment for brain cancer because of a clerical error. As his caregiver and a Board-Certified Patient Advocate, I know that wasn’t just an administrative oversight. It was a systems failure. And he’s not the only one it failed.

I’m the full-time, unpaid caregiver for my Kindergarten-aged son, a four-time brain cancer and stroke survivor. I’m also a healthcare professional with 15 years of experience and deep expertise in HIPAA, EHR interoperability, and data governance. Despite this, I spend 30+ hours per week navigating clinical coordination, insurance, pharmacy logistics, and provider communication just to keep my son’s care on track. There are no support systems or labor protections for this role. Most caregivers aren’t industry experts. I am, and it’s still unbearable.

System Failures I've Lived Through:
1. EHRs That Stall Complex Care: Designed for single-provider workflows, EHRs block collaboration on second opinions, trials, or innovative treatments.
2. Burned-Out Clinicians Who Resist Innovation: Creativity, like dietary interventions or off-label use, is often dismissed, even when evidence-backed.
3. Trauma Ignored: Caregivers navigating crisis after crisis need trauma-informed policies. Right now, we’re invisible.
4. Medicaid Coverage Gaps: My son was dropped mid-treatment. Reinstatement took intensive advocacy that most families don’t have the bandwidth to fight for.
5. No Protections, No Pay: If a nurse doesn’t show up, it’s my problem. If records don’t transfer, it’s on me. And yet, the system treats me like a liability, not a care partner.
6. Opaque Pricing: We face critical financial decisions with zero cost transparency.
7. Real-World Use of AI is Ignored: Families like mine are already using tools like ChatGPT to organize care and advocate. These realities should inform policy now, not in five years.

Recommendations to CMS:
To address these failures and empower caregivers as integral care partners, CMS must:
1. Establish a Patient & Family Workgroup: Include lived-experience experts in shaping federal healthcare innovation.
2. Fairly Compensate Workgroup Members: Ensure equitable access by removing financial participation barriers.
3. Implement Trauma-Informed Protocols: Require providers and systems to account for caregiver mental health.
4. Fix Medicaid Administrative Failures: No patient should lose access to care mid-treatment due to state-level errors.
5. Reduce Caregiver Administrative Burden: Streamline documentation, authorizations, and records access for designated caregivers.
6. Use Real-World Use Cases in Policy: AI, health data tools, and new care navigation platforms already have traction in families. Learn from us.
7. Establish Labor Protections for Caregivers: Treat caregiving as essential work, not invisible labor.
8. Mandate Price Transparency: Require providers and payers to disclose true costs upfront.
9. Shift Data Ownership to Patients: Patients and caregivers need control, not gatekeepers.
10. Prioritize the Human Experience: Design systems around people, not processes.

Why This Matters Now:
This comment supports the Quintuple Aim: improving patient and caregiver experience, reducing costs, improving outcomes, addressing health equity, and protecting healthcare workers’ well-being.

If caregivers remain unsupported, healthcare becomes unsustainable for everyone. We are the invisible infrastructure holding up your outcomes data, your readmission metrics, and your treatment adherence. Yet we are systemically ignored, unprotected, and burned out.

As a caregiver, board-certified patient advocate, and healthcare professional, I urge CMS to act now. This is not just about improving workflows. It’s about protecting lives and preserving the sustainability of our entire system.

Thank you for the opportunity to share this. I welcome the chance to support this work as a professional advocate and lived-experience expert.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Hello,

I am an individual insurance Broker that specializes in Medicare products.

I do not believe the technology is broken.

What is broken however, is the process. Specifically the call centers that are constantly cold calling seniors about their Medicare Coverage, and the year-round Special Election Periods that enable people to change their plans any time they want.

Want to fix the millions of marketing complaints? Get Joe Namath off the TV, find a way to stop the cold calls, and end the non-stop SEPs that allow the churning.

I can promise you the local small-time brokers are not the problem. Its the SEPs that ENABLE the churning, and the billion dollar call centers using speed dialers cold calling people that are.

I have 2-3 clients a day calling me, all saying the same thing "Dave, I just got a cold call from someone saying that they're from Medicare, and there is NEW things happening, and I should change me plan!"


I am a small time broker, that works exclusively in my community. I do not cross state lines. I have relationships with every one of my clients. I promise you, you are focusing on the wrong thing. Start  with the non-stop SEPs, then crack down on the cold calls.

Once that is fixed, sure update the website, launch Blue Button 3.0 and allow broker-developers to create their own API.

But that is not going to stop the abuse from the cold callers churning during decades long SEPs.

Thank you for listening.

Comment:
Greetings,
Thank you for asking for comments about "how best to advance a seamless, secure, and patient-centered digital health infrastructure."

My experience comes from providing caregiver to my father (diabetes) and mother (assisted living) who both passed several years ago. Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
In my experience, having the opportunity to meet with healthcare providers through telehealth programs has helped tremendously. I am a fall risk with osetoarthritis, and being able to speak to my doctors or therapists online instead of needing to leave my house has been incredibly helpful to me. I recognize that some appointments would require me to physically leave my home, such as for testing purposes, but when telehealth would be an option, I'd like to be able to have the appointments I can have through it.
One other thing I believe would make my healthcare easier to manage would be if I could have my medications delivered to me from the pharmacy I currently go to. Said pharmacy is through Walmart. It would extraordinarily helpful, not just for me, but for many people if similar businesses allowed medications through their pharmacies to be delivered to your doorstep, or for them to be picked up through the same process some grocery stores offer to place an order and pick up the items. Many medications require being stored at room temperature, so for delivery services, having them delivered in cooler boxes during summer months would most likely be necessary.
I feel as though MyChart should not have a monopoly on electronic/online health services. After all, what will happen if MyChart goes down? What will happen to medical records if MyChart goes bankrupt, or what about the times MyChart's services are unavailable? Sure, there's always pen and paper, and yes, services being temporarily unavailable is a well-known risk online. However, people across the nation are affected by MyChart's services, including when they go down. Many doctors have their schedules booked for months at a time. What happens to patients who need these telehealth services for time-sensitive and/or life-threatening conditions if MyChart suddenly stops working? Perhaps healthcare providers and hospitals should be able to connect to multiple websites with similar services that are NOT connected to MyChart, so if one goes down, there are backups. I don't believe they should be required to enter a formal contract for this, and exclusivity deals shouldn't be allowed. MyChart is very useful, but it should not have the power that it does over the healthcare industry.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
Scope Infotech recognizes the critical importance of enhancing the digital health technology ecosystem to empower Medicare beneficiaries and improve their health outcomes through effective technology adoption and seamless data interoperability. Our team supported the CMS Electronic Medical Documentation Interoperability (EMDI) initiative. These websites provide detailed information about the EMDI initiatives including pilots, implementation guides and training materials that can provide additional support in the efforts defined in this RFI.

https://www.cms.gov/data-research/computer-data-systems/emdi 
https://oncprojectracking.healthit.gov/wiki/spaces/TechLabSC/pages/16123414/EMDI+Home 
https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/dme-orders/ 
https://www.cms.gov/data-research/computer-data-systems/emdi/post-acute-fhir-order-and-referrals

Based on our experience with EMDI and our understanding of the current landscape, we offer the following technical response addressing the key areas of inquiry outlined in the RFI:
1. Digital Health Products: Accessibility and Effective Use for Medicare Beneficiaries

Current Market and Barriers:
The current market offers a growing array of digital health products, including telehealth platforms, remote patient monitoring (RPM) devices, mobile health applications, artificial intelligence, and personal health records (PHRs). While these technologies hold significant promise for Medicare beneficiaries, several barriers hinder their effective use:
•	Lack of Interoperability
•	User Accessibility and Digital Literacy
•	Integration with Existing Workflows
•	Reimbursement and Coverage Uncertainty
•	Data Security and Privacy Concerns.

Leveraging EMDI Solutions:
The solutions identified within the EMDI initiative offer a strong foundation for addressing these barriers:
•	Interoperability Standards (HL7 FHIR)
•	Expanded APIs and Integration (Blue Button 2.0)
•	User-Friendly Interfaces

2. Data Interoperability: State and Improvement Strategies

Current State:
While progress has been made with initiatives like the Blue Button 2.0 API and the establishment of interoperability rules, the current state of data interoperability within the digital health ecosystem for Medicare beneficiaries remains fragmented. Challenges persist in achieving seamless and secure data exchange across disparate systems and organizations. Variations in data standards, implementation inconsistencies, and a lack of universal adoption of interoperability protocols contribute to this fragmentation.
Strategies for Improvement:

To enhance data interoperability and better support patient care and health management, we propose the following strategies, building upon the lessons learned from EMDI:
•	Widespread Adoption of HL7 FHIR.
•	Development of Common Data Elements (CDEs)
•	Expansion of API Ecosystem
•	Implementation of Robust Identity Management
•	Support for IHE Profiles.
•	Establishment of Interoperability Testing and Certification Programs
•	Incentivizing Interoperability.
•	Focus on Data Quality and Governance.

Leveraging EMDI Technology Solutions and Standards:
As highlighted in the provided information, the following technology solutions and interoperability standards from the EMDI initiative are directly applicable to addressing the RFI requirements:
•	HL7 FHIR
•	Blue Button 2.0 API
•	Secure Data Exchange Protocols (Encryption, Authentication)
Addressing Challenges, Risks, and Issues:
We acknowledge the challenges, risks, and issues associated with achieving widespread adoption and effective use of digital health technologies and interoperability, as outlined in the provided text. Our approach to mitigating these includes:
•	Data Interoperability
•	Adoption of Standards
•	User Accessibility
•	Data Security and Privacy
•	Stakeholder Engagement
•	Financial Constraints
•	Regulatory Compliance 

Incentivizing Adoption Across Ecosystems:
To effectively incentivize the adoption of digital health technology across the ecosystem, we concur with the strategies outlined in the provided text, emphasizing:
•	Financial Incentives: 
•	Regulatory Support: 
•	Public-Private Partnerships: 
•	Education and Training: 
•	Pilot Programs

Conclusion:
Scope Infotech believes that by strategically leveraging interoperability standards like HL7 FHIR, expanding secure API access, prioritizing user-centered design, and implementing robust security measures, the digital health technology ecosystem for Medicare beneficiaries can be significantly enhanced. Addressing the identified challenges through collaborative efforts, clear regulations, and appropriate incentives will be crucial for achieving the ultimate goals of patient empowerment and improved health outcomes. We are committed to supporting CMS, ASTP, and ONC in this important endeavor and offer our expertise gained from the EMDI initiative to contribute to the successful evolution of the digital health landscape.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Comment:
xCures, Inc. appreciates the opportunity to respond to CMS and ONC’s Request for Information on strengthening the nation’s health-technology ecosystem. We are an AI-first health-data Software-as-a-Service company that converts structured data, free-text clinical notes, scanned documents, radiology, and pathology images into compute-ready FHIR++ outputs in near real time. To date, we have normalized more than 36 million clinical documents originating from over 327,000 care sites nationwide, supporting clinical care, patient access, clinical decision support, value-based payment programs, and program-integrity initiatives.

Many big ideas in healthcare interoperability are no longer aspirational; they are fully achievable with today’s production-ready technologies. We now have the tools to consolidate and transfer a patient’s complete medical record in real time, ensuring that new providers can deliver faster, better-informed, and safer care from day one. These same records can serve as the authoritative source for claims adjudication at the individual level, enabling fraud detection and eliminating vast administrative waste, producing immediate financial savings across the system. A national clearinghouse for EHR data would allow us to strategically optimize healthcare resources, guiding dollars toward what works and away from duplicative or ineffective interventions. Critically, this transformation does not require futuristic infrastructure or sweeping regulatory overhaul; it can be implemented today with minimal disruption. The long-term vision is clear: a learning health system that pays for what delivers results, not just what gets used, the true promise of value-based care and performance-driven payment.
Summary of Comments:

• The majority of clinically relevant facts, including cancer staging, biomarkers, social-risk factors, and imaging findings, remain hidden in unstructured notes and embedded image files. Unlocking that data is a prerequisite for quality care, accurate risk adjustment, timely gap closure, addressing health disparities, and detection of fraud or waste, which are all critical components of a modern, equitable healthcare system.

• AI-driven data extraction is production-ready, supporting data modernization. We have published validation for AI-based extraction yielding very high accuracy for clinically relevant details, yielding up to a five-fold information gain compared with document-level C-CDA alone and even larger improvements over current FHIR data exchange. Our customers are using these enhancements to close care gaps and fix the data-quality gap that hinders value-based contracts.

• CMS should treat computable, patient-level data, not just the envelope documents, as the default payload for TEFCA, Blue Button, and Bulk-FHIR transactions to effectively drive health equity, support value-based care, and enhance program integrity.

Detailed comments are included in our attached document.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Organization Name: Policy Center for Maternal Mental Health
Comment:
The Policy Center for Maternal Mental Health, a non-profit and non-partisan policy and research think tank, appreciates the opportunity to respond to the RFI on digital health solutions. Our comments focus on the potential of digital therapeutics (DTx) to improve maternal mental health (MMH) outcomes and the necessary federal policy infrastructure to support their effective use.

A notable example is MamaLift Plus, the first FDA-approved DTx for maternal mental health, which integrates evidence-based screening and treatment into a mobile app. Designed to promote open engagement and reduce stigma, it also features EMR integration and care team coordination. Clinical evidence shows it can divert two-thirds of cases from progressing into severe depression.

Recommendations for CMS Action
Standardize EMR Functionality: CMS should require primary care and OB EMRs to include clinical prompts based on evidence-based guidelines, such as routine screeners for maternal depression and anxiety. This standardization would ensure consistent care delivery and generate actionable clinical data for research.
Reimbursement Clarity for DTx: The 2025 Physician Fee Schedule introduces coding for digital mental health therapeutic (DMHT) devices, but without a national reimbursement framework, CMS risks fragmented implementation. Deferring to the seven regional Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs) may lead to inconsistent reimbursement rates and deter adoption. A unified billing policy is needed to drive provider and developer engagement.
Address Digital Literacy and Broadband Gaps: Federal support for digital literacy programs and broadband expansion, especially in rural areas, is essential. This would help overcome a major barrier to adoption among both patients and providers.
Promote Awareness and Training: CMS should support provider education on the distinctions between DTx and wellness apps, emphasizing their FDA oversight, clinical trial validation, and privacy protections. Use case demonstrations, reimbursement guidance, and integration strategies are key to broader uptake.
Responses to Select RFI Questions
PC-3: Health apps beneficial to Medicare patients and caregivers
MamaLift Plus exemplifies how DTx can enhance patient engagement, provide clinical insight, and connect seamlessly to provider EMRs. These features enable early identification of MMH conditions, timely interventions, and continuous care coordination.

PC-5a: Increasing adoption of digital health tools
Policy changes such as establishing clear reimbursement pathways, enhancing EMR integration, and educating stakeholders on DTx capabilities will accelerate adoption. Awareness campaigns and provider incentives are also necessary.

PC-6: Key accessibility features for digital tools
Accessibility hinges on broadband availability and digital literacy. Federal investment in state-level training and technology infrastructure can close gaps in access—critical to addressing geographic disparities in MMH outcomes.

PC-8c: Improving data interoperability and use
Standardized EMR platforms and integration of validated screening tools can streamline data collection and analysis. CMS should coordinate with vendors and standards bodies to align data elements and improve research quality and care delivery.

PR-1: Encouraging provider use of approved digital tools
Providers need education, support, and real-world examples to feel confident in prescribing DTx. Obstacles include infrastructure gaps, reimbursement uncertainty, and limited awareness—particularly in rural areas.

PR-1a: Information providers should share with patients
Providers must explain that DTx like MamaLift Plus undergo rigorous FDA review, are HIPAA-compliant, and maintain strict data security standards—on par with traditional medical treatments.

PR-1b: Provider responsibilities
DTx should supplement, not replace, clinician-managed care. Providers are responsible for monitoring use and ensuring patients remain connected to appropriate in-person or virtual clinical support.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I am writing to strongly advocate that the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) prioritize the adoption and enforcement of open, standardized protocols for the exchange of electronic healthcare records (EHRs), rather than endorsing or mandating specific platforms or vendors.

The internet's incredible success and interoperability are built upon foundational protocols like TCP/IP and HTTP. These protocols define how data is transmitted and secured, allowing countless different applications and services to communicate seamlessly, regardless of the underlying hardware or software. This model offers a powerful parallel for the future of healthcare interoperability.

Currently, the healthcare landscape is fragmented by proprietary systems and varying data exchange methods, creating significant barriers to efficient, secure, and comprehensive patient care. Mandating or favoring specific platforms stifles innovation, creates vendor lock-in, and ultimately hinders the fluid exchange of critical patient information across different healthcare providers and systems.

Instead, CMS should focus its efforts on developing and enforcing a robust set of common, vendor-agnostic protocols that define:

- Data Structure and Semantics: How health data is organized and understood consistently across systems.

- Secure Exchange Mechanisms: Standardized methods for encrypting and transmitting sensitive patient information.

- Authentication and Authorization: Protocols for verifying identities and controlling access to health data.

- Event-Driven Notifications: Standardized ways for systems to alert each other about relevant patient events (e.g., admissions, discharges, lab results).

By championing a protocol-centric approach, CMS can foster a truly interoperable healthcare ecosystem that benefits patients, providers, and innovators alike. This approach will:

- Promote Competition and Innovation: Allow a diverse array of vendors to develop solutions that comply with common standards, leading to better products and services.

- Reduce Costs: Eliminate the need for complex, custom integrations between disparate systems, saving significant resources for healthcare organizations.

- Improve Patient Care: Enable more complete and timely access to patient information, leading to better-informed clinical decisions and coordinated care.

- Enhance Data Security: Provide a consistent framework for secure data exchange, making it easier to identify and address vulnerabilities.

I urge CMS to learn from the lessons of the internet's open architecture and apply them to the critical task of achieving true healthcare interoperability. By focusing on defining the "how" through protocols, rather than the "what" through platforms, CMS can pave the way for a more connected, efficient, and patient-centered healthcare system.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
U.S. HEALTHCARE CYBERSECURITY MEASUREMENT
FOR PATIENT-PROTECTION AND HOSPITAL PREPAREDNESS

PROBLEM:
U.S. Healthcare is fragile due to its heavy dependence on interconnected IT systems, with continuous ransomware cyberattacks leading to frequent hospital outages impacting hundreds of thousands of patients.  To date current attempts to decrease this fragility have been reactive to individual events and government guidance reports, leaving the state of healthcare cybersecurity protection as both unmeasured and unknown.    

To be specific, at its core the U.S. healthcare system consists of interstate hospital systems, intrastate hospital systems, and independent hospitals.  The independent hospitals are mostly rural, and are particularly vulnerable to cyberattacks which can create severe continuity-of-care disruptions and even hospital closures - leaving entire communities without timely healthcare responsiveness for acute events.  

SOLUTION:

Working closely with a CMS threat intelligence (CTI) expert who provided requirements and originally developed the idea, we have used state-of-the-art U.S. technology to create a cybersecurity measurement system that can quantitatively measure cybersecurity metrics and provide a summary cybersecurity rating FOR ALL U.S. HOSPITALS thus providing measurement data and understanding about how best to proactively protect U.S. hospitals. We can thus proactively identify problems at hospitals in advance to prevent and deter cyberattacks instead of reactively addressing the aftermath of individual hospital shutdown events.

Leveraging the best available state-of-the-art U.S. technology, we have created a cybersecurity measurement system for ALL U.S. HOSPITALS, called CHART-PULL, which is now operational in a laboratory setting providing near-real-time information (updated nightly) and immediately poised to become a production system to support CMS if funded appropriately as a short-term pilot project or multi-year project.  CHART-PULL system is based on empirical analysis of network traffic and scan data. 

Our academic-corporate research team is based at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, including the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA) - home of MOSAIC the original Internet browser - and a team of professionals at the BitSight Corporation. 

BACKGROUND:  {only two recent examples, there are many more}
In February 2024, 190 million patients were affected when Change Healthcare suffered a ransomware attack outage which disrupted U.S. pharmacies nationwide for months causing patients to go without prescribed medications and consumer pharmacies to not be reimbursed, at a cost estimated to be $2.5 B.

In May 2024, Ascension Health suffered a ransomware attack outage which closed 140 hospitals affecting millions of patients both currently in the hospitals as well as diverting new patients to other hospitals.  Patients in these hospitals were immediately affected when IT systems were taken offline and doctors had to forgo IT-based protocols for testing, monitoring, and access to electronic medical records.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Commenting as American citizen and professionally as subject matter expert in healthcare practice and revenue cycle management:

With the focus on empowering seniors to manage their health journey, it is critical to have a foundational AI-driven platform taking an enterprise-wide approach, cautiously. However, most seniors are not technologically prepared to navigate digital applications but they are familiar with their provider's EHR system,  MyChart. as an example.  For those who want access to their medical records in real time, MyChart is readily available.  

Why not utilize this application making it user friendly for patients to independently access their information at a designated, privately enclosed area at their doctor's clinic the same way they can do so at home?

With proper education, guidance and simple step by step instructions, access can be readily available. Digital tools are sprouting all over and of great concern.  Besides being cost-prohibitive, the risks are many. The service delivered for the patient's benefit maybe seen as eliminating the paperwork for staff but will likely increase the cost of medical care overall.

AI is designed to improve efficiency on repetitive functions. Access to medical records must be protected. Why don't we give the control to keep their records private to the patient?

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As a dental policy consultant working within a state Medicaid program, I see firsthand how fragmented digital infrastructure impedes the integration of dental care into broader value-based and person-centered health systems. While these reflections are informed by my experience, they represent my personal perspective and not the official views of my department or employer.

Oral health continues to be siloed from most national health IT and care coordination strategies, despite its undeniable connection to systemic health. Dental providers often operate with electronic dental records (EDRs) that are not interoperable with medical electronic health records (EHRs) or health information exchanges (HIEs). This fragmentation contributes to missed opportunities for care coordination, burdensome documentation processes, and preventable disparities in access and outcomes—particularly for Medicaid-enrolled populations.

To better align with technology-enabled, value-based care, I encourage federal agencies to:

Integrate oral health into national interoperability frameworks and clarify that dental data should be part of health information exchanges and TEFCA implementation.

Support funding and incentives for dental-medical data integration, especially in safety-net settings like FQHCs, school-based programs, and rural clinics.

Encourage adoption of shared clinical terminology and coding systems, including ICD-10 and SNODENT, across EDRs and EHRs to enable coordinated care planning.

Reduce administrative burden by improving real-time data sharing for eligibility, benefits, and prior authorization processes across platforms.

Include oral health professionals and patients in digital health innovation pilots, ensuring that solutions address the specific needs and workflows of dental care delivery.

The path to a connected, patient-centered healthcare system must include oral health. I am grateful that CMS and ONC are soliciting input on this critical issue, and I hope this RFI marks a turning point toward truly interoperable care.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
NeuroFlow appreciates the opportunity to respond to this Request for Information regarding the Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0042-NC).
As a provider of behavioral health technology infrastructure across provider groups, health systems, payers, and government organizations—including 140 VA Medical Centers—NeuroFlow offers perspectives on how digital health technologies can advance behavioral health integration.

Digital Health Products for Medicare Beneficiaries (TD-1, PC-3)
To stimulate developer interest in digital health products for Medicare beneficiaries and caregivers:
- Establish reimbursement pathways for digital behavioral health solutions demonstrating outcomes and cost reduction.
- Develop frameworks to evaluate digital health effectiveness aligned with quality measurement.
- Integrate digital health education into Medicare enrollment and wellness visits to improve beneficiary digital literacy.
- Support providers with resources and best practices for introducing digital health tools.

Data Interoperability for Behavioral Health (PC-8, TD-13)
To enhance behavioral health data interoperability:
- Expand USCDI to include behavioral health assessment elements beyond PHQ-9 and GAD-7—priorities include substance use screenings (AUDIT-C, DAST-10), social determinants of health (SDOH), trauma screenings (PCL-5), and functional assessments.
- Leverage health IT standards for longitudinal tracking of behavioral health metrics and domain-specific documentation.
- Provide guidance for exchanging behavioral health information while upholding privacy protections under 42 CFR Part 2.
- Incentivize bidirectional integration of claims and clinical behavioral health systems for a real-time view of patient health.

API Implementation and Enhancement (PR-5, TD-10)
Regarding FHIR API capabilities and standardization:
- Extend APIs to support behavioral health use cases including assessment delivery, scoring, and longitudinal monitoring.
- Advance standardized resources and workflows for behavioral health practices such as care planning, risk stratification, and stepped care pathways.
- Develop guidance for secure exchange of sensitive behavioral health data, incorporating consent management aligned with regulatory requirements.
- Enable population-level behavioral health analytics and quality reporting via scalable, standards-based APIs.

Digital Identity and Patient Access (PC-14, TD-3)
Regarding digital identity credentials for healthcare access:
- Implement solutions addressing privacy considerations for behavioral health within identity management frameworks.
- Develop authentication guidance balancing security and accessibility for diverse populations.
- Create standards for delegated caregiver access specific to behavioral health.
- Support improved consent processes for behavioral health data sharing across the care continuum.

TEFCA Implementation Considerations (PC-10, PR-6)
Regarding TEFCA’s role in behavioral health information exchange:
- Enhance TEFCA implementation guides to address behavioral health use cases and privacy considerations.
- Develop guidance on handling sensitive behavioral health data within TEFCA.
- Address technical and operational barriers to behavioral health provider participation in health information networks.
- Create consent management standards specific to behavioral health information exchange under TEFCA.

Value-Based Care Technology Requirements (VB-3, VB-10)
On aligning technology requirements for providers in Alternative Payment Models (APMs):
- Enhance CEHRT criteria to better support behavioral health integration in value-based care.
- Provide flexibility in how APM participants demonstrate behavioral health capability adoption.
- Incorporate measurement-based care approaches into value-based technology requirements with flexibility in implementation.
- Support technology facilitating care coordination between physical and behavioral health providers in APMs.

Provider Burden Reduction (PR-7, PR-8)
To support providers in making behavioral health data available while reducing burden:
- Align behavioral health documentation requirements with clinical workflows.
- Streamline quality reporting by leveraging existing behavioral health measurement tools.
- Support bulk FHIR data exports to reduce manual quality reporting.
- Provide guidance for flexible behavioral health risk stratification.

Information Blocking Considerations (PR-12, TD-18)
Regarding information blocking and behavioral health data access:
- Develop guidance on when privacy protections for behavioral health data qualify as exceptions to information blocking.
- Address technical barriers to behavioral health data exchange that may be misinterpreted as information blocking.
- Provide educational resources for behavioral health providers on information blocking regulations and valid exceptions.
- Support enhanced consent management for sensitive behavioral health information sharing.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Hospital-at-Home has the promise of improved patient outcomes, improved patient experience, and reduced costs.  Given an aging demographic, Hospital-at-Home is part of a solution to most efficiently utilize available hospital beds for those who need them most while simultaneously reducing costs.  However there are many challenges that need to be identified and addressed before Hospital-at-Home becomes a reality on a wide scale.  

The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign has assembled and is currently convening a research working group of national experts researching the topic of “Hospital at Home”, specifically performing research on appropriate clinical use cases and human/technology challenges.

Under my leadership at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, I would like to propose leveraging our established research working group into organizing a one-day symposium on the topic of “Hospital-at-Home: Challenges and Solutions” to be hosted at CMS in the CMS Auditorium - with joint sponsorship from NIST and the National Academy of Medicine - both of these organizations have active interests on this topic.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Medical Alert Monitoring Association (MAMA) Response to CMS-0042-NC
June 5, 2025
Submitted electronically via https://www.regulations.gov
RE: Request for Information – CMS-0042-NC, Digital Health, Interoperability, and Technology for Medicare Beneficiaries

To whom it may concern,

On behalf of the Medical Alert Monitoring Association (MAMA), the national voice of the personal emergency response services (PERS) industry, we appreciate the opportunity to comment on CMS-0042-NC. Our association represents technology companies and monitoring providers that serve millions of vulnerable Americans, including Medicare beneficiaries living with chronic illness, limited mobility, or other risk factors for injury, hospitalization, or social isolation.

We commend CMS and ASTP/ONC for advancing the national conversation around equitable digital health access and interoperability. We urge you to recognize the essential role PERS plays as an established, scalable, and underutilized tool for achieving the core goals outlined in this RFI: improving health outcomes, reducing costs, and empowering patient-centered care for seniors and individuals with disabilities.

The Value of PERS in a Digital Health Ecosystem

PERS devices and monitoring services are already digital health products. They provide 24/7 access to emergency help and wellness interventions, often integrating with wearable sensors, home-based devices, and remote monitoring platforms. These services are life-saving for patients who live alone, are medically frail, or are at high risk of falls, medication nonadherence, or emergency events.

Despite their decades-long track record, PERS is rarely integrated into broader health IT or value-based care workflows. CMS can lead the way by:

Recognizing PERS as a foundational digital tool that enhances safety, autonomy, and outcomes for high-risk Medicare populations
Incentivizing plans to adopt PERS solutions as part of supplemental benefits, especially under Medicare Advantage, Dual-Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNPs), and ACO REACH programs
Creating pathways for PERS data integration into certified health IT platforms (e.g., EHRs or RPM dashboards), so these tools can support preventive interventions and reduce unnecessary hospital admissions
Key Policy Recommendations

We offer the following actionable ideas aligned with the RFI themes:

1. Digital Health Product Inclusion (PC-1, PC-5, VB-1)

CMS should explicitly include PERS and monitoring services in its definition and review of digital health tools eligible for reimbursement or program alignment. PERS should be considered in any future certification, quality, or impact framework for digital products.

2. Data Interoperability and Integration (PC-9, PR-4, TD-10)

To fully realize the value of PERS, CMS should create incentives or guidance that enable the real-time or near-real-time transmission of PERS events and wellness signals into care management platforms used by ACOs, primary care practices, and home-based care teams.

3. Value-Based Care Enablement (VB-3, VB-8)

Many PERS vendors offer capabilities beyond emergency response, including daily check-in features, geolocation tracking, medication reminders, and fall prediction using AI. These features should be recognized as meaningful contributors to value-based care objectives such as reduced ED visits, improved engagement, and early intervention.

4. Accessibility and Adoption (PC-6, PC-7)

Because PERS is already used by seniors with limited digital literacy, it represents a uniquely accessible form of connected care. CMS should invest in research and outcomes reporting on PERS usage, including its impact on loneliness, emergency room utilization, and time-to-intervention metrics.

Conclusion

We urge CMS to embrace PERS as a proven digital health solution with enormous untapped potential. It is cost-effective, deployable at scale, and trusted by patients. Integrating PERS into the broader digital infrastructure and value-based frameworks outlined in this RFI would have a profound impact on care quality and safety for Medicare beneficiaries.

We welcome the opportunity to collaborate further or provide real-world implementation examples from our members.

Sincerely,
Geoff Gross
President, Medical Alert Monitoring Association (MAMA)
info@mama.org
www.mama.org

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
CMS should focus on developing great products, not great standards. The "if you build it, they will come" approach has not produced the technology innovation CMS is looking for that makes people healthier and bends the health cost curve to a manageable rate of growth. Here are the three products CMS should build:

Product Recommendation #1. Build a Medicare Healthy Life App and make it available for free for Medicare FFS enrollees. Include diet management, exercise goals and tracking, nutrition information, social and gamification components, and possibly monetary or gift incentives. Most people lack access to powerful health improvement tools, but Medicare FFS individuals have the most limited access to a tool that is integrated with their claims, health status and coverage rules. If CMS issues an RFP to develop this product with objective engagement and lifestyle improvement objectives, industry will respond and deliver. The product should include special features for dual eligible beneficiaries (Medicare and Medicaid) and chronically ill beneficiaries as these populations require the most health management support and contribute disproportionately to preventable adverse outcomes and costs. This project could be new, or could build on the progress CMS has made with mymedicare, the Medicare Beneficiary Portal, and the Medicare coverage app. If CMS merely publishes standards and strategies and hopes the industry will "step up," this initiative will not be effective.

Product Recommendation #2. Build an AI-based Clinical Decision-Support Tool to guide Medicare national and local coverage decisions, both as general policies and as a point of care tool for providers. While AI cannot replace human decision-making by clinicians, it can inform, guide and improve these decisions based on the vast amounts of claims, clinical and demographic information combined with rapidly evolving AI-powered analytics. This tool would provide the data-driven rigor needed to make high-value and effective coverage and treatment decisions. Unnecessary and ineffective tests, procedures, and pharmaceuticals not only waste resources but also lead to adverse health outcomes like medical errors and potentially dangerous medication side effects. This product would shift the American health-care system towards the 50% lower per capita health care spending levels in the U.K., Germany, Japan, Italy, and France, all countries that out-perform the U.S. in terms of health outcomes and average lifespan. 

Product Recommendation #3. End the submission of paper and PDF medical records to CMS. This is both a policy and a technology recommendation. Each year, providers and plans submit millions of medical records, hundreds of pages in length, to CMS contractors so they can review them (by flipping through physical or virtual pages) to validate, deny or correct payments. Contractors also review these records to validate the submission of quality measures from EHR systems to CMS, which have both payment and safety implications. This process costs CMS hundreds of millions of dollars annually to fund manual contractor processes and billions in costs in provider burden. Moreover, this approach traps the power of clinical data in provider EHRs by creating a massive administrative and technology barrier to accessing clinical data. Structured data files exported from EHRs (e.g., HL7/FHIR/USCDI XML or JSON formats) can be more easily transmitted by providers and analyzed instantly by CMS systems, enabling the automation of most review use cases (including pre-service, pre-pay, or post-pay) except for the small number requiring true human judgement, most commonly associated with medical necessity determinations. And for those cases, the review can still be expedited and assisted with structured data analytics. CMS could establish a date, such as January 2027, to end all paper or PDF medical record submissions and adapt a centralized system to support this change, such as the CMS Electronic Submission of Medical Data (not Documents) (esMD).

All three of these products could be prototyped and piloted as CMMI models in specific regions, or for specific populations, prior to broader expansion. This type of model work would be more pragmatic, more measurable, and potentially deliver short-term results as opposed to the current CMMI models, many of which are lengthy, complex, payment formula–based models that are difficult to manage and assess. By favoring an indirect support model over building fully functional products, many promising CMS technology initiatives have stalled, or never reached their potential, such as creating a robust BlueButton-based app ecosystem, shifting health transactions to a national HIE network, FHIR-based measure reporting, AI-based medical review and many other needle movers.

Medkasa is a Baltimore-based HUBZone small business with 30+ years of experience working directly in CMS programs and systems.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1 (a)
I would like seniors to have the ability to know when their identity is used to file a claim.  The recent catheter scam, where beneficiaries were hit with copayment bills for goods and services never ordered by their physician and not needed, demonstrates the vulnerability that Medicare beneficiaries have.  The reporting process for potential fraud is cumbersome and requires significant manual intervention.  

PC-9 (b)Blue Button
Blue Button can be transformed to be a sentinel for senior to warn them about potential fraud and identity theft committed in their name.  Castlestone has already designed the application to automate the Blue Button query process and use that to identify potential fraudulent claims, and provide a simple interface for seniors to confirm or deny that the claim is legitimate.  

PC-14 Digital Identity
Castlestone has developed and deployed payment network technology to verify digital identity, verify outpatient claims and use of beneficiary and provider identities.  Virtual identification cards using the digital wallet capabilities already in place.  
a)	The challenges to get patients to sign up for digital identities in the Castlestone model are minimal.  An application can be easily downloaded from a game store.  Conversely, CMS can provide a web site to download an application including a virtual ID card that can be read at any standard card network terminal.  
b)	The benefits are substantial.  CMS and beneficiaries are better protected from fraud due to identity theft.  Providers identities are protected from misuse and authorizing claims for patients they never saw.  
c)	CMS can make this available today.  It is built and fully functioning and requires no new hardware or software at the provider office. 
 
PR-10  Digital identity credentials	
Providers already have digital identities in the form of an NPI.  Use of that identity, or any other for selected transactions should require multifactor authentication.  


CB-1 incentives to encourage ACOs or those participating in Medicare Shared Savings Program (MSSP)
Last year’s $3 billion catheter scam was a good example of where digital technologies can protect ACOs and those participating in MSSP.  There is no authentication that the physician, part of an ACO, ever ordered catheters in their office.  Using mobile (virtual card) and payment network technology, multi-factor authentication will reduce or eliminate the misuse of beneficiary and provider identities.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to provide input on the “Health Technology Ecosystem” Request for Information (HT RFI) on behalf of an initiative focused on enabling secure, interoperable, and privacy-preserving artificial intelligence across healthcare institutions.

We have developed a federated infrastructure for AI training and digital health delivery that aligns closely with the goals of CMS and ONC. Our system is designed to support innovation in areas such as surgical robotics, AI-assisted diagnostics, and software-based therapeutics—particularly those not currently accommodated by Remote Patient Monitoring (RPM) or Remote Therapeutic Monitoring (RTM) reimbursement categories.

Key Features of Our Architecture:
	•	Federated Learning: Local AI models train on-site using protected data. Encrypted updates—not raw data—are aggregated securely, preserving privacy while improving model performance.
	•	Cryptographic Identity Framework: Ensures only authorized healthcare nodes (e.g., surgical robots, EMRs, imaging devices) contribute to the learning network.
	•	Immutable Audit Trail: Participation, model contributions, and data access events are recorded transparently via distributed ledger technology to support regulatory and institutional compliance.
	•	Smart Governance Capabilities: Optional rule enforcement (e.g., data use policies, jurisdictional access controls) can be built into the system via programmable logic.
	•	Platform Agnostic: Compatible with existing EMR systems, imaging tools, robotic surgical platforms, and FDA-cleared digital devices.

This approach enables broad-scale innovation while upholding CMS’s mandates for patient privacy, data stewardship, and equity. It also lays the foundation for Medicare reimbursement of next-generation digital tools—including those covered under the proposed Prescription Digital Therapeutics (PDT) Act—by ensuring they are deployed in a secure, auditable, and interoperable framework.

Recommendation:
We respectfully urge CMS and ONC to consider:
	•	Expanding reimbursement eligibility to include AI-driven platforms that meet interoperability and privacy requirements
	•	Supporting non-centralized, privacy-preserving infrastructures like federated learning to advance access to real-time decision support and procedural intelligence
	•	Recognizing digital therapeutic systems and procedural robotics under a new class of reimbursable “interventional AI tools” within Medicare and Medicaid

We welcome the opportunity to engage further and support the national effort to modernize the healthcare technology ecosystem.

Sincerely,
Urologist

ID: CMS-2025-0050-0050.

Standards Development & Global Collaboration

FHIR Adoption & Health IT Modernization

•	Create CMS governing council of interoperability.
Incentives and Programs

Workforce and Education

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-3: Health Management and Care Navigation Tools
Existing apps (e.g., Medicare’s Blue Button-enabled tools, condition-specific platforms) provide basic data aggregation but lack caregiver-centric features. While apps like iBlueButton help beneficiaries access claims data, they fail to address critical gaps:
Training modules: 94% of caregivers lack formal training, yet no app integrates skill-building (e.g., wound care, dementia communication) with real-time expert feedback.
Mental health integration: Most apps omit burnout screening or connections to licensed therapists, despite caregivers facing 40-70% higher depression rates.
Task deconstruction: Complex care tasks (e.g., transitioning to assisted living) remain overwhelming; AI-driven tools to break tasks into daily checklists are rare.

PC-4: Missing Features and CMS Workflow Opportunities
a. Critical gaps in existing apps:
Gamified training platforms: Apps should reward caregivers for completing training modules (e.g., medication safety, crisis response) to address the 94% training gap. Current solutions lack adaptive learning or certification tracking.
Integrated mental health workflows: No app combines symptom tracking with automated referrals to low-cost teletherapy, despite evidence reducing caregiver depression by 37%.
Interoperable task managers: Tools to auto-populate care plans using CMS data (e.g., claims, EHRs) are missing, forcing caregivers to manually reconcile information.

a.i. Why these gaps persist:
Fragmented incentives: Developers prioritize patient-facing features over caregiver needs due to reimbursement structures.
Data silos: Lack of FHIR-enabled APIs for caregiver-specific workflows limits innovation.

b. CMS-specific workflows:
Standardized caregiver designation: Automate caregiver enrollment in EHRs during hospital discharge, triggering tailored app onboarding.
Real-time data sharing: Expand FHIR APIs to let apps pull Medicare Advantage data (e.g., ER visits) for proactive care alerts.
Cross-state licensure portals: Enable apps to connect caregivers with experts nationwide, bypassing state-specific barriers.


PC-5: Driving Adoption Through Policy and Technology
a. CMS review criteria and adoption strategies:
Certification framework: Use the Mobile Application Rating Scale (MARS) to evaluate apps on:
Clinical impact: ≥20% reduction in caregiver burden (Zarit Burden scores).
Interoperability: Seamless integration with CMS Patient Access API.
Reimbursement incentives: Offer MA plans bonuses for covering certified apps, mirroring Diabetes Prevention Program payments.
Gamification grants: Fund apps that reward caregivers for completing training or self-care tasks.

b. Enabling timely data access:
FHIR-based push notifications: Require providers to send automated updates to apps when care plans change.
API performance standards: Penalize EHR vendors with >500ms latency for data queries.
Caregiver data permissions: Expand HIPAA’s “personal representative” rule to enable app access without manual consent

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I have been in health care (specifically Home Health and Hospice) for over 33 years. It is heartening that CMS is focusing on improving technology to empower our patients. Health care has transitioned from a paper-based system to an electronic system.  For Home Health and Hospice, we have utilized several platforms for data management including PtCT (Patient Care Technologies), HCHB (Home Care Home Base), Allscripts, EPIC (including MyChart) and SHP (Strategic Data Platforms).   Our care providers’ paperwork burden has exponentially increased with each new implementation and in response to ever increasing regulatory requirements.  The 1995 Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) had the unintended consequence of increasing charting time per patient encounter.  Additionally, data management systems typically do not interface due to proprietary constraints.  The result is a fragmented medical record that is at the very least challenging to navigate.  I do not know of any data management system that gives the patient full access to their medical records.  Imaging is one of the biggest areas of waste in our health care system.  For example, a specialist may re-order a test that was previously provided from an outside unaffiliated (unintegrated) setting.  If patients were able to have a patient friendly, cloud-based system that seamlessly integrates information, it would drastically reduce unnecessary re-entry of medical information.  Giving patients access to their complete medical record would help them more effectively navigate the maze of health care.  This would also benefit providers who would have a complete picture of the patient’s health, reduce the documentation burden and allow for more face-to-face time with patients.  The result would be reduced health care costs.  A patient friendly platform should be able to contain ALL of the patient’s medical information.  Building a platform which integrates the best characteristics of current platforms is quite a challenge, but doable especially with AI technology.  
My Medical Images is one such application that gives patients images at their fingertips and offers cloud-based technology that allows for integration into all other platforms.  Imaging is a key component in care management.  It is also an expensive part of care.  Providing patients with their images as part of a comprehensive medical record is key for successful outcomes and management of Medicare patients.  I appreciate the opportunity to comment on health care management.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
At ChronicCare, we will provide input regarding the adoption of digital health technologies for Medicare beneficiaries and the infrastructure improvements necessary to foster interoperability and informed patient decision-making.

1. Overview of ChronicCare’s Mission and Services
ChronicCare is a mission-driven organization dedicated to improving outcomes and reducing the total cost of care for patients living with chronic conditions. We offer comprehensive Chronic Care Management (CCM), Remote Patient Monitoring (RPM), and Transitional Care Management (TCM) services that empower patients, providers, and payers to effectively manage chronic diseases in a scalable, data-driven, and patient-centered manner.

Our services are aligned with CMS’s value-based care goals and prioritize underserved populations, including Medicare beneficiaries, who often face barriers to access, coordination, and education.

2. Digital Health Products and Patient Empowerment
ChronicCare’s technology-enabled care model integrates biometric monitoring devices (e.g., for blood pressure, blood glucose, weight) with a user-friendly digital platform that allows patients and care teams to collaborate on personalized care plans. Our mobile apps and telehealth tools are designed to:

Provide real-time feedback and education to patients.

Facilitate remote engagement with care coordinators, nurses, and pharmacists.

Support medication adherence and lifestyle modifications through digital nudges and alerts.

Enable caregivers to stay connected and informed.

We have witnessed firsthand how the thoughtful use of digital tools can reduce hospitalizations, improve medication compliance, and increase patient satisfaction—especially among seniors who receive proactive guidance and support through our platform.

3. Health Data Interoperability and Infrastructure Gaps
A persistent challenge we encounter is the lack of seamless interoperability across EHR systems and data silos among providers, payers, and digital health vendors. ChronicCare supports federal efforts to standardize FHIR-based APIs, promote data portability, and ensure timely access to patient data for authorized stakeholders.

We strongly recommend:

Continued investment in trusted exchange frameworks and Qualified Health Information Networks (QHINs).

Mandating payer-provider data sharing for real-time medication, encounter, and care plan updates.

Funding for small practices and FQHCs to adopt and integrate CCM/RPM platforms with their EHRs.

4. Improving Digital Health Access for Medicare Beneficiaries
Many Medicare beneficiaries—especially in rural and medically underserved communities—lack the digital literacy, broadband access, or device availability to fully benefit from existing digital health products. ChronicCare addresses this by:

Providing devices (pre-configured and cellular-enabled) directly to patients.

Offering multilingual onboarding support and ongoing technical assistance.

Working with community partners (churches, senior centers, home health agencies) to bridge digital and social gaps.

Customizing outreach and education strategies to meet the cultural and cognitive needs of older adults.

We recommend that CMS expand reimbursement and incentives for digital literacy training, device distribution programs, and hybrid care models that blend tech-enabled services with high-touch care.

5. Using Data to Drive Health Equity and Policy Decisions
ChronicCare supports CMS’s goals to make more actionable data available to public health authorities, researchers, and policymakers. Our platform collects longitudinal, patient-generated data that can reveal trends in health outcomes, social determinants, and care gaps. However, we urge CMS to provide clearer guidance and funding mechanisms to:

Standardize how remote care data can be reported and shared under HIPAA-compliant frameworks.

Support analytic tools that integrate social risk factors into value-based care performance measures.

Encourage collaboration between private digital health companies and government data infrastructures.

Conclusion

The responsible adoption of digital health technologies holds immense promise for enhancing Medicare beneficiary health outcomes, driving system-wide efficiencies, and closing long-standing equity gaps. ChronicCare stands ready to partner with CMS, ONC, and other stakeholders to support the development of interoperable, patient-centered, and outcome-driven digital health infrastructure.

We welcome further dialogue and look forward to contributing to national efforts to modernize care for our most vulnerable populations.

Sincerely,
Dr. Cedrick Batchateu, PharmD
Founder and CEO, ChronicCare
support@chroniccare.net
