Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is Michael Kane, I am the founder of TEACHERS FOR CHOICE, a group of educators from New York who opposes all medical mandates to access society.

When it comes to health technology my primary concern is privacy rights for patients as well as parental rights. My requests are pretty straightforward

1. There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever.

3. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if AI or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted.

4. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Michael Kane
Founder, TEACHERS FOR CHOICE
TeachersforChoice.org

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to express my strong opposition to any federal initiatives or regulations within the proposed “Health Technology Ecosystem” that would infringe upon basic human rights—particularly the rights to medical privacy, parental authority, and bodily autonomy.

My concerns and expectations are as follows:

1. No Digital ID Requirement:
No individual should ever be required to possess or use a digital ID to access healthcare services in the United States. Healthcare is a human right and should never be conditioned upon compliance with digital identity systems.

2. Protection Against Biometric Data Mandates:
No one should be compelled to provide biometric data—such as facial recognition, fingerprints, retinal scans, or voice samples—in order to access healthcare. This is an unacceptable invasion of privacy.

3. Ban on Mandated Wearable Technology:
Under no circumstances should wearable devices be mandated for any health-related purpose. The principle of informed consent must always prevail. Any attempt to enforce wearable technology undermines personal autonomy and sets a dangerous precedent.

4. Right to Be Forgotten:
Patients must retain control over their personal health data. If artificial intelligence or other technological tools are used to collect or process data, individuals must have the right to request that such data be deleted entirely. Data collection should be opt-in, not opt-out, and subject to full transparency.

These are not radical positions—they are foundational principles of privacy, autonomy, and consent. I urge HHS to reconsider any policies or technological frameworks that would compromise these essential rights under the guise of modernization.

Sincerely

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is Tim Moon. I live in Minnesota, in the suburbs, where healthcare access is available, but your medical records are not. My wife has worked for years to enable HIE in Minnesota, but Epic hospitals refuse to cooperate, which leaves patients like me vulnerable. 

My parkinson's prevents me from working. I have memory problems related to the disease, so I am on social security and disability. Last year, I almost lost my disability benefits because we couldn't get a copy of my records from two providers' offices—Minneapolis Clinic of Neurology and Fairview Health Systems. 

We signed several forms for a copy of my records. We made numerous calls to follow up. We drove to the clinics in person and made requests. We argued with people over the phone and made complaints locally. The records never came. My wife ended up hacking the multiple MyChart accounts and retrieving PDFs, which she then sent to my email account, one page at a time. 

We were exhausted and frustrated, and I almost lost my disability benefit. 

My wife made two complaints to the ONC/ASTP information blocking website. We have never received confirmation of the submission, nor have we received any follow-up or resolution. This is fraud and misrepresentation. Why have a website if you never follow up or take any enforcement action? 

As my wife says, in Minnesota, we don't have HIE; we have Epic, and that system is tuned only to the business agendas of the local health systems, not to the needs of patients and caregivers. 

Timothy Moon
8462 152nd Place 
Minnesota
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As a nurse caring for stroke patients for over a decade, I see otherwise independent people who were working and providing for their family, come in with a new disabling brain injury. Often that can be improved with physical therapy, etc. but that requires so much time off work. Either to be in a hospital setting or for follow up appointments.

The patient and their caregiver, who may have been working as well, then need FMLA paperwork filled out so they can keep their income going during this time of upheaval. 

TIMELY SUBMISSION OF FMLA PAPERWORK IS CRITICAL IN PREVENTING UNNECESSARY UNEMPLOYMENT.

When delays occur—often due to confusion over employer-specific forms, uncertainty about which provider should complete the documentation, or administrative hurdles within healthcare systems—individuals may exhaust their paid leave or be penalized for absences, ultimately risking job loss. 

Often, an independent person who is working may not have a primary care/General Provider. Once leaving the hospital, the Primary Care may not have access to the hospital records to fill out the form accurately. And hospital staff may not be able to provide it after discharge without requesting from medical records, which can cause additonal delay.

A streamlined, standardized FMLA form that can be quickly completed and signed within the Electronic Health Record would reduce these delays, ensuring that those eligible for job-protected leave can access it promptly. 

By simplifying the process, we can safeguard employment during vulnerable times and support both health and economic stability.

I fully support the interoperability of oral health data with physical health data. The mouth and head are not separate from the body; each affects the other. And yet, without interoperability of oral and physical health data, each is blind to information about the other. It is critical for health care providers to be able to access all the information about their patient, not just part of it.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is John Matland, a former Candidate for US Congress and I was an Imaging Technologist for 18 years in New York. I opposes all medical mandates to access society. The mandates decimated healthcare from the employee retention aspect which negatively affected patient care. This will further the decline and out right destroy healthcare and the rights of the people seeking access to it. 

When it comes to health technology my primary concern is privacy rights for patients as well as parental rights. My requests are pretty straightforward:

1. There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever.

3. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard.

4. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if AI or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

John Matland R.T. (R)(CT)(ARRT),L.R.T.

@WeThePeopleAreTheNews

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Submitted on behalf of Salphaware, LLC, a veteran-owned health technology company

Please find attached our full comment in response to the Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS–0042–NC), Docket ID: CMS–2025–0050.

This submission reflects Salphaware’s constructive engagement with the proposed federal strategy. We offer perspective as a company actively developing hospital-aligned technologies that aim to enhance data interoperability, reduce administrative burden, and support quality reporting efforts, including in complex domains such as sepsis.

Our response shares observations regarding infrastructure readiness, suggests approaches to strengthen ethical and legal safeguards, and proposes frameworks that could help federal and private actors navigate this pivotal transformation. While our tools are still under development, they are being shaped in direct conversation with frontline hospital realities and regulatory intent.

We welcome continued engagement and are available to expand on any part of this submission.

Respectfully,

Wesley S. McFee
Founder & CEO, Salphaware, LLC

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: I am a dentist and health services researcher, and I want to convey the necessity of interoperability and data access that bridges the current silos between dentistry and other aspects of healthcare. I often have patients come in assuming that I have access to their medical diagnoses and medications, and it is cumbersome both for patients to need to share medication lists and health histories with multiple providers, and for me to ensure that my patients' health histories and medication lists are up to date. Interoperability would also facilitate better communication between medical and dental providers and enable us to provide more patient-centered and comprehensive care. The fact that dentistry/oral health is not in the pre-populated drop-down list for this open comment period is a perfect example of why this change is needed - dental care is a part of overall healthcare and should be treated as such with respect to patient and provider access to health information.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I want to comment on access to my and my loved ones' health information (re: https://www.federalregister.gov/d/2025-08701/p-41).

I had medical power of attorney and was involved in my parents' care during their stay at two assisted living facilities near me. They recently passed away at the ages of 88 and 92 from complications due to dementia. I visited my parents several times a week, and took them to doctor appointments and the hospital as needed. But I didn't have easy access to their health history, so I didn't always know how to answer questions that their doctors had (and that my parents couldn't answer because they didn't remember, at this point), especially because they moved from Florida to Indiana to be closer to myself and other family members. 

When the time comes for family to care for their loved ones, there needs to be one place to go to reference that patient's health history. Even if it requires some proof of relationship and the right to do so (patient privacy is the most important thing and must be maintained).

How many patient portals must a caregiver attempt to gain access to?  What if the patient never set it up, because back when they were seen, they didn't think they needed it (or didn't know how)? Now, an aging parent with cognitive decline or other issues that prevent them from being able to complete such tasks suddenly has no health history, in effect.  

Do I need access to labs and X-rays? Probably not. But I do need summary data and names/dates. (For example, something like - Dad saw his heart doctor, Dr. Doe, on 5/1/2021 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital - so that I can convey that information, or reach out to that doctor for whatever the current doctor needs.) 

I found out near the end of her life that my mom had Pulmonary fibrosis, something that would have been helpful for me to be aware of. I only found out after a visit to the ER, where a doctor asked if I knew how long she'd had it. Lack of convenient, comprehensive healthcare information puts added stress on caregivers and puts patients at risk.  

Thank you.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031: Enhancing Digital Health Adoption, Interoperability, and Responsible AI Use in Medicare

Submitted by:
Ricardo J. Silva, PhD, MBA, CCE
Chair, Artificial Intelligence Working Groups – IFMBE & GCEA
Member, IEEE Standards Committee on EHR Systems
Senior Advisor, World Health Organization
Professor of Health Informatics and AI, Villanova University

1. Introduction
As an academic, international advisor, and standards committee member with decades of experience in biomedical engineering, data interoperability, and ethical AI, I commend CMS for initiating this RFI to better understand and shape the digital health landscape for Medicare beneficiaries. I appreciate the opportunity to provide input on two areas I believe are critically underrepresented in the current proposal: data provenance and metadata for device-generated health data, and the governance, surveillance, and ethical integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS).

2. Background
CMS's initiative focuses on expanding the use of EHR systems and the Trusted Exchange Framework and Common Agreement (TEFCA) to support interoperability across providers, payors, and patients. While this is a necessary step, the current draft lacks strong articulation of how the quality and source of health data are tracked, and how advanced AI systems—already being used in many clinical contexts—will be safely governed and integrated under Medicare reimbursement structures.

3. Analysis and Gaps Identified
A. Data Provenance and Device Metadata
One of the most pressing risks in digital health data ecosystems is the ambiguity of data origin. For digital health to be trustworthy, especially in clinical decision-making and claims evaluation, CMS should require that every data point includes structured metadata identifying:

Who/what generated the data (device, provider, patient, AI, etc.)

Context of generation (setting, timestamp, credentials)

Technical specifications (e.g., device ID, last calibration date, error logs)

Such labeling is essential in remote patient monitoring (RPM), medical diagnostics, and risk scoring. Standards such as IEEE 11073 for device interoperability and IEEE 2621 for cybersecurity offer robust frameworks for metadata that CMS could require.

B. AI Governance and CDSS Oversight
Artificial Intelligence is notably absent from the proposal, despite its growing presence in diagnostics, scheduling, triage, payment reconciliation, and more. CMS must explicitly address:

Where explainable AI (XAI) is mandatory (e.g., high-risk clinical applications)

How premarket approval (PA) and especially post-market surveillance (PMS) of AI systems will be conducted

The establishment of AI Review Boards to evaluate evolving LLMs and CDSS tools under Medicare

The delineation of shared responsibility (developers, vendors, users) in the event of AI-driven adverse outcomes

CMS could leverage emerging standards such as IEEE 2802 (performance and safety of AI-based medical devices) and IEEE P2801 (quality management of datasets for AI in healthcare) to inform regulatory pathways.

4. Recommendations
Mandate standardized data provenance labeling across digital health platforms, especially for device and AI-generated data.

Incorporate AI safety, validation, and surveillance mechanisms explicitly into Medicare digital health strategy.

Establish an AI oversight body within CMS or HHS, with working groups for key AI use cases (e.g., CDSS, patient-facing apps, payment AI).

Adopt or adapt existing IEEE and ISO standards for AI and device interoperability, ensuring forward compatibility.

Encourage development of transparent metadata structures similar to DICOM for all clinically significant device data, enhancing patient safety, auditability, and claims validation.

5. Conclusion
The CMS effort is timely and well-directed, but must be broadened to ensure data trustworthiness and AI accountability. Without strong infrastructure for provenance and AI governance, digital health systems may compromise patient outcomes and system efficiency. I encourage CMS to treat AI integration and data transparency not as technical side-notes, but as core pillars of Medicare’s digital transformation.

Thank you for the opportunity to contribute to this vital initiative.

Respectfully,
Ricardo J. Silva, PhD, MBA, CCE
Villanova University

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The health IT ecosystem lacks basic patient-centric features, promoting burden, unnecessary costs, fraud, safety risks, and poor medical outcomes. Additionally, falsified information is being used for medical decision making, correlation with test orders/results, claims/payments, quality measures, research, and AI. No other profession has this low of a standard.

Many patient records contain vast misinformation, numerous errors, deliberate omissions, and fabricated information. Why are patients blocked from writing in our records? Blocked from making direct corrections to the visit notes? Blocked from uploading documents such as test results? Blocked from accessing most components of our records, such as triage notes, workflows, and timestamps? Why can't patients directly access all areas of our records?

It is imperative that patients:

-be permitted to write directly in the visit note above or below the provider's words to ensure valid/accurate data is recorded for use in decision making, AI, research
-be permitted to upload documents such as test results or symptom logs, directly into the encounter alongside the visit note to mitigate deliberate omissions, safety mishaps, and ensure the correct information is used for clinical decision making
-be granted direct access to all areas of the records to prevent burden and minimize falsification of records
-have a mechanism to directly correct visit notes to minimize burden, medical errors, and fraud (patient correction requests are burdensome and time consuming and are routinely denied, allowing misinformation to be used in clinical decision making) 
-be able to view all CPT codes and ICD-10 codes submitted with the claim for transparency and fraud prevention
-have all transactions such as test results pushed to patient file storage rather than require queries that allow providers to alter records

There are mechanisms used at various hospitals to falsify records and alter test results and the medical records in general. Incorporating the above features will also help minimize fraud, waste, and abuse associated with the medical record vulnerabilities. These features will also promote accuracy for data used for AI, research, and patient care.

Thank you for this opportunity.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Apps that don't exist but should:
1. App that allows direct, real-time patient access to all areas of the records, including AI input/outputs used in decision making
2. App that allows patients to insert corrections and documents directly in the visit note
3. App that allows patients to see all who accessed their record with the time and date
4. App that immediately pushes test results and other data to patients for safekeeping
5. App that facilitates provider experience of care reviews that can be connected to the visit and connected to a national directory
6. App for PACS access/store/share all radiology images
7. App that reads radiology images with AI and summarizes results, stored in the records alongside any AI or interpretations done on the provider end
8. App that shows all diagnoses and procedure codes associated with transactions

Why don't these exist?
1. Providers/health systems are clients of the EHR companies, so systems are created to maximize provider interests such as profit--often at the patient's expense
2. These mechanisms will help mitigate fraud 
3. These apps help mitigate concealment of medical errors, which is more widespread than people realize
4. Providers alter records and imaging studies, and these apps will minimize opportunities to do so
5. Providers manipulate imaging results and records to make it appear they are providing the standard of care when they are not; apps like these will help ensure some accountability
6. Information is power, and power enables profits
7. Information asymmetry enables medical paternalism and minimizes patient choice; the profession is still stuck in old ways
8. Many hospitals do not comply with HIPAA, and this is barely monitored and enforced
9. State boards barely provide oversight over clinical services, so there is little accountability which enables dysfunction
10. Corruption-institutionalized corruption created by the medical-industrial complex has created these systems that enable fraud, waste, abuse, and patient safety hazards

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Comment on CMS-0042-NC, Submitted by Marani Health

Marani Health, a digital health innovator focused on maternal and fetal care, appreciates the opportunity to provide input on CMS and ASTP/ONC’s Request for Information regarding digital health tools and health technology infrastructure.

We strongly support the Administration’s vision for a patient-centered, interoperable health technology ecosystem. We urge CMS and ONC to explicitly prioritize maternal health in its digital health strategy, and offer the following recommendations based on our work deploying prenatal monitoring technologies that serve Medicaid populations:
________________________________________
1. Enable Broader Data Access for Maternal Monitoring (PC-2, PC-9)
Our patients and providers face data fragmentation, often unable to unify pregnancy-specific clinical data (e.g., fetal heart rate, fundal height, weight gain trends) across systems. Integration of maternal and fetal data from devices and EMRs into APIs like Blue Button 2.0 would enable more holistic and timely care—especially valuable for managing high-risk pregnancies.
Recommendation: Expand API-supported data types to include pregnancy-related vitals, structured OB notes, and fetal monitoring outputs. Enable seamless third-party access through patient consent.
________________________________________
2. Prioritize Remote Monitoring in Covered Digital Health (PC-1, VB-3)
Non-invasive remote monitoring enables early detection of conditions like preeclampsia. CMS’s lack of clear support for such tools inhibits adoption by providers participating in value-based care (VBC) models.
Recommendation: Encourage or require digital maternal monitoring as part of maternity episode care bundles and APMs. Develop a CMS-reviewed list of effective tools with real-world evidence support for outcome improvement.
________________________________________
3. Promote Health Equity Through Access to Pregnancy Apps (PC-5, PC-6, VB-1)
Many underserved and rural patients lack the digital tools to navigate maternity care effectively. Navigation apps paired with monitoring can improve appointment adherence, triage support, and early complication detection.
Recommendation: Offer development incentives and reimbursement pathways for patient-facing tools designed specifically for prenatal care navigation and engagement. Address access barriers like smartphone availability, broadband gaps, and digital literacy through HHS programs.
________________________________________
4. Interoperability & Clinical Workflow Integration (PR-3, TD-4)
Maternal health data remains siloed. Providers cite challenges in integrating structured and unstructured OB data into care workflows. The result is burden and risk for patients.
Recommendation: Expand TEFCA priorities and certification standards to explicitly include obstetric/fetal monitoring data exchange. Incentivize maternal care providers' participation in health information networks and support FHIR APIs tailored to prenatal care workflows.
________________________________________
5. Real-World Data Collection to Validate Outcomes (PC-7, VB-10)
CMS can support innovation by collecting real-world data on digital maternal health tools—particularly those affecting readmissions, NICU stays, and maternal complications.
Recommendation: Establish a framework for voluntary real-world data submission on digital maternal tools and incorporate findings into future policy decisions around reimbursement and standards.
________________________________________
Closing
We urge CMS and ONC to treat maternal and perinatal health as a core test case for digital equity, interoperability, and VBC success. Marani Health is committed to collaborating with public partners to deliver the outcomes this initiative seeks.

Submitted by:
Marani Health
www.maranihealth.com

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
When it comes to health technology my primary concern is privacy rights for patients as well as parental rights. My requests are pretty straightforward:

1. There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever.

3. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard.

4. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if AI or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
In my view, many more problems are caused by government interference in citizens' health matters than are solved by it. We're individual living, thinking people, not interchangeable cogs in some machine. We don't need healthcare management to be better organized -- we need it to be rolled back so that we can manage our own health as is natural to us without unnecessary complication. Digitization of everything is a further complication that can only exacerbate citizens' helplessness when what we desperately need is to develop our capabilities as individuals, which we can certainly do if we're not overmanaged by institutions that insist on doing everything for us.

I want autonomy over my own health, not centralized management. I do not want to participate in a healthcare system that's even more centralized than the current one, however well organized and efficient. Above all, I absolutely do NOT want to be forced to have a digital ID to access healthcare or society. I do NOT want to be forced to give any biometric information to anyone to access healthcare. I DO want "the right to be forgotten" so if any AI is used to collect information about me, that information can be deleted from their systems and databases.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
At Doximity, our mission is to help physicians be more productive and provide better patient care. With over 80% of U.S. physicians as registered members, we have spent 15 years building a “LinkedIn for Doctors” with HIPAA-compliant tools that reduce administrative burden. We applaud CMS for recognizing the structural inefficiencies in today’s fragmented provider data ecosystem and for taking steps toward a unified National Provider Directory and secure Identity, Credential, and Access Management (ICAM) infrastructure.

We believe physicians deserve a modern, automated solution that reflects the realities of how they practice and interact with today’s digital systems. Too often, clinicians spend valuable time updating profile information across numerous disconnected directories, a process that creates duplication, inconsistency, and ultimately frustration. These consequences lead to delayed patient access and ultimately inferior care. Currently, physicians are required to navigate a multitude of credentialing and licensing processes. Unfortunately, these sites can be poorly designed, leaving physicians uncertain about which details will remain private and which will be publicly accessible. The accessibility of physicians’ personal information online can pose significant safety problems, including identity theft and harassment. A unified provider directory built on accurate, interoperable, and machine-readable data can meaningfully reduce the resource burden in addition to promoting physician safety. 

Doximity is well positioned to contribute to this vision. Our validated, continuously updated professional network includes detailed physician information, including subspecialties, academic history, cited publications, and current employment. Profiles on the Doximity platform are the most robust digital curriculum vitae (CV) for physicians in the country. When printed, our average CV spans more than 10 pages. These profile assets support not only accurate directory listings but also trust, identity resolution, and more intuitive referral workflows. Over the last five years, we have also implemented a unified OAuth-based login system across our physician tools, enabling secure and seamless access for providers and digital health players via an API model.

We encourage CMS to continue prioritizing automation, data interoperability, and strong governance as it builds this foundational infrastructure. We will continue to support efforts that align with our core mission to make the practice of medicine easier for physicians across the country.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Public Comment Submission
RE: Request for Information – Health Technology Ecosystem (Document Number 2025-08701)

As a federal employee supporting Medicare operations and enterprise transformation—and as the primary caregiver to a Medicare beneficiary—I appreciate the opportunity to provide input on the development of a more responsive and equitable health technology ecosystem. My professional work focuses on the alignment of business processes with modern technology strategies, including the use of artificial intelligence, automation, and data-driven tools in Medicare programs. Personally, I have witnessed how critical it is for beneficiaries to have access to technologies that support timely, independent health decisions. I respectfully offer the following comments for consideration:

1. Self-Monitoring Tools Are Essential for Medicare Beneficiaries

Medicare beneficiaries living with chronic conditions such as atrial fibrillation (Afib), hypertension, diabetes, and heart failure should be empowered to monitor their vital signs at home—without relying on a nurse or physician to perform the measurement. Access to vetted, high quality, easy-to-use tools such as blood pressure cuffs, heart rate monitors, glucometers, and pulse oximeters, along with mechanisms for directly transmitting this data to care teams in real time, is vital to early detection of complications and effective disease management.

As both a business architect and a caregiver, I believe that real-time, self-driven monitoring will reduce avoidable hospitalizations, emergency visits, and costly acute episodes, especially for beneficiaries with heart failure and/or Afib. CMS should promote coverage and integration of modern at-home monitoring tools within the Medicare program and ensure that beneficiaries receive the support and education necessary to use them effectively.

2. “Informed Health Decisions” Must Include Guidance on Where to Seek Care

The term “informed health decisions” should clearly encompass a beneficiary’s ability to assess where and when to seek care—especially for those with episodic conditions like Afib. CMS should prioritize technologies that help beneficiaries answer critical, real-time questions such as:

“Should I go to the Emergency Room or wait?”

“Is this symptom urgent or manageable?”

Accessible and easy-to-understand digital triage tools, symptom checkers, and AI-assisted care guidance should be included in the health technology ecosystem. These tools can support Medicare beneficiaries in making confident, safe, and cost-effective decisions—while also helping reduce unnecessary ER visits and improve care coordination.

3. Medication Management Tools Are Imperative for Chronic Condition Control

Medication management is a key element of chronic disease control. CMS should examine supporting technology-enabled solutions such as digital reminders, connected pill dispensers, and alerts for missed doses or potential drug interactions. These tools should be accessible to both beneficiaries and caregivers and ideally integrated with EHR and pharmacy systems to ensure real-time coordination with prescribers.

Additionally, Medicare beneficiaries should have access to secure, real-time communication with their care teams before filling or refilling high-cost prescriptions. This would help reduce the number of times beneficiaries pay hundreds of dollars for medications—particularly for heart conditions—only to later have their provider change the prescription. Avoiding these costly medication errors improves adherence and reduces avoidable health episodes.

Improved medication adherence and communication lead directly to fewer complications, hospitalizations, and ER visits—making this a high-impact area for innovation and investment within the health technology ecosystem.

4. Clear, Accessible Health Information Is Foundational to Beneficiary Empowerment
For any health technology ecosystem to truly serve Medicare beneficiaries, it must prioritize accessible, easy-to-read information about chronic condition prevention and care. Many beneficiaries struggle with health literacy, which can lead to misunderstanding diagnoses, missing important care steps, or failing to take preventive action.

CMS should ensure that digital platforms, care management tools, and educational content are:

-Written in plain language

-Available in multiple languages and accessible formats

-Visual or interactive when possible to aid comprehension

-Tailored to help beneficiaries understand how to manage their conditions day to day

When beneficiaries have clear, digestible information about their conditions—what symptoms to watch for, how to prevent complications, how to stay well—they are more likely to engage in self-care, follow provider recommendations, and avoid costly or dangerous health outcomes.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Sifter Solutions, Inc. appreciates the opportunity to provide additional comments in response to CMS’s Request for Information. We would like to highlight the Sifter Shopper Companion, a digital health tool designed to support food-as-medicine initiatives.

The Sifter platform connects individual health needs to personalized grocery guidance through real-time diet-matching technology. The Shopper Companion integrates seamlessly with third-party healthcare and wellness platforms to support nutrition-based interventions. Key capabilities include barcode scanning, condition-specific food prescriptions, and benefit redemption—empowering individuals to make informed, health-aligned food choices.

We believe solutions like the Sifter Shopper Companion are essential to advancing health equity and improving outcomes. By guiding patients to purchase foods that meet both prescribed dietary requirements and personal preferences, this tool supports sustainable, scalable models of nutrition care.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This is the second part of my individiual comments. The first part (part 1) comments posted earlier ID: CMS-2025-0050-0050).

The generalized bullet points are below:

1. Standards Development and Ontologies
•	CMS, ASTP/ONC should create a formal ontology for the national provider directory
•	Create SNOMED CT extensions for HCPCS/CPT to SNOMED CT maps among SNOMED International, AMA, CMS
•	SNOMED CT ECL should be adopted to query outbreak metadata
•	Promote IHE profiles like sIPS, SVCM
•	Use IPS sharing for emergency care, rural health, disaster response
•	ASTP/ONC should enforce Sequoia Project’s Data Usability Implementation Guide
•	Free intellectual property issues to use assessment scales nationally across standards and ontologies 

2. FHIR IG Adoption and Expansion
•	Adopting the Risk Adjustment FHIR IG will reduce clinician and administrative burden
•	AUCDI with chronic disease management plan in FHIR for Sparked FHIR accelerator – implement US realm
•	Autism USCDI+ data elements should be created 
•	Dementia and Alzheimer’s complications KPIs
•	The American medical specialties (American Academy of ____) should create respective FHIR IGs
•	Promote the electronic case reporting FHIR IG
•	Enable FHIR-based advance directive forms with the National Association for Home Care and Hospice
•	Create a FHIR-based Outbreak Report
•	Integrate and FHIRize the CDC NORS form for public health data exchange
•	Include digital payments vendors in FHIR exchange
•	Include DME pharmacy benefit for FHIR exchange
•	Expand CMS 0057 to include prescription drugs for FHIR exchange
3. Data Exchange Improvements (TEFCA + Validation)
•	TEFCA exchange sending Empty CDAs and CDAs without validation
•	TEFCA exchange should enforce validation for CDA/CCDAs and FHIR exchange
•	Eliminate duplicate testing under TEFCA with LOINC+SNOMED CT for lab, imaging, procedures orders and results
•	Partner Sequoia Project and NLM for terminology services in TEFCA
•	Adopt DS4P profiles for TEFCA sensitive data
4. Stakeholder Engagement & Collaboration
•	CMS should engage the AHA, AMA, ACHE and the related state chapters to spearhead FHIR adoption among health systems/hospital systems/providers
•	Engage medical equipment companies, referral mgmt. vendors, and third-party administrators to use FHIR
•	CMS, ASTP/ONC, NLM should sign a collaborative agreement with openEHR International
•	CMS should promote and adopt openEHR archetypes and templates to enable standardized, computable queries across archetype-based health records
•	CMS should sign a collaborative agreement with GA4GH to improve interoperable genomics data sharing
•	The transformation from EHRs and APIs to Unified Digital Health Platforms (UDHP)
5. Education, Certification & Incentives
•	Provide education credit hours via CMS and healthcare professional associations
•	PIQI certification program
•	Bonus incentives for cross-HIE FHIR exchange
6. Genomics Data
•	Scale genomics data sharing across API CEHRT
•	CMS should sign a collaborative agreement with Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH)

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
There are legitimate reasons for a nation to require its citizens to have an ID that confirms their identity.

However, requiring a digital ID to be presented "for no reason" other than government or private sector surveillance is a horrible idea.

The Fourth Amendment protects the right to privacy and prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures.

In situations where it is reasonable to require a citizen to present an ID, a bar code on a driver's license is sufficient to enable technological enhancement of the identification process. In these cases, precedent exists for querying government databases.

We do not need an electronic ID that enables tracking or stores personal information beyond basic identifying details.

WE DO NOT NEED A DIGITAL ID!

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
[full text of the ACT response to "CMS RFI: Health Technology Ecosystem" is in Attachment 1; the excerpt below is the conclusion presented in the full response]

Conclusion:
This RFI seeks stakeholder input to help CMS and ASTP/ONC “build on the existing policy framework to drive large-scale adoption of health management and care navigation applications, reduce barriers to data access and exchange, realize the potential of recent innovations in healthcare that promote better health outcomes, and accelerate progress towards a patient-centric learning health system.” 

Formed in November 2023, the Accelerating Care Transformation (ACT) initiative builds on 20 years of successful collaborative work toward these same goals involving HHS (including CMS, ONC, and many other HHS agencies), VA, and many private stakeholders. ACT provides proven frameworks, methods, tools, and collaborations that can be applied to addressing – individually and collectively - many of the challenges and opportunities identified in the RFI. For example, improving patient-centered workflows and outcomes (e.g., population health, patient/care team experience, costs) within and across targets and organizations, surfacing and disseminating best practices and tools, breaking down silos and building cross-stakeholder consensus, and supporting standards-based exchange and use of computable/ interoperable data, evidence, and information management tools.  We would be happy to answer questions and further cultivate these opportunities.
Jerome A. Osheroff, MD, FACP, FACMI for the ACT Steering Committee (members listed here: https://www.tmitconsulting.com/act-initiative)

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is Kate, and I live in Minnesota. In 2024, I was pregnant and in active labor in rural Minnesota. I received all of my prenatal care in Shakopee, Minnesota, though I lived 25 minutes further south. I couldn't receive care in my own city, because Mayo Clinic in April 2024 closed down the maternity services in New Prague, MN. 

I had a normal course of prenatal care, experienced gestational diabetes, and was expected to deliver a normal vaginal birth at the hospital where my OB doctor practiced in Shakopee, MN. When I started active labor, I was discouraged from entering the hospital; now I know that the hospital didn't have any beds for laboring soon-to-be new moms like me. Unfortunately, that instruction created a problem for me later because my water had broken, and I was leaking amniotic fluid, something I reported to my OB office. 

Later that day, the contractions became more frequent, and I again called for instructions. This time, I was told to drive to the hospital. However, before we could get to my car, I received a call telling us not to go to the hospital where I had planned to deliver my child. Instead, I was diverted to a Twin Cities hospital almost an hour from where I live. We got in the car and started to drive, but again, we received a call telling us that there were no beds and to go to a different hospital, this time in the southern metro suburb.

We headed to the north and anticipated that the hospital would be waiting for us. Unfortunately, we were called again, and this time, we were informed that no beds were available. We were diverted a fourth time, and this time to a critical access hospital that is 1 hour south of the Twin Cities and to the south and east of where we live in Southwest Minnesota. We were told to go to Northfield, Minnesota.

My doctors didn't practice at this hospital, nor did they have privileges at any other hospitals except the original one. In Minnesota, our medical records don't follow us, and there is no record of me ever having been seen at Northfield Hospital. The lack of infrastructure in Minnesota puts me and my baby at risk, and the lack of beds and rural maternal child care for pregnant moms puts 10% of all births in Minnesota in jeopardy of a bad outcome. 

I am submitting this comment because the state of Minnesota needs help, and there needs to be protections for patients like me who have no control over where we end up delivering our babies. The doctors, staff, and employees of Northfield had no way to know what my prenatal care looked like or who I was, or what special care I may or may not need. 

Rural maternal care and connected health records are a fundamental right.

Kate Bixler
New Prague, MN

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This was in the report on ID: CMS-2025-0050-0050

I realized I did not separate out the below paragraphs. This point may be more of a longer term goal.

CMS and ASTP/ONC should explicitly include care delivery organizations (CDOs)—including those structured as independent physician associations (IPAs) or affiliated with payers—within the definition of “providers” required to adopt API-enabled Certified EHR Technology (CEHRT). This inclusion is essential to reflect the reality of evolving healthcare delivery models, enhance interoperability, and ensure patients and consumers have consistent access to their electronic health information.
CMS should also require all CDOs submitting data to CMS—particularly for programs such as quality reporting, value-based care, and risk adjustment—to use CEHRT with robust support for both CDA and FHIR APIs. To reduce reliance on PDFs and manual processes, CMS should accelerate the transition to FHIR-based submission workflows by providing clear implementation guides and financial incentives. These actions will improve data timeliness, accuracy, and patient outcomes.

FHIR and CDA education should be done to flow from the parent organizations of provider health systems and payer-affiliated care delivery organizations down to frontline staff, including insurance verification specialists and certified medical assistants. Ensuring that all levels of clinical and administrative personnel are knowledgeable about interoperability standards is critical to successful implementation, data accuracy, and improving patient care coordination.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-2. Do you have easy access to your own health information in one location?

No. Obtaining records is unnecessarily burdensome or not possible. The available patient portals block access to many areas of the records. I am required to fill out burdensome forms to ask permission from health care organizations to obtain my own records, and sometimes they never send them. Please revise the patient user login profile requirements to enable patient access to all areas of the records. There should NOT be separate systems for providers and patients to access medical records.

b. If not, in what contexts or for what workflows would it be most valuable to use one portal or system to access all such health information? 

I would greatly benefit from access to the system that stores the radiology images. It is very difficult to get the complete set of images that I want to share with other providers or family members. There should NOT be separate systems for providers and patients to access radiology imaging studies. Patients should not be required to request permission from anyone to obtain their records, fill out forms to obtain records, or jump through hoops to get them. Additionally, the raw images should be automatically released to the patient as soon as they are captured, before the patient leaves the testing site.

c. Were there particular data types, such as x-rays or specific test results, that were unavailable? 

•	I cannot access the Epic Care Everywhere feature to monitor for accuracy the information being shared among multiple organizations, which is often different that the information visible to me in my record. This is a violation of my HIPAA rights.
•	I’ve discovered some organizations have 2 different versions of the visit notes, but I can only access one version. The accessible version often contains minimal information but the detailed version of the visit note is inaccessible to me. This is a violation of my HIPAA rights.
•	I cannot access my original EKG reports. Sometimes the original EKG reports are available but overwritten with a vague conclusion. The EKG test facilitator prints a copy of the EKG report at the testing site for the provider, but I am not permitted to have a printed copy myself even though it takes 2 seconds to print the extra copy. Sometimes it takes weeks for the EKG report to be released on the portal, and still then, often the original EKG report output is overwritten by a provider’s conclusion or a vague statement that masks the original results. It is best practice to add an interpretation but preserve the original automated output.
•	I cannot access other test results, such as an endoscopy reports.
•	I cannot access diagnoses used for claims and clinical decision making.
•	I cannot access radiology imaging orders to monitor the accuracy of the reason for the study indicated on the order, but the reason determines the testing protocol and guides the interpretation of the results.
•	I cannot access radiology images. When the image studies are provided, components of the image results are blocked, require a password to access certain images through links, or removed from the study results altogether.
•	I cannot access the logs to see who edited test results and other record information, who shared my information, where it was shared, and who received it.
•	I cannot view the clinical decision tools, profiles, and scores that impact the care I receive.

Again, there should not be ‘separate systems’ of access for patients and providers. I should be able to obtain and monitor all information in my chart including all information used in clinical decision making or for other reasons. I am the only person looking out for my safety and accordingly, should have access to everything.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-4 - APPS THAT SHOULD EXIST

A patient-controlled global medical record is needed that automatically preserves the original record including test results. Patients are in a unique position to collate all their medical records in one place. The app should allow connection to any EHR or app the patient chooses, and any new information generated by external health care organizations-especially EHRs-should be pushed to the patients' global record account automatically.

Audit features in EHRs do not protect patients. Many health organizations change the records, including test results and claims diagnosis, after it is discovered the patient had a serious problem or dies, but wasn't given appropriate medical care. The record is recreated to make it look like the providers did things right when in reality, they ignored the patient's obvious signs. Old EHRs or old EHR software configurations that lack audit features still in use are used to alter the medical record then imported back into the newer EHR. Fixing this problem would promote patient safety and therefore reduce costs, and prevent fraud. The system currently in place incentivizes poor quality of care because providers know the records can be altered later if something bad happens to the patient.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
CMS, ASTP/ONC, NLM should support adoption of the ICNP–SNOMED CT Nursing Reference Set to reduce nursing documentation burden by enabling streamlined, structured documentation, reducing redundant data entry, and improving clinical decision support. This aligns with the CMS burden reduction agenda, promotes efficient EHR use, and enhances nursing contributions to team-based, high-quality care.

1. Streamlines and Standardizes Documentation
•	With standardized codes and concepts for common nursing problems, goals, and interventions, nurses spend less time searching for or free-texting terms in EHRs.
•	Drop-downs, templates, and clinical decision support (CDS) can be pre-populated with ICNP-SNOMED CT terms, making documentation faster and more intuitive.

2. Reduces Redundant Data Entry
•	Structured nursing data can be reused across workflows (e.g., care plans, quality reporting, shift handoffs), minimizing the need to re-document the same information in multiple places.
•	It supports interoperable reuse, meaning data collected in one system can auto-populate or sync with another, which is crucial for home health, post-acute, or long-term care nurses.
3. Enables More Intelligent EHR Interfaces
•	ICNP-SNOMED CT-coded data enables smarter, context-aware clinical decision support, nudging nurses toward evidence-based actions without adding extra documentation tasks.
•	Over time, this could allow automation of routine documentation (e.g., “standard fall precautions initiated”) based on clinical context.

4. Improves Team Communication Without Extra Charting
•	Standardized terminology allows other team members (physicians, care managers, social workers) to better understand and act on nursing documentation.
•	This reduces follow-up calls, notes, and redundant communication tasks that often fall on nurses.

5. Reduces Burden of Quality Reporting and Audits
•	Structured, coded data supports automated reporting for quality measures (e.g., pressure ulcer prevention, mobility), reducing the burden of manual chart review or retroactive coding.
•	This helps nurses spend more time on direct patient care instead of audit preparation.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
File Code: CMS-0042-NC
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this request for information. I am a board certified pathologist, and I spent the last ten years of my career before retirement as a medical officer in the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation (ASPE) in the Department of Health and Human Services. Prior to my work at ASPE I was at CMS where I worked on the Doctors Office Quality Information Technology Project and its continuation through the Quality Improvement Organization’s 8th scope of work. Based on this experience, our health technology ecosystem is limited in its performance for the following reasons.

First, it does not consider the tremendous complexity of diagnosing and treating the numerous disease combinations found in Medicare patients. While at ASPE I had access to a comprehensive database of Medicare claims data as well as extensive access to analytical tools and statisticians. The central finding of this research is that patients are surprisingly unique in their medical histories even at the national level. For example, the most complex 35% of Medicare patients account for approximately 80% of Medicare expenditures, and the national cell size of patients with similar disease combinations in this group is approximately 5 individuals. Each of these distinct combinations is small and scattered across the nation. One way to view this statistical fact is that patients with one of the many combinations of multiple diagnosis would fall into a patient cluster size that meets the requirements for classification as a rare disease. Thus, multiple comorbid patients face the same challenges as a patient with a single rare disease. Notably, even the largest healthcare systems do not have access to enough patient data to form useful datasets for artificial intelligence (AI) training or to perform clinical trials on these numerous small clusters of complex patients.

Secondly, it fails to incentivize the sharing of patient data required to train and validate the numerous applications of AI needed to improve patient care. AI training requires access to large high quality data sets. Given the extraordinary variability of humans and the resultant complexities found in all aspects of patient care, it is crucial that the current state of the art of clinical data be improved if we are to maximize the benefit of AI. In many ways it is unclear how accurate our data sets are, and the ability to aggregate them and share them with appropriate privacy and security protections needs improvement.

Thirdly, it fails to improve the accuracy and timeliness of the diagnostic process and thus reduce diagnostic errors.  Indeed, health care organizations are rewarded financially for unnecessary testing that may delay and complicate the patient’s treatment. Contributing to this issue is that providers have access to clinical laboratories with thousands of different tests to choose from, and an ever growing variety of new tests are becoming available. There is a similar explosion in new imaging modalities. No individual human can keep up with this level of complexity, and it is clear that new solutions are needed at every step from test selection through test result interpretation. This will require significant advances in the application of AI as well as significant organizational changes to the diagnostic branches of healthcare. Examples of these changes would include the national adoption of digital pathology, greater integration of pathology and radiology services, and the formation of diagnostic management teams to help providers care for specific patients.

Fourthly, it does not adequately incentivize the development and adoption of advanced diagnostic technologies. We are witnessing a renaissance in the development of new diagnostic tests (genetic, cell phone data etc.) many of which extend into the patient’s home and working environments. Again, our current health technology ecosystem is proving slow to integrate these technologies and provide an optimal environment for establishing their utility or lack thereof.

Finally, there is an overreliance on highly centralized quality improvement and measurement strategies that fail to account for the high level of variation and complexity found in human disease. To correct this deficiency, the future health technology ecosystem must support the sharing of data and knowledge needed to treat the numerous small patient clusters that are found nationally.

To further address these issues, please read the following peer reviewed paper describing how a new national marketplace based on data and knowledge sharing can be developed that meets the actual needs of providers when caring for a specific complex patient. A copy of this article has been uploaded as part of this response, and it may also be found at:  https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7047746/

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ONC) seek input on how to accelerate a patient‑centered, standards‑based digital ecosystem that improves outcomes and lowers cost. Rune Labs strongly supports this objective and offers the following key points drawn from our work with StrivePD - the leading digital management platform for Parkinson’s disease (PD):

1. Passive, consumer‑grade sensors meaningfully reduce acute‑care utilization. In a Kaiser Permanente pilot, StrivePD users experienced a 42 % reduction in emergency‑department visits compared with matched controls. We encourage CMS to recognize such digital biomarkers as legitimate measures for Alternative Payment Models (APMs) and expand Remote Therapeutic Monitoring (RTM) codes beyond musculoskeletal use cases.

2. API‑first data exchange should explicitly include Patient‑Generated Health Data (PGHD). StrivePD’s Apple HealthKit pipeline already produces FHIR resources that can flow into Blue Button 2.0. CMS should add PGHD to USCDI v4 and require Qualified Health Information Networks (QHINs) to support those data classes.

3. Digital identity rules must preserve consumer‑friendly sign‑on methods. Medicare Beneficiary Identifiers (MBIs) and NIST IAL2/AAL2 requirements should allow third‑party authenticators such as Apple ID to avoid disenfranchising older beneficiaries.

4. Value‑Based Care models need timely, device‑collected outcomes. Continuous gait‑quality and mobility metrics captured by smartphones detect progression 3–6 months earlier than in‑clinic scales; CMS should pilot such measures in the Innovation Center’s forthcoming neuro‑degenerative VBC models.

5. Early engagement with specialty‑specific digital platforms de‑risks TEFCA adoption. Requiring QHIN‑level certification for PGHD exchange without clear transition funding would stall innovation; we propose a phased glide path tied to public–private testbeds.

We provided detailed evidence, recommendations, and implementation considerations in the PDF attached. We stand ready to serve as a real‑world test case as CMS and ONC operationalize the policies outlined in this RFI.

Thank you for publishing the Federal Register notice entitled “Request for Information; Health Technology Ecosystem” (CMS-0042-NC) (the “Notice”). Highlander Health appreciates the Agency’s commitment to advancing health technology infrastructure and improving data-based decision-making. Highlander Health Institute (“HHI” or the “Institute”) is a public interest platform that develops learning labs in a variety of settings. The Institute brings together provider, regulatory, academic, tech and life sciences collaborators to set the standard in next-generation evidence generation and care. Our aim is to nurture pressure-tested, practical, and widely shared answers to longstanding problems in how we assess and access treatments

We welcome the opportunity to provide feedback on the state of data interoperability and broader health technology infrastructure. Please see the attached file for our full comments and please contact us with any questions or comments.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Response to CMS RFI CMS-0042-NC: Enabling a Shoppable, Value-Based Healthcare Marketplace

Tendo appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback to CMS/HHS 

In operating a national healthcare marketplace serving self-insured employers, we have consistently observed that informed patients and navigators make value-driven decisions when they can compare cost, quality, and convenience. Enabling this transparency creates healthy market competition, drives efficiency, and reduces overall healthcare costs.

The RFI, particularly in Section PC-12a(1-5), highlights critical use cases such as “finding the right provider,” access to “binding costs,” and visibility into “quality metrics.” These goals directly align with building a shoppable healthcare experience—one that allows patients to see the total cost of an episode of care and compare provider quality in a meaningful, procedure-specific way.

Section TD-19 highlights the current limitations of price transparency. We believe the next policy evolution is to make this transparency actionable—enabling patients to not only compare options but also purchase care directly. In other words, to treat healthcare like e-commerce.

Furthermore, Sections VB-2 and VB-10 emphasize the need for technology that supports clinical quality measurement, risk adjustment, and value-based models like episode-of-care bundles. These goals are best served by platforms that streamline care delivery and payment through bundled, pre-negotiated, and quality-assured offerings.

We strongly encourage CMS to explore and support models that enable this level of consumer engagement and simplification. A marketplace built on transparent binding costs, useful quality metrics, and seamless e-commerce workflows can help modernize Medicare, expand patient choice, and improve affordability through natural market dynamics and incentivizing efficiency.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is Leslie Manookian, I am the president of Health Freedom Defense Fund (HFDF). I am writing to express our concerns as they relate to the request for information from HHS surrounding the "Health Technology Ecosystem" and what impact this will have on the liberties and freedoms of all Americans. In my personal capacity, during the recently ended Idaho legislative session, I drafted and helped to pass the IDAHO MEDICAL FREEDOM ACT which bans nearly all mandates for the state of Idaho. I did this because I am deeply passionate about civil liberties especially surrounding issues of health.

DIGITAL ID
HHS has put out a request for information at the following link:
https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/05/16/2025-08701/request-for-information-health-technology-ecosystem

Under 3b & d in the Digital Identity section, HHS poses the following question, "Regarding digital identity credentials ... What impact would mandatory credentials have on a nationwide provider directory?" HFDF and I are resolute in our conviction that digital identity must never be a requirement to access healthcare for any American citizen. The entire program should be an opt-in program barring mandates of any kind. However, should the system come to pass, then HHS must provide a valid mechanism to opt-out of such a digital ID requirement without impacting the type or quality of healthcare available to every individual.

BIOMETRICS
Implicit in the questions HHS raises surrounding digital identity is what biometric data requirements will be implemented. Again, HFDF stands staunchly opposed to any biometric data requirement for any American to access healthcare and should such requirements come to pass, there MUST be permanent valid op-outs without impacting the type or quality of healthcare provided.

WEARABLES
When it comes to wearable technology every American should have the right to decide whether to utilize such technology or not. The IDAHO MEDICAL FREEDOM ACT explicitly prohibits any private or state actor from requiring a medical interventions or requirements including devices and wearables in order to lead a normal life. It is a little-known fact that in 2018 the state of West Virginia attempted to require all teachers to wear Fitbits to access medical insurance. The teachers rose up in what became a historic strike and this requirement was abolished. The attempt by authorities to impose such a requirement illustrates that some stakeholders take no issue with mandating wearable technology. This morally repugnant stance implies that human beings are nothing more than livestock to be tagged and must never be tolerated in America, a nation that values human dignity and the value of every individual. A West Virginian teacher discusses this issue at the following link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pa9MVP5aMdQ

The "right to be forgotten"
With the rise of AI and data being viewed as "the new oil," some European nations have placed value on a concept known as "the right to be forgotten." If a patient receives medical care from a doctor or provider who is using AI tools, the patient has the right to determine whether their information is saved in a database or deleted permanently.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As an American citizen I am concerned about protecting our basic freedoms and privacy rights.

1. There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever.

3. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard.

4. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if AI or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted.

Please help guard our freedom.

Thank you,
Roberta Amley

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The Maternal Mental Health Leadership Alliance (MMHLA) respectfully submits the following comment in response to the joint RFI from CMS and the Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT. We commend the agencies’ focus on improving digital health infrastructure and encourage the inclusion of maternal mental health (MMH) as a key priority throughout the digital health policy landscape.  Digital health tools play a critical role in improving maternal mental health outcomes and addressing the maternal morbidity and mortality crisis in the United States. Mental health, including suicide and overdose, is a leading cause of maternal mortality in the U.S. and globally. Suicide remains the leading cause of direct maternal deaths in the first postnatal year, often occurring during the second half of that year. Maternal mental health conditions—such as perinatal depression, anxiety, and postpartum psychosis—not only represent some of the most common complications of pregnancy and childbirth, but also significantly increase the risk of suicide. Digital innovations present unique opportunities to bridge care gaps, especially for underserved and remote populations. One such approach is collaborative care—a team-based model that integrates mental health services into primary and obstetric care through shared care plans, regular case reviews, and measurement-based treatment. This model improves screening, diagnosis, and access to timely treatment, and when paired with digital tools, can further expand reach and reduce stigma by connecting patients to care in convenient, low-barrier settings.
MMHLA’s Technology Council serves as a strategic forum for technology companies in the maternal mental health space to partner in advancing education, awareness, and policy solutions that support the mental health of mothers and childbearing people across the United States. Through this Council, MMHLA is building partnerships, developing strategies, and expanding organizational capacity to strengthen the digital maternal mental health ecosystem. By fostering collaboration with innovators in digital health, MMHLA aims to improve the effectiveness and reach of tools that support maternal mental health screening, treatment, and ongoing care. These efforts align with the broader federal focus on health technology infrastructure, including recent initiatives such as CMS and ASTP/ONC’s request for information on digital health tools for Medicare beneficiaries. Effective and responsible adoption of digital tools can empower patients to make better-informed decisions, improve access to care, and expand data availability for stakeholders working to reduce maternal morbidity and mortality. MMHLA and its partners are committed to shaping a future in which all mothers and birthing people have equitable access to high-quality digital mental health care.

Digital platforms and telehealth services can provide timely access to mental health screenings, interventions, and follow-up care regardless of geographical or logistical barriers. This is especially crucial given the shortage of perinatal mental health providers nationwide and the frequent lack of coordinated behavioral health support in obstetric and primary care settings. Moreover, integrating these tools into electronic health records and making screening results interoperable allows for better monitoring, referrals, and follow-up, leading to more comprehensive, patient-centered care.

Beyond access, digital tools can reduce stigma by offering anonymous symptom tracking, peer support communities, and culturally relevant education. These capabilities encourage individuals who may otherwise be reluctant to seek help to engage earlier and more consistently. Furthermore, digital health applications and provider directories can empower patients with actionable information to make informed choices, increasing self-efficacy and engagement in their care.

The inclusion of maternal mental health functionality in national health IT standards and CMS-supported tools will also support data-driven decision-making. By capturing maternal mental health metrics, CMS can better understand patient needs, identify service gaps, and design responsive quality improvement initiatives.

Incorporating maternal mental health into the broader digital health ecosystem should not be optional—as it is essential to reversing the alarming rise in maternal mortality, particularly due to mental health complications and substance use. Digital health innovation is a cost-effective, scalable, and urgently needed solution to ensure every birthing person receives timely, equitable, and evidence-based care.  Please contact us if you have questions and/or would like additional information.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the CMS RFI related to Information Blocking and the implementation of the 21st Century Cures Act. I am writing to strongly recommend that CMS enhance the current requirement for publishing a practice’s service base URL to also include a complete listing of all associated providers at the National Provider Identifier (NPI) level.

The current requirement, while a meaningful step forward, does not sufficiently support patients in identifying or accessing health information tied to a specific provider involved in their care. In large or multi-specialty organizations, patients often receive treatment from a wide range of professionals under a single practice or facility umbrella. Simply publishing the practice-level URL obscures the link between an individual provider and the patient’s health data, thereby weakening the spirit of patient-directed interoperability that the Cures Act aims to promote.

By requiring the inclusion of NPI-level detail alongside the base URL, patients will be empowered to direct their health information requests to the exact provider on record for their care. This refinement would help eliminate confusion, minimize delays, and ensure a more streamlined and transparent process for patients seeking to aggregate or share their medical history, especially in scenarios involving second opinions, transitions of care, or participation in clinical research.

Moreover, this enhancement would reinforce the accountability of each Provider Actor as defined by the Cures Act. By publicly associating their NPI with a service base URL, providers are reminded of their individual responsibility to enable access, exchange, and use of electronic health information in a timely and complete manner. In practice, this could reduce instances of unintentional or deliberate information blocking at the individual level, promote better compliance, and enhance auditability.

In short, expanding this requirement is not merely a technical improvement, it is a patient-centric policy refinement that aligns with the broader goals of the Cures Act: advancing transparency, access, and patient autonomy. I urge CMS to consider this enhancement as part of the ongoing rulemaking process and to collaborate with ONC to ensure consistency across regulatory frameworks.

Respectfully submitted,

Wayne Singer 
SVP Regulatory Affairs
Darena Solutions LLC

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Flexpa is the leading consent management platform enabling patients to securely access and share their health claims data from over 320 U.S. health plans via standardized FHIR APIs. As the operator of the nation’s largest network of Patient Access API connections, we have direct, hands-on experience implementing CMS-9115-F requirements and troubleshooting real-world interoperability challenges. Our mission is to build infrastructure that supports meaningful digital health innovation by ensuring patient-controlled, seamless, and secure data exchange.

In our comment on CMS-0042, we outlined several recommendations grounded in this operational experience. We urged CMS to strengthen implementation quality and enforcement mechanisms for Patient Access APIs, address current fragmentation in digital identity systems, and modernize the Blue Button 2.0 API to bring Traditional Medicare into alignment with Medicare Advantage. We highlighted gaps in current payer API implementations—including missing or inconsistent USCDI elements—and called for rigorous conformance testing, machine-readable validation, and public audits tied to financial incentives. We also recommended API-based EHI export and support for high-assurance digital identity credentials like Login.gov, which would reduce patient login friction, improve fraud monitoring, and increase adoption across the ecosystem.

We also called attention to payer behaviors that mirror information blocking—such as opaque developer registration processes, unresponsive support, and arbitrary rate limits—which remain unaddressed due to current regulatory scope. We urged CMS to extend information blocking provisions to payers and invest in education for payer staff who often lack the knowledge to support patient-directed access. Our letter advocates for hybrid infrastructure models that allow both direct and shared-network connectivity, creating a level playing field for developers and improving data consistency. Flexpa is committed to partnering with CMS and the broader healthcare ecosystem to advance patient access and unlock the full potential of interoperable health data.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Attached is a comprehensive comment document addressing the CMS Health Technology Ecosystem RFI (File Code: CMS-0042-NC). This submission provides detailed recommendations across multiple sections including Value-Based Care Organizations, Patients and Caregivers, Providers, Payers, and Technology Vendors.

The attached PDF presents a vision for transforming Medicare into a patient-empowered healthcare ecosystem through six critical transformation areas: transparent information infrastructure, aligned economic incentives, elimination of information silos, revolutionized care coordination, modernized regulatory frameworks, and supporting infrastructure for all beneficiaries.

Key recommendations include mandatory value-based care participation, universal interoperability requirements, AI-enhanced patient engagement tools, and comprehensive data transparency initiatives. The document responds to specific RFI questions while advocating for systematic healthcare transformation that empowers patients, improves outcomes, and controls costs.

Please see the attached PDF for the complete detailed analysis and recommendations.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Intro:

Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the provided questions on how CMS and HHS can make healthcare access and technology more effective. Years of rulemaking and incentives for open access to healthcare information have not solved the problem of patients lacking consistent and easy access to their records. Confusing hurdles force many patients to give up.
Despite the poor progress on open access technology, the overall digitization of healthcare has sped up with providers and payors spending records amounts of money on digital services that don’t follow open standards, create data silos, and create waste and friction. This has also resulted in patients losing control of their data and how it’s used.
CMS and HHS must ensure open documentation and free availability of foundational healthcare frameworks and give patients and their families control over their records.

See the full response attached and thank you for your attention.
