Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
pulling this extract out of ID: CMS-2025-0050-0254

FMLA and ADA forms on FHIR
To improve the efficiency, consistency, and interoperability of medical certifications under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), CMS should work with the Department of Labor (DOL), ONC, and standards organizations to digitize the FMLA process using open health data standards such as FHIR and  openEHR.
FMLA certification forms (e.g., WH-380 series) currently rely on manual, paper-based workflows that burden clinicians, delay patients' access to job-protected leave, and create administrative overhead for employers. By leveraging HL7 FHIR resources such as Condition, CarePlan, Practitioner, and DocumentReference, the clinical portions of the forms can be automated and exchanged directly from certified EHRs. Additionally, openEHR’s archetype-based approach offers a robust model for long-term storage, computability, and data validation, particularly for complex use cases such as intermittent leave or chronic conditions.
FHIR can support real-time generation and sharing of required certification data through SMART on FHIR apps, while openEHR templates can serve as durable, version-controlled clinical models aligned with existing documentation standards. Integrating these approaches would reduce clinician burnout, speed up patient access to leave, and improve data quality for oversight and policy analysis.
CMS should consider pilot programs or interagency collaborations to:
•	Define a standardized FMLA Questionnaire/QuestionnaireResponse using FHIR
•	Promote the use of openEHR templates for clinical certification of medical necessity
•	Engage EHR vendors and employers to implement interoperable, standards-based workflows
•	Ensure patient and employee data rights are preserved during electronic exchange
CMS should engage leave management vendors stakeholders such as Sedgwick, ReedGroup, Unum, AbsenceSoft, and Matrix Absence Management. These vendors process millions of FMLA and ADA claims each year on behalf of employers and already interact with healthcare providers. Supporting their adoption of FHIR APIs for intake of clinical certification data would align with CMS’s goals of reducing burden and improving coordination across sectors. The ASTP/ONC and HL7 International should also engage leave management vendors as stakeholders to do FHIR API based exchange.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1a, PC-2b, PC-4a, PC-11b

CMS, researchers, experts, and commenters are losing sight of the forest for the trees.

Despite seamless integration, team-based, patient-centric, value-based, quality improvement, incentivized, digitized, standardized, outcome focused, accessible, burden reduction, patient experience, interoperability, care coordination, social determinants of health, innovation, transformation, leveraging, and technologically enhanced initiatives, many struggle to obtain basic medical care. 

Do the ‘experts’ have secret health care systems? Because It seems like everyone talks about these things but few are doing them.

***To prevent chronic illness, we need our providers to diagnose us in a timely manner.***

Yet, this is often unobtainable. And for reasons unrelated to insurance. It would be helpful to have an app (not owned by the medical provider) such as ChatGPT that is integrated into the EHR. The patient would enter their symptoms, and AI would correlate with the patient's history to output a list of differential diagnoses and next steps such as testing. This output would be captured into the visit note. This would be highly beneficial and help prevent chronic illness because it would facilitate timely and accurate diagnosis.

The health IT ecosystem seems to be building on the existing dysfunction. This might be one of the few circumstances where it might be better to simply reinvent the wheel. Create a centralized patient record into which all information feeds and is managed. 

Please work to understand patient needs. Read some social media posts to learn what the average care-seeking patient goes through merely to obtain basic medical care. Understand that our health systems often create chronic illness, yet efforts to prevent this seem to be directed mostly at the patient. Our stories often sound nothing like what is being offered by the commenters and existing systems overall.

Thank you
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This comment pertains to PC-4, apps needed that do not exist.

An app that allows me to add corrections directly to the providers note is very much needed to prevent medical errors and chronic illness. Even to obtain basic medical treatment. 

It's impossible to have an accurate medical record. My record is so inaccurate that it seems to be about someone else. When I ask for corrections,  they are usually denied even when I have proof. Or I hear no response about it at all. At the most, I am permitted to add a statement that gets buried in some obscure part of the record that no one reads. And it takes months to get it added. 

Better yet, just let the patient add reason for the visit and symptoms and any test results directly to the provider's note. This would help ensure i receive quality care.

I think this capability doesn't exist because the records are set up with intentional errors. Because if the real information was there, the doctor might be questioned for not providing the standard of care. In other words, doctors would be incentives to do their job.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Patient.com appreciates the opportunity to respond to this RFI, CMS-0042-NC.  To achieve “the promise of radical transparency” and usability in healthcare data and ensure individuals “have the information they need to make well-informed healthcare decisions.” We propose the following opportunities:
1.	Resolve information blocking. 
a.	Allow digital health products to use the “High Confidence” Identity Assurance Level 2 (IAL2) and Authenticator Assurance Level 2 (AAL2) (NIST SP 800-63-3) processes to access Clearinghouse, Blue Button 2.0 and QHIN clinical data in multiple ways.  
i.	A BAA should not be required with a Covered Entity for an IAS. 
ii.	Digital Health Products should be able to use IAL2 and AAL2 service which is developed and managed internally or from any suitable vendor and not only the six certified Credential Service Providers. 
iii.	Instead of requiring individual login and password credentials, as with Blue Button 2.0 and other Payer Patient Access APIs, allow bulk access to the data using demographics gathered from the IAL2 process. 
b.	Reconsider the Common Agreement for Trusted Exchange Framework.  A contract in this scenario may be limiting possible networks, participants and sub-participants from joining.  Decreased management of this contract process would lead to cost reduction.  
c.	Encourage and incentivize participation of Covered Entities in the Trusted Exchange Framework Common Agreement (TEFCA) Qualified Health Information Network (QHIN). 
d.	Penalize TEFCA QHIN participants and subparticipants who do not return data for the currently required exchange purposes of Treatment (T-TREAT) and Individual Access Services (T-IAS).  
e.	Access to QHIN Directory remains limited to RCE and QHINs but should be made public as soon as possible. 
f.	Create a modified version of TEFCA for Individual Access Services with terms that recognize the generation of queries with a patient’s consent, invoking FTC Act and the Health Breach Notification Rule obligations instead of HIPAA.
g.	Ensure all data queried is returned without geofencing. 
h.	Ensure the availability of complete price information in a standard data format for clinical products and services to patients prior to encounters and order fulfillment that is easy to access and comprehend. 
2.	Ensure the “Patients over Paperwork” commitment to “cut the red tape” and “…allow providers to concentrate on their primary mission: improving health outcomes”. 
a.	Allow digital health products to facilitate patients’ access to ASC X12 Version 5010 transaction data through HETS and other clearinghouses without the necessity of a provider’s credentials.  
b.	Remove the HETS provider affidavit requirement for ASC X12 Version 5010 transactions.
c.	Allow bulk ASC X12 Version 5010 transactions requested by digital products on behalf of patients without requiring provider credentials.   
3.	Advance Standards more quickly. 
a.	Advance the other exchange purposes (XPs) from the TEFCA Standard Operating procedure V.3 August 6, 2024 quickly. 
b.	Regarding the United States Core Data for Interoperability (USCDI):
i.	Review the Standards Version Advancement Process (SVAP) for any concerns and if none, promote the United States Core Data for Interoperability (USCDI) to the current approved version, 5.  
ii.	Reinstate the Health Information Technology Advisory Board to continue advancing USCDI. 
iii.	Review and approve new versions of USCDI faster, at least quarterly. 
iv.	Incorporate more data classes and elements in USCDI versions.
c.	Incentivize QHIN and other health information networks for end-to-end FHIR exchange for quicker implementation. 
d.	Maintain the January 1, 2027 requirement for the CMS Interoperability and Prior Authorization Rule (CMS-0057-F)
Please see details and citations in the attachments.  Thank you.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This response to the HHS RFI CMS-0042-NC regarding Health Technology Ecosystem  is specific to PC-8c. What specific opportunities and challenges exist to improve accessibility, interoperability and integration of clinical data from different sources to enable more meaningful clinical research and generation of actionable evidence?

A key challenge in enabling more meaningful clinical research and generation of actionable evidence is the lack of shared agreement in how to communicate clinical research and evidence data throughout all phases of research design, conduct, analysis, and reporting.

Key opportunities are established with the Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR (EBMonFHIR) Implementation Guide and the Scientific Evidence Code System (SEVCO). 

The HL7 FHIR standard (Health Level 7 International Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) is already accepted and encouraged throughout the CMS/ASTP/ONC efforts noted in this HHS RFI as the standard for health data exchange.  Prior to 2018 there was no equivalent standard to support data exchange for scientific evidence.

In 2018, participants from communities of biomedical/healthcare research, systematic review development, clinical practice guideline development, and clinical decision support development collaborated to obtain approval of HL7 to extend FHIR to evidence-based medicine (EBM) knowledge assets, a project now called EBMonFHIR.

The community supporting the EBMonFHIR project evolved to become the Health Evidence Knowledge Accelerator (HEvKA), an open collaborative effort with 10 to 15 active working groups meeting weekly and bringing together at least 100 people from many disciplines and at least 18 countries. Participant details at https://fevir.net/HEvKA 

The EBMonFHIR project has extended FHIR to be used for science data exchange.  For example, a FHIR Evidence Resource provides a standard form to represent what the evidence is about (e.g. the effect on mortality comparing a treatment with a placebo in a specific population), the statistical findings for that evidence (e.g. a relative risk reduction of 5% with 95% confidence interval ranging from 10% risk reduction to 2% risk increase, or an absolute risk reduction of 10 fewer deaths per 1,000 people with 95% confidence interval ranging from 20 fewer deaths per 1,000 people to 4 more deaths per 1,000 people), and the certainty of the evidence (e.g. low certainty due to limitations in study design and wide confidence intervals). 

The Evidence Based Medicine on FHIR Implementation Guide (available at https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/ebm) covers many aspects of science data exchange.  It covers the broad scope of representation of scientific knowledge, including (1) citations to represent identification, location, classification, and attribution for knowledge artifacts; (2) components of research study design including study eligibility criteria (cohort definitions) and endpoint analysis plans; (3) research results including the statistic findings, definition of variables for which those findings apply, and the certainty of these findings; (4) assessments of research results; (5) aggregation and synthesis of research results; (6) judgments regarding evidence syntheses and contextual factors related to recommendations; (7) recommendations; and (8) compositions of combinations of these types of knowledge. The types of interoperability covered include syntactic (Resource StructureDefinitions) and semantic (value sets).

Strengths of the EBMonFHIR IG include development and maintenance within the ANSI-approved standards development processes with HL7, coordination with the HL7 FHIR standard used widely for health data, a broad community across the evidence ecosystem, and providing a base solution for interoperable data exchange across the EBM and patient care communities.

The Scientific Evidence Code System (SEVCO) (available at https://fevir.net/sevco) is a standard vocabulary for research study design, statistics, and risk of bias. SEVCO release 2.0 includes 468 terms with hierarchical relationships. The terms include definitions, alternative terms, and comments for application. The SEVCO ontology supports precise, unambiguous, machine-interpretable reporting of research. SEVCO was developed by an open, global, multidisciplinary, expert working group.

Strengths of SEVCO include openness (transparency and inclusiveness) for consensus development, comprehensiveness in scope of coverage, attention to prior works, diverse multidisciplinary participation, open access, and availability in both human-readable and machine-interpretable forms.

Leveraging this technical standard (EBMonFHIR) and standard vocabulary (SEVCO) can enable the clinical research and evidence ecosystem to experience interoperability like that found in financial, navigation, and entertainment ecosystems.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Extract from part 2 of my comments with ID: CMS-2025-0050-0254

Enabling FHIR-Based Advance Directive Forms Through IP Clearance

Background:
The National Association for Home Care & Hospice (NAHC) stewards widely used advance directive forms across states. These forms often have IP restrictions limiting their digital, interoperable use. CMS can play a pivotal role in negotiating IP clearance and fostering adoption of standardized, FHIR-enabled advance directive forms to improve care coordination and patient empowerment.

Link to the forms that you can click on by state:

https://www.aarp.org/caregiving/financial-legal/free-printable-advance-directives/


Recommendation:
CMS should establish a multi-stakeholder initiative with NAHC, CaringInfo, state health agencies, EHR vendors, and standards organizations (HL7 International, ASTP/ONC, SNOMED International, Regenstrief Institute) to:
1.	Negotiate IP licensing agreements with NAHC and states to permit the use of advance directive forms in interoperable digital formats (FHIR resources).
2.	Support development and publication of FHIR Implementation Guides for advance directive forms aligned with state legal requirements.
3.	Incentivize adoption through Medicare/Medicaid quality programs and EHR  and API CEHRT certification criteria requiring support for FHIR-based advance directives.
4.	Encourage state alignment to harmonize legal and policy frameworks facilitating cross-state interoperability.
5.	Fund education and outreach for healthcare providers and IT implementers on the use of standardized digital advance directives.
Expected Outcome:
This approach will reduce IP barriers, enable interoperable advance directive data exchange nationwide, enhance patient-centered care, and improve clinical decision-making at transitions of care.
•	Digitize advance directives (move from PDFs/paper to structured digital forms)
•	FHIR-enable advance directives for nationwide interoperability
•	Resolve IP barriers with NAHC/CaringInfo/state forms
•	Support state-specific legal requirements in a standardized FHIR framework
•	Empower patients and families to view, update, and share directives digitally
•	Make directives available at point of care (ERs, hospitals, EMS, LTC, etc.)
•	Improve care coordination and decision-making across settings

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: CMS, in coordination with the Office of the National Coordinator for Health IT (ONC) and the Assistant Secretary for Technology and Policy (ASTP), should formally align the National Library of Medicine’s (NLM) Health Data Standards Branch with national interoperability implementation efforts, including The Sequoia Project and TEFCA. Given NLM’s role as the U.S. National Release Center for SNOMED CT, this alignment is essential to ensure consistent terminology governance, support SNOMED CT adoption in FHIR-based exchange (including USCDI+ domains), and strengthen terminology validation infrastructure across the ecosystem. A coordinated governance model would improve implementation fidelity, reduce variation in SNOMED CT use, and accelerate high-quality clinical data interoperability.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1(a)a. What are the top things you would like to be able to do for your or your loved ones' health that can be enabled by digital health products? 

Access HIE to view and monitor information shared so that I can understand the rationale for clinical decision making, monitor for accuracy, and watch for fraud. 

Does CMS realize the HIE systems block patients from accessing them and so are designed to circumvent HIPAA? The exchanges share information about my health that I never see in the version of records I request. How can patients exercise their HIPAA rights to request corrections if they cannot even view the records?

Does CMS realize that providers can login and have instant access to patient records, but the subject of the record-the patient-is blocked from the records (aside from the minimal 'patient portal') must ask permission to view them, wait 30 days to view them, and often do not ever get the information requested?

If CMS was serious about patient centered news, we would simply have a login or mechanism to instatantly see all areas of our medical records.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Imaging 

TEFCA with Imaging 
TEFCA should prioritize the inclusion of imaging exchange use cases, leveraging existing IHE profiles such as XDS-I.b, MHD, and AIR. While imaging has historically been excluded from TEFCA’s initial document-focused design, national imaging interoperability is critical for AI workflows, diagnostics, and care coordination.
CMS and ASTP/ONC should partner with organizations like IHE, RSNA, and vendors with FHIR/DICOMweb experience to advance TEFCA-aligned imaging pilots. TEFCA must eventually support imaging for it to be a comprehensive national framework.
Imaging with FHIR 
CMS should promote the adoption of HL7 FHIR for radiology to improve the interoperability, accessibility, and computability of imaging data across care settings. Today, imaging reports are often exchanged in narrative form via CDA or as unstructured PDFs, which limits their usefulness in clinical decision support, care coordination, and patient access.
FHIR resources like ImagingStudy and DiagnosticReport, when integrated with DICOMweb, enable rich, structured, standards-based radiology data exchange. This is essential for emergency response, telehealth, value-based care, and post-acute care.
I recommend CMS encourage the use of FHIR-based APIs for radiology in CEHRT certification, promote the use of DICOM-FHIR mappings, and prioritize structured radiology data in USCDI expansion. Including radiology interoperability in CMS and ASTP/ONC’s regulatory frameworks will unlock substantial clinical and operational value.

openEHR with radiology
openEHR provides a rich modeling environment for structured radiology results and imaging-related clinical observations. CMS and ASTP/ONC should explore integration patterns where openEHR-based structured reports can feed into FHIR-based APIs or TEFCA networks, especially for longitudinal imaging follow-up in oncology, neurology, or population health use cases. While DICOM and FHIR handle transport, openEHR supports semantic persistence and querying of imaging context over time.

SNOMED CT

SNOMED CT is useful for imaging with the clinical concepts for the radiology findings, like the imaging observable entities, such as 

<<Imaging finding (finding): 365853002
<<Imaging interpretation (observable entity): 282290005
<<Imaging observable (observable entity): 399060005

To support high-value radiology use cases such as AI-driven decision support, precision medicine, and longitudinal imaging follow-up, CMS and ONC should promote consistent use of SNOMED CT for three distinct but interrelated components:
1.	Imaging Procedures – Representing what was done (e.g., 169069000 |CT of chest|, 
Computed tomography of chest (procedure): 169069000

Magnetic resonance imaging of brain with contrast (procedure): 16327691000119101


using SNOMED CT ensures standardization of imaging modalities, body regions, and intent (diagnostic, screening, follow-up).

2.	Observable Entities – Capturing structured measurements and characteristics such as size, attenuation, location, or number of findings 
Lump size (observable entity): 248529005
Number of lesions (observable entity): 246206008 
provides the computable backbone for AI, tumor tracking, and structured reporting.

3.	Findings and Impressions – Coding clinical conclusions derived from imaging, such as 
Solitary nodule of lung (finding): 427359005
enables semantic alignment with registries, downstream care, and analytics.
These three SNOMED CT hierarchies—used together—create a fully structured radiology record that can be expressed in FHIR DiagnosticReport and Observation resources, or modeled in openEHR using archetypes like imaging_exam_result.v1.
CMS should encourage certification requirements and TEFCA QHIN workflows that support this level of semantic structuring to enable image-enabled clinical decision-making, cohort identification, and longitudinal follow-up. This approach also aligns with emerging IHE profiles (e.g., AIR), openEHR adoption in the EU, and global convergence around FHIR and SNOMED CT for imaging interoperability.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My comment pertains to PC-12 - barriers to competition.

Interoperability involving medical records and claims data is drastically reducing competition, decreasing patient choice, and reducing quality of care.

Medical providers do not compete. Patients can’t get a second opinion anywhere. And if the patient has been misdiagnosed or experienced a medical error at any point in time, providers will not accurately diagnose the patient, leaving the patient with no treatment and creating chronic illness. Each doctor copies the last incorrect note, test result, or diagnosis. This occurs even if the patient is unsafe, even if the diagnosis contradicts reality. It is intentional. It is the culture.

Patients should hold the records in a central repository and have the ability to choose what to share with which providers and when. There should be incentives for providers to want to do better instead of maintaining the status quo.
 
It must be recognized that doctors often create chronic illness. CMS better find a way to fix this and keep patients safe. It is only getting worse as interoperability increases.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I. Introduction

Massive Bio, Inc. is an AI-driven oncology clinical trial and real-world data technology company committed to democratizing access to advanced cancer care and research. Through our SYNERGY-AI platform, we engage over 160,000 consented oncology patients across 17 countries and integrate clinical, genomic, and real-world data from over 3,400 sites and 100,000 physicians. Recognized by the White House Cancer Moonshot, our mission is to transform access to precision oncology through patient-centric, digitally enabled platforms.

We appreciate the opportunity to provide public comment on CMS’s Request for Information 2025-08701 regarding the Health Technology Ecosystem. We commend CMS, ASTP, and ONC for taking steps to empower patients, foster interoperability, and create a trusted, seamless digital health landscape for Medicare beneficiaries.

Our comments focus primarily on:

PC-1 through PC-12 (Patients and Caregivers)

PR-1 through PR-4 (Providers)

TD-1 through TD-10 (Technology Vendors and Data Providers)

II. Key Recommendations and Responses

PC-1 / PC-2 / PC-3 / PC-5 / PC-6 – AI-driven Navigation & Real-Time Trial Matching

Massive Bio’s Patient Connect app helps Medicare beneficiaries understand their condition, organize medical records, and match in real time to clinical trials based on genomic, imaging, and EHR data. This hybrid “click-and-mortar” system combines digital screening with concierge support, enabling participation from rural or underserved areas. Patients have reported easier decision-making and faster access to therapies. We recommend CMS promote such tools by creating a "CMS Trusted App" designation and integrating trial awareness into the Annual Wellness Visit.

PC-4 / PC-8 / PC-9 / PC-10 / PC-12 – Integrated Data, TEFCA, and Real-Time Use Cases

Structured access to full EHR data, especially pathology reports and genomics, remains elusive. By leveraging TEFCA and FHIR-based interoperability, Massive Bio aggregates records from multisite networks and identifies high-probability matches for trials. We support extending Blue Button 2.0 to include MA encounter data, genomics, social determinants, and lab results, and enabling patient-mediated FHIR access to HIEs.

PR-1 / PR-2 / PR-4 – Reducing Provider Burden with Smart Integration

Providers in our network benefit from AI tools that auto-extract eligibility from EHRs and reduce manual chart review. CMS should further support digital product integration into physician workflows through CPT codes for digital navigation and via funding implementation grants (especially in rural ACOs). Interoperability policies should mandate APIs that support both structured and unstructured data.

TD-1 / TD-2 / TD-3 / TD-4 / TD-9 / TD-10 – Unlocking Innovation for Developers

Developers require clearer access pathways to CMS data and APIs beyond claims (e.g., imaging reports, genomic annotations, social care data). CMS could establish a Developer Sandbox with synthetic data and credentialed digital identity frameworks (e.g., Login.gov + SMART on FHIR) to facilitate application development. We encourage support for OpenID Connect, and expansion of the ONC Certification Program to prioritize real-time patient-use APIs.

VB-1 / VB-3 / VB-5 / VB-11 – Aligning Digital Tools with Value-Based Oncology

Massive Bio supports inclusion of digital oncology tools into ACO models and the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM). CMS could incentivize trial referrals, tele-consent, and AI-driven remote monitoring as measures of innovation and equity in care navigation. Pilot projects could link Medicare claims to real-time eligibility APIs to inform shared savings calculations.

III. Conclusion

We commend CMS and ONC for their leadership in advancing the patient-centric digital ecosystem. To unlock the full potential of health technology for Medicare beneficiaries, CMS should:

Prioritize use of certified AI-powered tools that enable decentralized clinical trial access.

Expand patient access to all EHR formats under TEFCA and Blue Button.

Invest in caregiver support features and multi-language accessibility.

Promote public-private partnerships that drive innovation, such as ACTR and trial-matching.

Massive Bio is eager to continue supporting these efforts. We are available for demonstration or pilot engagement opportunities with CMS and ONC.

Sincerely,Dr. Arturo Loaiza-Bonilla, MD, MSEd, FACPCo-Founder & Chief Medical Officer Massive Bio, Inc.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy (ASTP):

Please accept these comments in response to the Request for Information (RFI) on the Health Technology Ecosystem, file code CMS-0042-NC.

I am submitting this response as a private citizen, a health IT professional, and most importantly, as a son and primary caregiver who recently navigated the care of my elderly parents through hospitalization, skilled nursing, and hospice. My detailed comments are provided in the attached PDF document.

My response focuses on the real-world gaps between policy goals and the lived experience of patients and caregivers. Key recommendations include:

Mandating timely and complete data access for patients.
Improving the "front door" for health app innovation through a national API directory and reliable vendor sandboxes.
Establishing forward-thinking policies for patient-centric AI and a patient's fundamental right to capture their own health story.
Thank you for the opportunity to provide feedback on these critical issues.

Sincerely,
Jim Younkin

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
DATA VALIDITY, DATA VALIDATION, DATA INTEGRITY ARE MISSING FROM THE DISCUSSION COMPLETELY!
There appears to be an erroneous assumption that if a piece of medical data exists on any electronic platform relative to a human patient that it is correct and valid.  This is a completely false assumption.  
Medical and data errors find their way into patient records in a multitude of way.  Human error, miscommunication, misdiagnosis, missed diagnosis, medical errors, the wrong patient's data in the wrong patient's records, AI hallucination, transcription errors (human, software, AI), medical fraud, and identity theft. Feeding all data into any AI or software system without a robust data validation and data integrity process will lead to massive amounts of medical errors including misdiagnoses, missed diagnoses, incorrect medication and treatment recommendations, patient harm, wasted time and medical resources, increased medical costs, the need for more medical care to correct the medical errors, patient harms up to and including patient death.  It is foolish and embarrassing that this is not included in the CMS discussion and planning process.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Protecting Providers from Penalties for Documented Patient Refusals in Quality Measures

•  CMS should ensure quality measures include patient refusal exclusions to avoid penalizing providers unfairly.
•  Measures for breast cancer, colon cancer, A1C, and BP control often lack standardized refusal handling across programs (e.g., MIPS vs. Star Ratings).
•  Repeated outreach to patients who decline care creates inefficient care loops, staff burnout, and verbal escalation toward nurses and MAs.
•  Providers face pressure from health plans, CDOs, and HEDIS teams to repeatedly “nag” patients despite refusals without clinical benefit.
•  Technology vendors (TD) must support structured refusal documentation (e.g., SNOMED CT codes) to enable fair measure exclusions.
•  CMS should address health IT ecosystem misalignment — providers (PR) are penalized while patients (PC) can refuse and vendors (TD) may not support refusal capture.
•  Remote monitoring data (e.g., BP cuffs, CGMs) should be integrated and measured appropriately, with patient opt-outs excluded from penalties.
•  CMS must ensure that value-based care models (VB) reward actual provider effort, not just patient behavior.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
My name is Audrey Dennis and I became a member of TEACHERS FOR CHOICE after COVID19; when this group was formed to include educators from New York under the leadership of Michael Kane.  We oppose all medical mandates to access society because people are not a monolith; we think independently and individually

When it comes to health technology, I believe in privacy rights for all patients as well as the rights of parents to advocate for their children. 

1. There is absolutely no need to force digital ID requirements for any human being to access healthcare in globally.  Who comes up with these rules for everyone to group think.  There must be choices and options always.  If the powers that be wants to do this, then go ahead and let others be free will thinkers as God intended it to be.

2. No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America, ever. (Agree).

3. Under no circumstances should any wearable technology ever be mandated on any human for any healthcare purpose. Informed consent must always be the standard. (Agree).

4. Everyone should have "the right to be forgotten," meaning if Artificial Intelligence or other technological tools are being used to gather data on a patient, it should be up to the individual if that data is stored or deleted. (Totally in agreement with Mr. Kane).

Thanks for your attention and consideration in this very important matter.

Audrey Dennis
Member, TEACHERS FOR CHOICE

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I am participating in my employer's response to specific technical interoperability comments but also have personal comments for this RFI. For context, here is a summary of my background as to how I come to my recommendations: 
• 30 years healthcare experience across multiple settings
• 20 years health technology implementation and adoption
• 20 years privacy & security compliance 
• 15 years in federal and state legislative and regulatory advocacy pertaining to health IT, interoperability, privacy, security, quality payment programs, public health, and Medicaid
• 5 years facilitating innovation through standards development, accreditation programs, and strategic partnerships

My comments are these:

No matter what policy and implementations come forth from the results of this RFI, adoption cannot be fully realized unless CMS and ASTP engage intimately with the impacted stakeholders. In my many years of experience I have witnessed consistently that policy makers and technology developers have created frameworks, tools, mechanisms, and models that may work perfectly at a macro or technical functionality level but are not being used, or used fully, by those giving, receiving, or paying for care. There are so many gaps in implementation and adoption whereby the end users do not know a technology exists, has had it insufficiently implemented, or does not have the adequate resources (financial, technically adept workforce, time, etc) to execute implementation and subsequent optimizations. Given that, I would like to offer the two following recommendations:


1. "True" real world testing. In other words, getting to the actual workflow and experience in every size, type, and geography of organization or user/stakeholder. For example, not once in any of my personal encounters for care, payment, or diagnostics have I ever fully experienced interoperability, access, digitization in a manner that I know to be possible given the work that I do. Such as when my PCP finds my test results from another health system via our state HIE (good!) but then prints it out to have staff scan back into the system (bad!) because they either do not have, or do not know how, to import into their EHR in a discrete manner that will populate key fields that will satisfy quality measures and decision support. I would like to see HHS develop a program to assess these issues more closely. This could look like a 'tracer' or 'secret shopper' type of approach to see how this really works in practice. By contrast, if an organization or vendor knows HHS is asking to see this, they will show you everything that is working the best or in theory, not what the staff or consumers are experiencing on a daily basis. 
2. Institute a technical assistance pathway that is more than guidance or implementation documents. It needs to be hands-on support with organizations. I recommend this vs. lump sums of incentive money because the organization who needs the most help may not know that the best use of those funds may be best spent on a consultant or a specific type of technical staff member. Also, giving incentive payments may or may not be sustainable into the future. Usually the latter. Knowing this, sometimes organizations are reticent to use it to upgrade technical environments because they won't be able to keep up the improvement due to future funds. For instance, I worked with a state public health department on where they were hesitant to apply for modernization funding because it would come in a large sum and couldn't sustain their infrastructure far into the future and they didn't believe the funds would continue. Which turned out to be a legitimate fear as public health funding has decreased. Guidance on how to implement and sustain any technical improvements will be essential to true adoption. 

Please do not hesitate to reach out to me as a resource. I am passionate about being part of the solution to improve outcomes through integration of information to patients & caregivers, providers, & payers.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Summary of Recommendations from Circle Engage
1. Technology Vendors
Create a two‑tier “Certified Developer Access Track.”
Tier 1 opens a structured, developer‑ready HPMS plan‑benefit dataset; Tier 2 grants read‑only MARx/BEQ eligibility checks (dual status, LIS, SEP, current enrollment).

Stand‑up a CMS‑hosted Standardized Enrollment API. Certified platforms could submit, track, and correct applications directly—eliminating today’s costly, proprietary middleware and extending AOR transparency.

Adopt a plan‑developer co‑review model for content compliance. Plans and certified vendors jointly attest to benefit‐display accuracy; CMS spot‑audits instead of reviewing every screen.

Require open standards (FHIR, SMART on FHIR, OAuth/OIDC) across all new CMS APIs. This ensures one integration path rather than multiple proprietary feeds.

Public RFP disclosure with security pre‑screening (e.g., HITRUST/SOC 2). Publishing all tech‑related RFPs and allowing only pre‑qualified vendors to bid broadens competition while limiting noise.

2. Data Providers
Expand and enrich priority CMS APIs.
• BEQ API – add Medicaid level detail, SEP flags, human‑readable error codes; drop “plan‑sponsor only” restriction.
• Provider Directory API – require near‑real‑time updates, new‑patient status, wait times, languages, accessibility, network tier, C‑SNP/D‑SNP filters.
• Patient Access API – include encounter histories, prior auths, benefit accumulators; support caregiver delegation and multi‑payer consent.
• Payer‑to‑Payer API – mandate a single schema for enrollment history, pre‑auth carry‑over, and provide shared sandboxes.
• Prior Authorization API – support batch queries, real‑time responses, standardized service codes, and publish turnaround benchmarks.

Blue Button 2.0 enhancements. Add MA encounter data, current coverage elections, OOP accumulators, LIS status, care‑team NPIs, and social‑risk indicators.

Streamline beneficiary credentialing. Issue Medicare.gov access codes at enrollment, enable Login.gov / ID.me federation, and publish SDKs for user‑friendly onboarding.

3. Networks (Exchange & Directory Infrastructure)
National, FHIR‑based provider‑directory standard. CMS should define the schema, require quarterly plan attestations, expose an open registry, and allow provider self‑attestation to reduce plan burden.

Promote TEFCA alignment while eliminating redundant pathways. Encourage QHIN participation for broad coverage but unify overlapping standards to a small core set (FHIR, OIDC, CDS‑Hooks).

Mandatory publication of FHIR endpoints and digital‑identity requirements. A nationwide directory combining endpoint URLs with trusted identity credentials would simplify routing and security for payers, providers, and consumer apps.

Support bulk‑FHIR and group‑based queries. Shared network infrastructure should favor scalable, population‑level access over point‑to‑point feeds, reducing provider burden for quality reporting and care coordination.

Maintain sustainability with CMS governance. CMS can ensure critical mass by tying compliance deadlines, certification pathways, and audit requirements to network participation.

These actions, taken together, lower entry barriers for innovators, guarantee richer real‑time data for decision support, and create a transparent, standards‑driven ecosystem that ultimately benefits beneficiaries, caregivers, and the broader Medicare market.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Ref: CMS-0042-NC

As a multi-state virtual behavioral health provider serving primarily Medicaid beneficiaries, we welcome CMS's efforts to improve technology access and interoperability for Medicare. We strongly encourage CMS to extend these initiatives to Medicaid, where the need for modernization is even more urgent due to severe variation across states and managed care organizations (MCOs). 
--

STANDARDIZATION ACROSS STATES

Medicaid is administratively fragmented, with widely differing standards for credentialing, eligibility checks, and data access. CMS should: 

1. Establish a federal interoperability baseline for Medicaid programs.
2. Require uniform implementation of patient access APIs and provider data exchange standards across all Medicaid MCOs.
--

CREDENTIALING DELAYS

Credentialing with State Medicaid and MCOs continues to be one of the most significant obstacles for new provider groups:

1. Credentialing timelines routinely range from 3 to 12 months, with no standardization or transparency.
2. Duplicate submission requirements across MCOs within the same state add inefficiency.
3. Occasionally, the absence of retroactive billing during these long timelines leads to lost revenue and, more importantly, severe delays to care delivery.
4. Some MCOs do not accept tele-health only providers, restricting access to underserved regions.

Recommendations: 
1. CMS should require MCOs to comply with credentialing SLAs (e.g. 30-45 days).
2. Create a federal provider enrollment and credentialing platform for Medicaid to streamline onboarding.
3. Support national licensure portability efforts to enable virtual providers to serve patients across multiple state lines without duplicative barriers.
--

ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION

In several states, running automated eligibility checks for Medicaid beneficiaries is difficult or unsupported. This results in:

1. Significant time spent on manual eligibility verification, often using legacy web portals with limited API support.
2. Delays in care and administrative bottlenecks, especially for organizations serving thousands of patients per month. 
3. Increased risk of denied claims due to coverage changes that aren't surfaced until after a session. 

Recommendations:
1. CMS should standardize real-time eligibility API protocols across all Medicaid MCOs.
2. Require all Medicaid plans to offer programmatic access to eligibility verification, including retroactive coverage and benefit details. 
--

Although this RFI is focused on Medicare, we urge CMS to extend these modernization efforts across Medicaid as well. Doing so would enable equitable technology-driven care, reduce wasteful administrative burden, and unlock significant access improvements for millions of low-income patients. Providers are ready to scale evidence-based care, but we need aligned infrastructure and federal leadership to do so effectively. 

We welcome the opportunity to collaborate with the appropriate bodies to design, develop, and roll out these changes, if appropriate. 


cc: Dr. Nirav Shah

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I am a private practice Occupational Therapist with 20 years experience billing Medicare.  The billing process seems unnecessarily complicated and expensive for small providers such as OT, PT, ST, since I need to hire a biller, pay for a clearing house (a clearing house charges extra to bill Medicare).  I am now starting to use PC-ACE, for billing for free directly to Medicare which seems fantastic although it has not been easy to use.  (set up, directions, support could be greatly improved please!).  I hope this direct billing to Medicare improves for small providers so many more small providers will not hesitate to provide services, increasing the number of providers to Medicare beneficiaries.  Speaking of support.  over the years I have found Noridian Medicare support staff out of North Dakota(?) to be extremely helpful and considerate (not time consuming, just efficient and respectful and knowledgeable).  Keep that up!  We need similar support for the PC-ACE process.  Please improve the PC-ACE program for billing Medicare!  

There are comments about using tech to track Medication.  But true health is about so much more.  We need a way to track the stories of people's experience so that providers can empathize, hear how health changes with treatments and services.  Tech can do so much more than monitoring the simple things to  monitor like meds,and blood pressure.  Occupational Therapy and the rehab professionals are about how well people LIVE, what they do, the quality of their life.  Cognition, Mobility, Being Pain Free, Engagement, Confidence, Satisfaction, Lack of Fear, Adaptability:  please add these factors into your tech processes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This comment is submitted in response to the Request for Information (RFI) regarding the national healthcare technology and interoperability landscape. As practitioners in the health information technology sector, we have direct experience with the persistent challenges that inhibit the seamless and secure exchange of health data. Our perspective is informed by firsthand observation of the successes and, more significantly, the failures of federal interoperability policies to date.

The United States healthcare system has reached the absolute limit of what a compliance-driven, market-led approach to interoperability can achieve. The persistent failures of the past decade the superficial adoption of standards, the entrenchment of data-hoarding business models, the stagnation of innovation, and the constrained potential of AI are not incidental bugs in the system. They are predictable features of a market that structurally rewards the creation of data silos. Continuing down this path with more incremental rules and voluntary frameworks will only yield more of the same frustrating results.

A fundamental strategic pivot is required. We urge CMS and ONC to consider the following analysis and recommendations, which propose a shift from reactive regulation to the proactive construction of a national health data infrastructure.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
See Attachment for full response

Response to RFI: Health Technology Ecosystem
CMS-0042-NC
Submitted by: Human Services Research Institute (HSRI)


Organization Background: Human Services Research Institute (HSRI) is a nonprofit organization with over 40 years of experience in person-centered care across the lifespan. We develop healthcare transparency websites, manage state all-payer claims databases, and conduct research to improve health outcomes for vulnerable populations. Our work includes extensive expertise in behavioral health systems, intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) services, and integrated care models for individuals who are dually eligible for Medicare and Medicaid. We have supported states, federal agencies, and healthcare organizations in developing data systems, quality measurement frameworks, and care coordination models that bridge medical, behavioral, and social services.
________________________________________
Executive Summary
While we appreciate CMS and ASTP/ONC's efforts to advance digital health technology for Medicare beneficiaries, we respectfully submit that the current RFI framework represents a significant missed opportunity. By focusing primarily on Medicare beneficiaries, this initiative overlooks the fundamental principle that health is a lifelong journey requiring seamless care coordination across all ages, payers, and care settings.

Our core recommendation: Expand the scope of health technology interoperability initiatives to encompass true lifespan interoperability that serves all individuals regardless of age, insurance status, or care setting. This approach will ultimately better serve Medicare beneficiaries by ensuring they enter the Medicare system with comprehensive, accessible health histories and can transition seamlessly between different care environments throughout their lives.

Conclusion: The future of health technology lies not in payer-specific solutions but in comprehensive, person-centered approaches that follow individuals throughout their lives. By expanding the current Medicare-focused framework to embrace lifespan interoperability, CMS and ASTP/ONC can create truly transformative digital health solutions that improve outcomes, reduce costs, and enhance the healthcare experience for all Americans. What's needed is the policy leadership to require open standards, cross-system integration, and genuine commitment to serving the public good.

HSRI stands ready to contribute our expertise in person-centered care, health data transparency, and state health information systems to support this expanded vision. We urge CMS and ASTP/ONC to consider how broadening the scope of this initiative will ultimately better serve Medicare beneficiaries by creating a more integrated, comprehensive, and equitable health technology ecosystem.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Federal and state legislation makes it easier for consumers to access more health information than ever, but barriers still exist for consumers seeking to take full advantage. In particular, the digital divide, now recognized as a super social determinant of health, risks exacerbating health disparities for certain populations. To bridge the digital divide for system-wide impact in health care, it is critical to address the digital divide in consumers’ capacity to adopt and use patient portals in their ongoing care management.  

Certain populations, such as aging individuals, commonly encounter barriers as a result of limited digital skills and physical accessibility issues. Psychosocial factors can also be barriers to learning such as “tech anxiety,” or fear of “breaking” something using technology, or “tech hesitancy” due to the uncertainty about the value and benefit of digital interventions in their lives. Unfamiliarity with portal features (like secure messaging and appointment scheduling) can reduce adoption rates further.

The digital divide in health care underscores the importance of delivering interventions that provide digital health navigation and critical digital literacy training and supports at the community level. To promote digital inclusion and improve health outcomes, user-friendly, specialized and individualized training approaches with patient instructors can enable healthcare consumers to acquire the critical skills needed to log-on, schedule appointments, message providers, view test results, and refill prescriptions, potentially leading to fewer missed visits, better treatment adherence, and reduced health disparities.

San Francisco Tech Council (SFTC) believes tackling the digital divide requires broad-based, intentional collaboration, as well as integration of digital inclusion programming into community support systems. In 2023-24 SFTC led a collaborative development effort between community-based organizations, medical providers, and digital health practitioners of a web-based, interactive patient portal training platform that provides a simulated practice environment for consumers to acquire the digital skills they will need, practice key patient portal functions and build confidence in a safe environment and without compromising personal health data. Training is delivered in community settings (eg, community centers, libraries, affordable housing) by digital navigators.

SFTC piloted the intervention in 2024. Barriers to patient portal use among two-thirds of participants who identified as non-users of patient portals were: (i) not sure how to use it and (ii) never heard of it. The pilot identified several variables as key determinants of optimal patient portal adoption and usage: (i) comfort or level of competency with technology skills and (ii) whether participants had someone available to help with technology. Post-pilot surveys reported the training was effective in increasing patient portal use, both in terms of encouraging more people to use it and promoting more frequent use among existing users.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
I. Introduction

Zlenox welcomes CMS’s RFI CMS-0042-NC on interoperability. As creators of the Zlenox Healthcare Enterprise Resource Planner “ZHERP”—a cloud-native EHR/HRM/CRM for post-acute care—we offer policy perspectives to foster an open, collaborative ecosystem for both established vendors and emerging innovators.

Increasing competition in an EHR market dominated by a single company with over 75 percent market share is essential to ensuring that skilled-nursing facilities (SNFs) boost productivity through technological adoption. When one company controls the de facto system of record for SNFs, third-party innovators cannot introduce new solutions without full interoperability, covering both administrative and clinical data.

II. The Imperative for Competition

• Medicare Scale & Value: In FY 2022, Medicare Part A payments to SNFs reached $27.2 billion across 15,000+ facilities. Ensuring those funds drive value, rather than entrenching static systems, is vital for cost-effective, high-quality care.

• Network-Effect Barriers: Developers target large user bases; facilities hesitate to switch without a mature app ecosystem. This cycle can stall innovations like decision-support modules, staffing alerts, or readmission analytics unless structural measures lower barriers.

• Data-Portability Friction: USCDI ensures a baseline export, but full record migration still relies on custom, vendor-specific extracts that must be transformed and manually reconciled. Combined with staff retraining and change management, this friction deters facilities from adopting new systems.

III. HALO-Inspired Collaborative Framework

Canada Health Infoway’s HALO illustrates how to build inclusive interoperability:

• Central App Catalog: A vendor-neutral SMART on FHIR repository with streamlined certification.

• App Accelerator: Shared infrastructure enabling platforms—regardless of FHIR support—to host SMART apps seamlessly.

• In-UI Embedding: Deep-link and UI-extension specs that integrate third-party apps natively within the EMR interface.

• Layered Profiles & Security: US Core and SMART OAuth2 provide a baseline; adding post-acute extensions and enforcing full SMART conformance eliminates bespoke mapping. IV. Policy Recommendations

1. National App Repository Mandate: Require all certified EMRs to support a centralized, ONC-endorsed SMART on FHIR catalog with clear security and performance criteria, governed by a multi-stakeholder council.

2. Enhanced Data-Portability Standards: Expand Cures Act requirements to mandate full-scope exports (standard and custom elements, configuration data, audit logs) within defined timelines (e.g., 30 days) and quality thresholds (e.g., ≥ 99 percent completeness), backed by reference tooling.

3. SMART UI Embedding Extension: Adopt a “UI-Host” profile in SMART on FHIR for deep-link parameters and launch contexts; require EMRs to expose this endpoint natively or via a shared accelerator.

4. Non-Discrimination & Fair Access: Prohibit unreasonable fees, arbitrary delisting, or throttling of certified SMART apps; allow transparent, security-focused controls rather than closed-door approvals. 

5. Collaborative Pilot Programs: Fund joint demonstrations pairing incumbents and startups in SNFs to co-develop integrated solutions and evaluate outcomes—readmission rates, clinician efficiency, migration costs, and patient satisfaction.

V. Conclusion

By combining a HALO-inspired app ecosystem, strengthened data-portability mandates, and structured collaboration, CMS can create a balanced, competitive post-acute care marketplaceenabling vendors of all sizes, including Zlenox, to deliver better tools, lower costs, and improved patient outcomes. We look forward to partnering with CMS, providers, and peers to realize this vision.

HALO explainer video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=16VEjl3PJqc&ab_channel=CanadaHealthInfoway

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Extract from part 2 of my comments with ID: CMS-2025-0050-0254

Intellectual Property Issues with Assessment Scales 

One of the biggest issues with the data exchange of assessment scales is the intellectual property, meaning that every standards organization would need to get IP approval to share the questions and answers of an assessment scale.



SNOMED International wrote a document related to this entitled “Principles for managing Assessment Scales in SNOMED CT.”
As one can imagine, if an EHR vendor or healthcare application vendor obtains IP approval from every organization to do an assessment scale, that could be very expensive. 

One recommendation is that CMS could:
•	Negotiate blanket licenses for common tools (e.g., MoCA, Barthel Index, Neuropsychiatric Inventory, Lawton IADL, COPD Assessment Test, Asthma Control Test, Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, Gilliam Autism Rating Scale, Autism Spectrum Quotient) across providers.
•	Require IP holders to publish digital, interoperable versions as a condition of endorsement.
•	Fund development of open-access alternatives to reduce dependency on restricted tools if licensing is prohibitive.
•	Include FHIR-compatible versions of assessment tools in standard rulemaking (e.g., QPP, MVPs).
•	Explore multi-stakeholder partnerships (tool owners, standards bodies, federal agencies) to create a licensed digital content clearinghouse.
•	Issue grants or contracts to buy rights for common tools, common assessment scales and facilitate inclusion in SNOMED CT and LOINC.
•	Promote use of these licensed digital assets in regulations, programs, and certification criteria.


Some of these assessment scales and questionnaires are prevalent in the common chronic illnesses such as assessment scales for:
•	Dementia
o	Mini Mental State Exam
o	Montreal Cognitive Assessment
o	Neuropsychiatric Inventory 
o	Functional Activities Questionnaire
•	Alzheimer’s
•	Asthma
o	Asthma Control Test
o	Asthma Control Questionnaire 
o	Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire 
•	Autism
o	Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule
o	Gilliam Autism Rating Scale 
o	Autism Diagnostic Interview- Revised


Link below:
https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/download/attachments/236027963/Principles%20for%20managing%20Assessment%20Scales%20in%20SNOMED%20CT%2020240430%20v0.1.docx.pdf?version=1&modificationDate=1716224860000&api=v2

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Newfire Global Partners appreciates the opportunity to respond to this Request for Information (RFI) regarding the Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0042-NC). As a firm providing product advisory and software development to healthcare organizations, including providers, payors, tech-enabled services, and independent software vendors (ISVs), we bring perspective from building, implementing, and maintaining software used by our customers who serve millions of patients - many of whom are Medicare and Medicaid beneficiaries. Our comments focus on expanding interoperability, improving standards adoption, and enabling scalable data exchange for modern healthcare use cases.


Trusted Exchange Framework and Common Agreement (TEFCA) (PC-10, PR-6):
Newfire supports the continued adoption and advancement of TEFCA. We recommend that future regulations mandate the expansion of TEFCA (and require query responses by network participants) to use cases beyond treatment to enhance the usefulness of Qualified Health Information Networks (QHINs) for additional types of healthcare organizations, such as ISVs, with the consent of patients. This would require the implementation of advanced consent and identity management frameworks to make it easier for patients to consent to sharing their data with various parties and then easily manage that access, including restricting and revoking access at a later date. By empowering patients to manage consent dynamically, CMS and ASTP/ONC can promote trusted data sharing while preserving privacy and mitigating risks associated with indiscriminate data access.


Bulk FHIR (PR-5, PR-7, TD-9, TD-15):
Bulk FHIR has the potential to enable large-scale data liquidity between EHRs and other enterprise applications and third parties such as clinical research organizations (CROs). However, the current requirements for adoption of Bulk FHIR by EHR vendors do not go far enough to make it a reasonable option for many use cases, such as cohort analysis and population health outreach. Without regulatory incentives or requirements, EHR vendors lack strong market pressure to improve Bulk FHIR functionality.

Some of the current limitations include:
-EHR-imposed restrictions on the size of FHIR groups: Most EHR vendors explicitly or implicitly limit the number of patients for which a Bulk FHIR extract can be run; this limit may be as low as 100 patients. This inhibits the potential usefulness of Bulk FHIR beyond other data access options (e.g. individually calling many FHIR API endpoints for a given patient). 
-Lack of ability to create FHIR groups without EHR administrator involvement: For many use cases, the roster of patients that are in scope for a given run of Bulk FHIR may change frequently. Many EHR vendors currently require manual intervention from their support staff to create new groups, which slows down the process and may result in additional support costs for ISVs and healthcare organizations.
-Poor public documentation: Comprehensive, self-service documentation for developers would reduce implementation burden for all parties involved. 


Technical Standards and Certification (TD-7, TD-9(d)):
USCDI has significantly improved interoperability by requiring all certified EHRs to support a common dataset for API-based retrieval. The primary limitation that we see among our customers is the limited scope of EHR-supported USCDI data elements, which results in most interoperability use cases requiring the combination of USCDI FHIR endpoints with other integration methods such as HL7v2 and proprietary EHR APIs. USCDI could be further improved upon by continuing to expand the dataset over subsequent versions and incorporating these versions into future regulations that influence the adoption of FHIR APIs by EHR vendors and other parties, including for event-driven data flows.

Requiring the development and implementation of FHIR Subscription functionality among EHR vendors would be a large step toward fully migrating commonly-used interoperability mechanisms to modern infrastructure and reducing the implementation and maintenance burden of interoperability for a variety of affected parties including provider organizations and ISVs. FHIR Subscriptions would allow applications to receive automatic updates when patient data changes in a given system, reducing polling overhead and supporting timely care interventions.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
RE: Public Comment on CMS-0042-NC: Request for Information–Health Technology Ecosystem 

Dear Administrator Oz and CMS RFI Review Team,

Delfina Care Inc. (Delfina) welcomes the opportunity to respond to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Request for Information regarding the Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0041-NC). We are encouraged by your leadership in shaping a digital infrastructure that enables more effective and interoperable healthcare.
Executive Summary
Delfina’s mission is to transform pregnancy care by providing access to individualized insights and integrated systems that improve health outcomes. Delfina partners with managed Medicaid plans, provider organizations, and community-based healthcare practices to deliver our AI-powered maternal health technology platform. Our tech-enabled, closed-loop system of care helps healthcare providers identify patients who would benefit from early intervention, and then deploy evidence-based interventions and non-clinical support to the patient between clinical visits to help mitigate the risk for complications such as preeclampsia and preterm birth; leading drivers of maternal mortality and neonatal ICU (NICU) admissions. 
We fully support CMS's goals to promote interoperable, patient-centered technologies and urge CMS to explicitly prioritize maternal health use cases across its digital health modernization strategy. In the following comments, we offer recommendations based on our experience developing and deploying scalable digital tools that integrate into clinical workflows and support real-world impact in Medicaid and value-based care. 

Delfina Responses 
While not directly responding to any specific RFI question, we want to acknowledge that without a national reimbursement framework, any progress made in embracing the use of technology to serve patients remains incomplete. A unified billing policy (e.g., a dedicated CPT code for AI-enabled maternal health platforms) is crucial for fully realizing the potential of technology and supporting meaningful engagement from both providers and developers. Please find attached our responses to specific questions posed.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the CMS Health Technology Ecosystem RFI. Sharecare is a digital health company with proven public-private partnerships delivering results across Medicare, Medicaid, ACA, and employer programs. We’re excited to help CMS accelerate modernization and bring connected care to more Americans.

Intelligent navigation built for real-world use.
AskMD, our AI-driven health navigation platform, integrates real-time eligibility, provider matching, EHR connectivity, and value-based care alignment. Unlike point solutions or pilots, AskMD is live and deployed at scale through Sharecare’s enterprise infrastructure, reaching diverse populations across Medicaid, Medicare Advantage, ACA exchanges, and commercial networks.

Scalable, interoperable, and grounded in real-world relationships
Sharecare’s reach across U.S. markets enables scalable solutions that improve access, engagement, and outcomes. AskMD reflects this investment and is built on longstanding partnerships with health plans, government agencies, health systems, employers, and leading technology and cloud services and is shaped by millions of real-world interactions across Medicaid, Medicare, and commercial populations.

Live demonstration: Georgia
Georgia offers a real-time model for CMS to observe scalable public-private collaboration in action, serving diverse populations and funding models across the state, where Sharecare supports:
•	SHBP: One of the nation’s largest public employee groups
•	Georgia Access: Supporting QHP enrollment on the state exchange
•	Medicaid: Digital front door for the largest MCO in the state
•	Commercial and VBC networks: Concierge experience that integrates benefits, care access, and rewards

Together, these deployments provide a testbed aligned with CMS’s vision for an integrated digital ecosystem, creating opportunities to validate provider directories, support real-time eligibility navigation, and personalize benefit delivery across coverage types.

 
Embedded research to evaluate impact
A new partnership with the University of Georgia is evaluating AskMD’s impact on access, enrollment, and satisfaction for 1.5M exchange members. This academic study will measure cost, experience, and plan fit between members using AskMD and those navigating legacy systems.

Proven reach and results
Sharecare supports 9.6M eligible lives, including:
•	2.25M Medicare Advantage members
•	900K+ Medicaid members, many in rural areas
•	450K+ federal employees (FEP)
•	750K+ individuals via government contracts
•	10K+ provider sites through ROI services

Secure, scalable, and ready to grow
AskMD is built on Sharecare’s CMS-certified infrastructure, including HIH and QCDR status. Our SaaS platform supports rapid deployment, cross-system interoperability, and configurable branding for Medicaid, exchange, and employer markets. It enables identity verification, real-time data exchange, and benefit navigation tailored to user needs.

Aligned with value-based care goals:
AskMD supports value-based care contracts by value-based care contracts by embedding risk stratification, real-time data inputs, and behavioral nudges that align with performance metrics. APIs and backend integrations support care team workflows, while reporting capabilities track progress against quality and cost-of-care goals.

A platform ready for CMS partnership
Our solution aligns directly with CMS’s modernization priorities: augmenting national provider directories, enabling identity verification, supporting Blue Button 2.0 integration, and strengthening value-based care enablement. This is not a concept or pilot in development. It is a live platform delivering measurable results.

The success of Sharecare and our AskMD solution provide a strong example of how scalable, public-private infrastructure can be deployed nationally. We welcome the opportunity to work with CMS to evaluate, expand, and scale what’s already working.

As part of our submission, we’ve also included letters of endorsement from key leaders across the state of Georgia, reflecting the state’s unified support for this effort. These endorsements underscore Georgia’s readiness to serve as a demonstration site and highlight the strength of the public-private partnerships already in place.

We appreciate CMS’s thoughtful approach and would welcome the opportunity to expand, evaluate, and demonstrate how AskMD can further national goals. Included with our submission are letters of endorsement from Georgia leaders, highlighting the state’s readiness to support demonstration efforts.

We look forward to continued collaboration. Thank you,

Jeff Arnold
Sharecare, Founder & Executive Chairman

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Electronic Caregiver, Inc. is pleased to submit this comment in response to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Request for Information (CMS-0042-NC) regarding the digital health ecosystem for Medicare beneficiaries. We commend CMS and Dr. Mehmet Oz for articulating a transformative vision for an AI-powered, consumer-centric healthcare model. Our flagship platform, Addison Care, represents a ready-made solution to the RFI's outlined priorities.

Section A: Patients and Caregivers – Aligned Use Cases
Addison Care is an AI-powered 3D virtual caregiver that engages patients with real-time health management, daily reminders, vitals monitoring, and avatar-driven education. The platform is tailored for accessibility, supporting seniors, low-tech users, and diverse populations with voice-first interaction and culturally adaptive content.

Aligned Questions: PC-1 through PC-7
- Addison provides personalized engagement and symptom tracking.
- Enables single-point access to health information and integrates with FHIR APIs.
- Tracks daily health inputs and alerts care teams of anomalies, supporting chronic condition management.
- Demonstrates readiness to support CMS data collection and efficacy assessment.

Section B: Provider Support & Value-Based Care Integration
Addison Care enhances clinical workflows through pre-visit data collection, post-visit engagement, and AI-driven decision support. It reduces provider administrative burden and aligns tightly with VBC goals.

Aligned Questions: PR-1 through PR-8, VB-1 through VB-13
- Prepares actionable summaries for clinicians based on structured patient data.
- Automates care navigation, adherence coaching, and personalized education.
- Supports modular integration into CEHRT and contributes to shared savings initiatives.
- Tracks outcome KPIs and patient satisfaction, supporting CMS VBC reporting.

Section C: Interoperability and Ecosystem Participation
Addison Care is built on a scalable, enterprise-level platform with RESTful APIs, HL7/FHIR compatibility, HIPAA compliance, and integration capabilities with EHRs and RPM devices.

Aligned Questions: TD-1 through TD-17
- Supports Bulk FHIR, Blue Button 2.0, and Smart on FHIR.
- Designed to promote seamless, standards-based data flow and real-time access.
- Addison’s data engine supports federated data access and CMS validation efforts.

Conclusion and Request
Electronic Caregiver, Inc. (ECG) encourages CMS to consider Addison Care as a pilot-ready platform for real-world validation within Medicare and Medicaid populations. ECG's cloud-based platform-as-a-service (PaaS) software solution has been built on and validated by Amazon Web Services (AWS) as the most private, secure, and scalable solution to enable AI-driven care. Designed as an open solution, services and solutions connect to ECG's PaaS via APIs and webhooks to enable horizonal and vertical extensions of the solutions. Service extensions address issues such as social determinants of health (SDOH), social isolation and loneliness, ride share, medication management, 24/7 physician-on-demand, and falls risk identification, management, and response. Currently, ECG manages over 70,000 connected devices daily while leveraging algorithms and AI to receive, process, interpret, and deliver care insights to clinicals from over 500 million data invocations annually. ECG's robust platform is built to support over 100 million users. ECG's platform is directly integrated into the athenahealth athenaOne EHR and integrated through leading care management platforms into EPIC, Cerner, and other leading EHRs. 

ECG's leadership in the area of AI+Aging solutions is recognized via the National Institutes of Health (NIH) awarding ECG and UMass-Amherst a grant to accelerate productization of an innovative product for falls risk identification and prevention, at home. Leveraging computer vision, an AI-driven virtual avatar, AI, and algorithms - Addison Care delivers functional assessments, gait analysis, the Johns Hopkins Falls Risk Assessment to older adults at home, at any time, to proactively address increase risk of falls. This is but one example of how an AI-driven solution can provide on-edge intelligence and insights to complement clinicals to enhance decision making. 

We support a future where AI-led, consumer-centered tools are certified, reimbursed, and fully integrated into the national health technology ecosystem. We welcome further discussion and look forward to CMS’s continued leadership in shaping a more connected, patient-friendly system.
