Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
C. Providers
PR-1. What can CMS and its partners do to encourage providers, including those in rural areas, to leverage approved (see description in PC-5) digital health products for their patients?
As an FQHC-led Accountable Care and Management Services Organization supporting Medicare beneficiaries in 8 states and the District of Columbia, we see strong potential for digital tools—like appointment scheduling, medication tracking, and provider messaging—to improve care coordination, reduce burden, and empower patients.
Barriers to adoption include:
•	Limited digital literacy and lack of access to devices or broadband
•	Low interoperability across tools and EHR systems
•	A mismatch between tool functionality and patient/provider needs
We recommend CMS:
•	Provide financial incentives for FQHC-developer partnerships, ensuring that new digital tools address the real needs of underserved populations.
•	Tie incentives to interoperability with major EHR platforms (e.g., MyChart) to improve care management and reduce redundancy.
•	Fund broadband and device access programs for patients to bridge the digital divide, especially in rural communities where internet access is not readily available.
•	Establish certification pathways for digital tools optimized for safety-net providers, including multilingual and low-bandwidth features.
•	Support shared infrastructure (e.g., regional digital platforms or consortia) to make adoption more feasible for small FQHCs.

F. Value-Based Care Organizations
VB-1. What incentives could encourage APMs such as accountable care organizations (ACOs) or participants in Medicare Shared Savings Program (MSSP) to leverage digital health management and care navigation products more often and more effectively with their patients? What are the current obstacles preventing broader digital product adoption for patients in ACOs?
Digital health management platforms—especially those using predictive analytics and AI—can identify care gaps, risk factors, and opportunities for timely intervention. AI scribes can streamline documentation, support accurate coding, and reduce administrative burden. These tools are highly promising, particularly in resource-constrained settings like FQHCs. However, barriers include: 
•	High costs of evaluation, implementation, and maintenance
•	Limited EHR integration
•	Lack of guidance on scalable, high-impact solutions for underserved populations
We recommend CMS:
•	Create financial incentives tied to successful tool integration into care management workflows
•	Prioritize tools with demonstrated ROI for underserved communities
•	Fund shared digital infrastructure that can be leveraged across FQHCs
•	Incentivize adoption of AI-assisted documentation to improve risk adjustment and reduce provider burnout

VB-9. What technology requirements should be different for APM organizations when comparing to non-APM organizations (for example, quality reporting, and interoperability)?
To reduce administrative burden and enhance data utility for APM participants, especially FQHCs, we recommend:
1.	Align CMS and HHS data standards and reporting systems to eliminate duplicative reporting and streamline quality measurement.
2.	Allow UDS data submission in lieu of separate MSSP and ACO REACH reporting. Since FQHCs already report through HRSA’s Uniform Data System, using this for CMS reporting would reduce burden and encourage broader participation in value-based care models.
This alignment would improve data integrity, reduce costs, and help ACOs focus resources on improving care—not navigating redundant reporting processes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Combs-Dyer Consulting, LLC—founded by former CMS official and registered nurse Melanie Combs-Dyer—submits this response to file code CMS-0042-NC, offering targeted recommendations to strengthen the health technology ecosystem and protect the Medicare Trust Fund from improper payments. Drawing on over 30 years of experience in the Medicare Fee-for-Service (FFS) program, Combs-Dyer Consulting proposes modernizing data exchange infrastructure, expanding FHIR-based transactions, and refocusing policy levers to reduce fraud, waste, and abuse while also lowering provider burden.
Key Recommendations:
     •	Modernize Medicare Documentation Submission
Replace outdated esMD systems with a FHIR submission of Medical Documentation (fsMD) ecosystem. CMS should establish a new Health Information Handler (HIH) program for fsMD to enable scalable, cost-effective adoption.
     •	Enforce Broader API Adoption
CMS and ONC/ASTP should require EHR vendors to support CRD, DTR, PAS, CDex, and CDSO APIs without special effort through updates to the CEHRT program. These APIs remain underused due to lack of EHR integration mandates.
     •	Reform Promoting Interoperability Program
Refocus the program away from quality measure reporting and toward adoption and use of FHIR-based tools that prevent improper payments, such as Clinical Documentation Supporting Orders (CDSO) and prior authorization APIs.
     •	Develop CDSO Standards and Infrastructure
Fund and finalize an HL7 Clinical Documentation Supporting an Order (CDSO) Implementation Guide. Require CDSO capabilities in EHRs and integrate CDSO exchange into DMEPOS competitive bidding processes and Medicare claims review workflows.
     •	Support Nationwide FHIR Directories and fsMD Training
Launch a national directory of FHIR endpoints for instant medical documentation access. Establish fsMD vendor workshops to scale a network of certified, standards-compliant vendors.
     •	Revitalize TEFCA Participation
CMS should rejoin eHealth Exchange and pilot the use of TEFCA/QHINs to accelerate scalable medical record exchange for integrity reviews.
     •	Leverage Pilot Programs and Extrapolated Review Incentives
Run multi-stakeholder pilot tests of CRD/DTR/CDex/CDSO transactions, and use extrapolated audits as incentives for ordering clinicians who fail to adopt API-based documentation exchange.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Force Therapeutics appreciates the opportunity to provide comments, attached, in response to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services' (CMS) Request for Information regarding the digital health technology ecosystem for Medicare beneficiaries (Docket ID CMS-2025-0050).

Force Therapeutics is a provider-prescribed episode-of-care management platform that supports over 130 hospitals and health systems nationwide. Founded in 2010, our platform delivers clinically validated education and personalized care plans to patients preparing for and recovering from surgery. We have managed over 200,000 Medicare patients, including 80,000 Total Knee Arthroplasty and 50,000 Total Hip Arthroplasty surgical episodes on the Force platform. Force's virtual care platform is purpose-built to meet the needs of modern surgical care, empowering providers with automated workflows, standardized digital pathways, and actionable insights to improve patient engagement, satisfaction, and outcomes. Our team is dedicated to the value-based care movement and the delivery of high-quality healthcare for all Americans, and we are closely aligned with the CMS mission to advance value-based, patient-centered care as means of improving care quality and reducing the national burden of healthcare expenditure.

We are encouraged by CMS' ongoing strategic initiatives and outreach to the digital health community. We believe that digital care must play a critical role in enhancing the healthcare ecosystem for all patients, and we welcome continued collaboration with CMS to achieve this goal.

Thank you considering our comments. We look forward to continued engagement and would be happy to discuss our insights further. Please feel free to contact us for further discussion.

Sincerely,
Bronwyn Spira (bronwyn@forcetherapeutics.com)
CEO and Founder
Force Therapeutics

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
RE: Response to CMS Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS–6082–NC)

As a developer of digital diagnostic solutions, BioBeat Technologies is pleased to submit this response focused on the intersection of reimbursement policy, digital health access, and clinical workflow modernization.
Hypertension is one of the most prevalent and costly medical conditions in the US, with nearly half of all U.S. adults diagnosed with hypertension and annual costs estimated around $220 billion annually in 2019, per the CDC.  Three-quarters of people with hypertension do not have their blood pressure under control, leading to almost 700,000 deaths in 2022 in which hypertension was the primary or contributing cause of death.  Effective and highly cost-efficient options to diagnose and manage BP are available, including ABPM, but adoption is very low.  For instance, self-monitoring of blood pressure is estimated to save $7.50 to $20 for every $1 invested over 10 years, yet far fewer than 0.01% of people with hypertension use ABPM technology despite national coverage.  Streamlining access to ABPM services – and ensuring coverage of more convenient and manageable ABPM technology – can dramatically improve long-term Medicare costs and health outcomes
About BioBeat and Our Technology
BioBeat USA Inc. offers a modern cuff-less, wearable FDA-cleared device that accurately provides ambulatory BP monitoring based on photoplethysmography (PPG) and other validated methodologies that can reliably monitor blood pressure over 24-hour cycles without the discomfort, complexity, and operational barriers posed by traditional cuff-based systems.  
As we explained when we were honored to present at Mar-a-Lago during US-ISRAEL AI FORUM on May 7, 2025, BioBeat’s wearable sensor is a chest-applied, fully cuffless device that captures blood pressure every 15 minutes over 24 hours. The device passively transmits the data via a mobile app to a secure cloud, where it is processed into a comprehensive clinical report viewable by the provider through our web portal. BioBeat’s system requires no ongoing patient interaction, making it especially well-suited for older adults and patients with limited digital literacy.

See our detailed response in the attached file.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: Battelle Memorial Institute (Battelle) welcomes the opportunity to provide input to CMS and ASTP/ONC on strategies to advance interoperability and health data infrastructure in support of value-based care (CMS-0042-NC). As the current CMS-contracted Consensus-based Entity (CBE) we write from the perspective of stakeholders implementing clinical quality measures (CQM) both for payment models focused on accountability and for payment models focused on care transformation, structural investment, and evidence generation. In these latter models, providers and communities are empowered to generate value through transformation infrastructure, including tools like SCAMPs (Standardized Clinical Assessment and Management Plans), FHIR standards for positive deviation reporting, and registries that support learning from local variation. Summary recommendations and responses to individual questions are included in the attachment.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As for "provider directories", the most common queries of the public are:

* Is this health care organization/location part of my plan?
* Is this individual provider part of my plan?
* Is this medication covered by my insurance plan?

In my opinion, using FHIR for provider directories is not the best choice for this type of information. FHIR is for health information, but this data is identity/affiliation data. A simpler fit-for-purpose JSON document, per plan, would be easier to use.  Furthermore, there is no national index/list of these provider directories required by insurance plans and Medicaid plans. CMS/HHS/ASTP need to find a way to aggregate all of this information into one place so it is easy to answer the above common queries. An easy to use nationwide website for search and answering these question would also be helpful.  

It is also important to consider that "providers" are not the only actors in the health care ecosystem.  The US Health care system/HHS needs a directory registry that encompass other entity and object types (that do not have NPIs) including plans, APIs and other entity identifiers (OEIDs).

Comment: Patients and their families should be easily able to gauge where they are with respect to standards of care.  Have they received what's recommended? Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
June 16, 2025

The Honorable Dr. Mehmet Oz
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health and Human Services
7500 Security Blvd.
Baltimore, MD 21244

Submitted via the Federal Regulations Web Portal, http://www.regulations.gov

RE: Request for Information; Health Technology Ecosystem

We commend the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP/ONC) for addressing the state of data interoperability and broader health technology infrastructure. The release of this Request for Information (RFI) underscores CMS’s commitment to fostering collaboration with stakeholders to enhance healthcare delivery and outcomes.

Persistent disparities in health outcomes, particularly among historically underserved communities, are exacerbated by outdated and incomplete data collection practices1. The adoption of comprehensive and standardized data collection categories is crucial for enhancing data access, utilization, and community-driven interventions.

To improve interoperability and support equitable health outcomes, we urge the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its agencies, including CMS, to adopt and promote the 2024 revised Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Statistical Policy Directive No. 15 (SPD 15) standards for the collection and use of race and 
ethnicity data. Standardizing these elements across federal programs, health IT systems, and value-based care models is foundational to identifying disparities, mitigating bias in emerging technologies, and advancing health equity2. This aligns with the RFI’s emphasis on strengthening interoperability and ensuring secure, standards-based data exchange.

Incorporating the updated OMB SPD 15 categories into the United States Core Data for Interoperability (USCDI), FHIR implementation guides, and health IT certification criteria will promote consistency across the ecosystem and support CMS’s broader goals in prevention, wellness, and chronic disease management3. Further, these standards 
will aid in bias mitigation in AI tools used for clinical decision support and resource allocation.

We respectfully urge CMS and ASTP/ONC to integrate the revised OMB SPD 15 standards into all plans to advance interoperability.

As conveners of the Data Equity Coalition, we appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this Request for Information (RFI).

Sincerely, 
Data Equity Coalition Stakeholders

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
(NOTE: these are brief comments, full comments in the attached PDF)

Executive Summary 

The Rising T1DE Alliance urges CMS and ASTP/ONC to extend patient access, interoperability, and certification requirements—currently applied to EHRs and certified health IT—to include medical device data platforms. These steps are essential to support data-driven, value-based care and empower Medicare beneficiaries with full control of their health information 
 

Key Recommendation: Medical device data portals should be subject to the same regulatory framework as EHRs and certified health IT systems, including FHIR API requirements, patient access standards, and interoperability mandates under the 21st Century Cures Act. This framework is essential for supporting data-driven care models and ensuring the long-term sustainability of value-based care initiatives. 

 

About the Rising T1DE Alliance 

The Rising T1DE Alliance (RTA) is a multi-institution collaboration committed to revolutionizing diabetes care through data-driven, patient-centered, scalable innovation. Co-led by Children's Mercy Kansas City and Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, RTA brings together clinicians, data scientists, implementation leaders, patient advocates, payors, and industry experts to develop, test, and disseminate cutting-edge tools and models for diabetes population health.  In addition to its leaders, active participants in the Alliance include Cincinnati Children's, University of Kansas Medical Center, Montana HIE Big SKY Care Connect, and activities cover both pediatric and adult patient populations.  The RTA also works closely with the Diabetes Technology Society, who created The Integration of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Data into the Electronic Health Record (iCoDE) Project. The 2022 iCoDE Report: CGM-EHR Integration Standards and Recommendations serves as a model for a collaborative, multi-stakeholder approach to advancing medical device data interoperability and integration. 


Conclusion 

The Rising T1DE Alliance urges CMS and ASTP/ONC to extend comprehensive data access, ownership, and interoperability requirements to medical device data and its related platforms. This action would close a significant gap in the current digital health ecosystem, provide Medicare beneficiaries with complete control over their health information, and enable sustainable value-based care programs that improve outcomes while reducing costs. 
	Medical device data—including continuous glucose monitoring and insulin delivery data—falls within the definition of electronic health information (EHI) as outlined in the ONC Cures Act Final Rule. EHI encompasses not only the USCDI but all electronic protected health information (ePHI) maintained in a designated record set and used to inform care. As such, medical device platforms that hold, transmit, or display this information should be subject to the same access, interoperability, and anti-information blocking requirements applied to EHRs and other certified health IT. 

Medical device data represents some of the most actionable health information available to patients and providers. The continuous, real-time nature of this data makes it particularly valuable for preventive care, chronic disease management, and population health initiatives. Ensuring this data is accessible, interoperable, and patient-controlled aligns perfectly with the goals outlined in this RFI and supports the transition to a truly patient-centric digital health ecosystem. 

The sustainability of innovative care models depends on comprehensive data integration. The Rising T1DE Alliance's data-driven care programs demonstrate that when medical device data is properly integrated with clinical and claims data, the result is measurably better patient outcomes, reduced healthcare costs, and economically viable value-based care arrangements. Without standardized access to medical device data, these promising care models cannot achieve the scale necessary for broad Medicare beneficiary impact. 
 
CMS has the opportunity to accelerate the adoption of evidence-based, data-driven care models by establishing the regulatory framework that makes comprehensive health data integration both possible and sustainable. The extension of EHR-level requirements to medical device data and its platforms represents a critical step toward this goal.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1a. I appreciate digital health products that provide feedback about important factors that support health, such as diet, exercise, mindfulness, and sleep.
PC-1b. I do not need a personal assistant, as I am capable of synthesizing and acting on information on my own without the interference of AI or other software.
PC-2 I have easy access to my medical information through my providers' electronic health record platforms.
PC-2a. Access to my medical information allows me to ensure the information I have provided has been properly recorded, allows me to update the medications I am taking, gives me access to lab results so I can consider lifestyle changes or to maintain healthy choices to achieve or maintain optimal results, and it allows me to see information across providers on the same platform for a holistic view of my information.
PC-2b. it would be valuable to have one portal or system for prior authorization and to eliminate the tremendous reliance on faxing documentation to insurance companies. It would also help to allow information to flow between healthcare providers who are not on the same electronic health record. 
PC-3 My providers generally use Epic and MyChart platforms. They continue to improve over time. 
PC-4a. One feature that would be very helpful is to connect health system financial applications with patient insurance systems in the context of knowing out-of-pocket costs before a decision is made about whether or not to seek elective health services. The cost estimate is just an estimate that seems to be made without regard for a person's individual insurance policy provisions, so it would help people have better information about their financial obligations before seeking care. Patients would also be helped by knowing the costs associated with providers who are embedded in care due to exclusive contracts who are not in-network for the patient's insurance coverage; this could prevent exorbitant out-of-pocket balances that sometimes occur when a patient doesn't have a choice of provider for certain aspects of care. A care navigation app that contained information about exclusive contract providers would make their presence more transparent and avoid surprise bills. I believe these systems do not exist because apps with these features would lessen the ability of insurance companies to shift costs to patients and would harm their profit margins.
PC-5 Younger patients who are comfortable with technology already have a heightened interest in digital health products. With the connectivity they experience in other aspects of their digital lives, they cannot understand why healthcare data lacks this connectivity and restricts their and their provider's ability to see all of their information in one place.
PC-5a. Cost is a major barrier to adoption of digital health products. Organizations and providers have already spent trillions of dollars collectively to stand up their electronic health records and associated applications. The main criterion for reviewing applications has to be privacy of Protected Health Information and cybersecurity. This data should not be comingled with data from elsewhere in the federal technology ecosystem. Streamlining of bureaucratic processes to reduce waste associated with prior authorization and other insurance-driven workflows would also be important to preserve healthcare dollar resources for reinvestment in the actual care of people.
PC-6 It is important to understand the range of abilities and technology access across generations, without making judgements or assumptions about each generation. That said, accommodating a variety of technology tools is helpful, including but not limited to computers, cellphones, and iPads. The impact of disabilities that impact how people use technology should also be considered.
PC-7 Data collection should not place an added burden on providers or patients. Common data sets using NIST standards for uniformity and accuracy of data collection and cybersecurity should be considered. Any data collected should not be used in any way to restrict a person's freedom to make their own healthcare decisions and choices.
PC-8a. Data that is valuable but hard to access includes clinical data, appointment schedules and prices. Clinical data often requires providers to make special efforts to document through clicking on boxes or remembering obscure codes to get credit for work they are performing. Appointment schedules are not set up to work effectively within the realities of fluid changes occurring in day-to-day operations. Prices are impossible to pin down due to the differences in charges vs. actual costs of care and the web of insurance contract provisions regarding copays and deductibles. A single payor system would eliminate bureaucratic waste and close loopholes that can be exploited for fraud and abuse. A simplified system would also be able to provide data for research to improve peoples' lives.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
CMS, ASTP/ONC, and NLM should support adoption of the LOINC–SNOMED CT Ontology as part of its health IT regulatory and quality reporting framework. The ontology provides a harmonized representation of laboratory and clinical observations by embedding LOINC concepts within the SNOMED CT ontological structure. This alignment allows for consistent semantic interpretation across systems, supporting more robust FHIR-based data exchange, clinical quality measurement, and public health reporting.
The ontology now in its v1.0 release as of March 2025 contains over 35,000 mapped concepts covering high-volume laboratory tests and physiological measurements (LOINC / SNOMED CT – Regenstrief Institute, Inc. and SNOMED International, n.d.). It offers implementers the flexibility to use LOINC, SNOMED CT, or the harmonized concepts based on their system’s needs, reducing duplication and ensuring semantic alignment. CMS should consider referencing this ontology in certification criteria, USCDI+, and quality programs to accelerate alignment with international terminology best practices and promote more meaningful use of structured data in real-world workflows.

The LOINC SNOMED CT extension (LOINC SNOMED ontology) will be very helpful for stakeholders. The LOINC model is different than the SNOMED CT concept model for various reasons and it’s wonderful to see the LOINC will be “SNOMED-ized” with the attributes, etc.

Finding more SMEs for the different stakeholders related to LOINC will help with the acceleration of the releases.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
CMS and ASTP/ONC should enable FHIR-based exchange of advance directive forms, using HL7 PACIO’s Advance Directive Interoperability (ADI) Implementation Guide as a foundation. Partnering with the National Association for Home Care and Hospice (NAHC) would help ensure adoption and alignment across post-acute and end-of-life care settings. This supports person-centered care, reduces documentation burdens, and ensures patients’ wishes are accessible across care transitions under TEFCA. 

State Variation = FHIR IG Extensions or Profiles
•	State-specific variations can be handled in FHIR via profiles or extensions, allowing a national IG with localized constraints

A FHIR hackathon for such implementation 
•	Pilot a national implementation model
•	Generate sample artifacts for training & certification
•	Identify legal-to-technical translation gaps (e.g., notary, witnesses, revocation)
•	Bring together:
o	HL7 PACIO
o	NAHC
o	AARP
o	Epic/Oracle Health/PointClickCare
o	CMS Innovation Center
o	HIEs and public health agencies
o	State legal reps
•	Hackathon themes could include:	
o	Cross setting access  (hospital, SNF, home health)
o	Patient app prototype (upload and validate directive)
o	State specific logic (adjust for state notary/witness requirements)
o	Clinical workflow integration (display directive in ED, EHR, post acute)
o	Validation engine  (ensure validation and legal compliance)

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Public Comment on CMS–2025–0050
(Medicaid Health Technology and Ecosystem Modernization)

To Whom It May Concern at CMS and HHS,

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public comment on this important initiative. I submit this both as a caregiver and health advocate, as well as someone with direct experience navigating the gaps in our current Medicaid system.

I am the mother of two adult dependents with cystic fibrosis—one of whom is a Medicaid recipient—and I have spent decades navigating complex systems of care, from hospital networks and specialty pharmacies to federal and state programs. In addition to my personal experience, I served as a national volunteer on the chronic illness and health reform team for the RFK Jr. presidential campaign, where I helped lead outreach to families facing complex care challenges and advocated for solutions rooted in prevention, food access, and caregiver support.

⸻

1. Recognize the Gray Zone Between Chronic Illness and Formal Disability

Many individuals on Medicaid live with serious, unpredictable chronic illnesses or serve as unpaid caregivers for those who do. These individuals often fall into a gray area—not officially disabled, but also not consistently employable due to flare-ups, hospitalizations, or caretaking demands. The current process to gain disability status is so complex that many must hire a lawyer—an impossible step for those already living on the financial edge.

We urgently need a pathway within Medicaid eligibility that recognizes this lived reality and avoids penalizing individuals or families for not fitting rigid definitions.

⸻

2. Streamline Access and Reduce Bureaucratic Burdens

The Medicaid system, as it currently functions, is extremely difficult to navigate—even for highly engaged and informed families like mine. More paperwork and shifting eligibility rules, especially without widespread public education, will only increase coverage churn and medical instability.

Recommendation:
CMS should invest in plain-language education, multilingual navigation support, and case managers trained in serving the chronically ill and caregiver populations.

⸻

3. Remove State Border Barriers for Complex Care

Those with rare or complex diseases often need to travel across state lines to access specialty care. Yet state-by-state Medicaid rules often delay or deny needed care—a problem that disproportionately harms those in rural or underserved regions.

Recommendation:
Standardize reciprocal authorization across state lines, particularly for medically complex individuals, and encourage interstate Medicaid “care-corridor” compacts.

⸻

4. Prioritize Nutrition and Food Access—Especially in Food Deserts

Access to healthy, nutrient-dense food is a medical necessity, not a luxury—particularly for individuals with chronic or metabolic conditions. In food deserts, where fresh food is often unavailable or unaffordable, health outcomes suffer and dependency on emergency care and medication increases.

Recommendation:
Establish a national Food-as-Medicine benefit that enables providers to prescribe healthy food and partner with local farms, CSAs, and mobile markets. This should be fully integrated into Medicaid plans and tracked with the same importance as pharmaceutical coverage.

⸻

5. Empower Through Employment—Don’t Threaten Coverage Because of It

While we all want to see people thrive and participate in meaningful work, many with chronic illnesses or caregiving roles face inconsistent capacity to work. Threatening Medicaid access based on work status will backfire—creating hardship rather than empowerment.

Instead, we should offer remote work training, micro-credentialing, and job placement support as optional pathways out of dependency, not punitive mandates.

Recommendation:
CMS should pilot Medicaid-funded career programs tied to flexible, remote roles—particularly for caregivers and the medically complex—paired with stable healthcare coverage to foster true upward mobility.

⸻

Conclusion

The next era of Medicaid must be rooted in reality:
	•	Not all disabilities are formally recognized.
	•	Not all caregivers can work full time.
	•	Not all health can be restored with prescriptions alone.
	•	And not all lives fit into a checkbox.

We have the opportunity to build a smarter, more compassionate system—one that reduces costs while improving quality of life, dignity, and health.

Respectfully submitted,
Jacqueline Capriotti
Founder, Victory Garden Alliance
Chronic Illness & Caregiver Advocate

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As CMS explores modernization of the health technology ecosystem, we encourage the agency to prioritize digital innovation and standardization within the Independent Dispute Resolution (IDR) process under the No Surprises Act (NSA).
The NSA's IDR framework is essential in protecting patients and resolving out-of-network payment disputes. However, the process remains overly manual and fragmented. By streamlining the IDR system with modern technology, CMS can:
•	Reduce administrative burden on providers, payers, and IDR entities
•	Improve compliance through standardized digital workflows
•	Enhance transparency and auditability of determinations
•	Facilitate real-time tracking of status, timelines, and fee processing
•	Improve access to structured data for oversight and analysis
We recommend CMS:
1.	Invest in a centralized IDR platform with secure bi-directional APIs that all parties (payers, providers, IDR Entities) can integrate with.
2.	Adopt national standards for data exchange in IDR submissions, leveraging FHIR or similar protocols.
3.	Enable real-time dashboards and status alerts to support compliance with statutory timelines.
4.	Pilot AI-driven triage tools for dispute eligibility, batching validation, and decision support—without compromising neutrality.
5.	Streamline the IDR Entity approval process to add capacity to the pool of IDREs possibly through a tech-enabled certification and monitoring process—ensuring timely onboarding of qualified entities while maintaining integrity and oversight.
These improvements would not only increase efficiency but would also better align the IDR process with CMS’s broader goals for interoperability, equity, and transparency.
Thank you for considering these suggestions as part of CMS’s ongoing tech innovation efforts.
Sincerely,
Michael Izhaky
CEO & Founder, Qualtrate

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
In response to "TD-5. How could a nationwide provider directory of FHIR endpoints improve access to health information for patients, providers, and payers? Who should publish such a directory, and should users bear a cost?"

A "endpoint registry" could be helpful in facilitating data exchange.  NPPES is not the right place for these endpoints.  Organizations often have many facility codes (NPI Type 2s) and many individual providers (NPI1s).  These electronic endpoints (of type FHIR, Direct, & others) need to be published on the organization-level.  Endpoints should be bound at the EHR or organization level. For example the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) identifier "dukehealth.org" could be the primary key to lookup electronic endpoints for that organization.  This record would also tie together all related facilities (NPI2s) and individual providers (NPI1s), in a similar way to an FEIN.

Also individual providers are usually not the individuals responsible for updating NPPES or other organization/affiliation data records.  HHS must make it easy for organization-level staff and/or agents to manage published information on their behalf.  CMS/ASTP/HHS may consider using DNS to verify/ascertain organization-level identity.

The bar should be low for organizations to publish their own information.  It should be achievable at a low cost with just a content-delivery-network (CDN) and a well-known URL.  A FHIR server should not be required, as this is unnecessary complexity for this type of data.  HHS should aggregate information into one place and provide both APIs and a website for easy lookup of information.  It makes sense if CMS paid for aggregated registry.  I would imagine this registry to be comprised of many entity/object types....not just NPIs.  All entries would be JSON documents with a few common fields across all records.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Remote Physiologic Monitoring (RPM) creates access to real-time data, empowering Americans, especially those in rural areas, to take accountability for their health in partnership with their clinicians. Patients appreciate building knowledge and self-management capability through the use of RPM tools. We welcome the conversation on how connected health technologies can generate and leverage data to deliver meaningful results for patients, consumers, and taxpayers. We look forward to working with CMS and ASTP to improve the current infrastructure to increase beneficiary access to effective digital capabilities needed to make informed health decisions, and increase data availability for all stakeholders contributing to health outcomes.

The Remote Monitoring Leadership Council is a new collaborative of seven, innovative companies operating across all 50 states and collectively offering a large percentage of all remote monitoring and care management services being delivered to Medicare beneficiaries. In addition to advancing patient access to these important tools, we have agreed to promote best practices and standards for the delivery of RPM services. Our companies are collecting vast amounts of patient data that is provided to both patients and treating providers. Efficacy in our field requires that we solve for interoperability and ensure the rapid movement of highly-curated data to the clinical care team, who uses it to make crucial treatment decisions. Our capabilities should be a top use case for efforts to unlock data from the point of care and make it more available for treatment. Visit rpmleadershipcouncil.org for more information.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
H1 applauds CMS’s focus on data interoperability and value-based care. The RFI correctly identifies provider directory and network data as essential for VBC, but current systems remain fragmented.  We urge the agency to foster private-public partnerships that fuel innovation, open data across standardized frameworks and breakdown data barriers that inhibit value based care.

H1’s platform provides one unified source of accurate provider information – including network affiliations, specialties, languages, locations, and credentialing status – delivered via open APIs. These capabilities directly address the RFI’s concerns, as illustrated below. 

In the attached document, we offer recommendations to harness mature private-sector solutions (like H1’s) in CMS initiatives: endorse voluntary certification of high-quality provider directory APIs, integrate such APIs in TEFCA/FHIR frameworks, and focus solutions on enabling interoperability in service of value based care.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
On behalf of Vitality Group, please find attached our formal response. As a global leader in behavior-based health improvement with active programs across Medicare Advantage, commercial, and ACA populations, we appreciate the opportunity to contribute to this forward-looking conversation. Our mission is 'To Make People Healthier' - a principle that aligns closely with the administration’s Make America Healthier Again initiative and its recognition that lasting health begins with behavior. Drawing from our experience operating in 41 markets and serving over 40 million members globally, this submission outlines practical, scalable recommendations that support CMS’s vision of a digitally enabled, prevention-oriented, and patient-empowered Medicare system.

This comment focuses specifically on the Patient and Caregiver Empowerment (PC‑1 to PC‑7) and Value-Based Care Enablement (VB‑1 to VB‑4) domains, and highlights policy changes that could remove longstanding frictions—such as fragmented data access, regulatory complexity, and limited support for digital tools and behavior-linked incentives. It also reflects our interest in participating in ongoing framework development and pilot innovation alongside CMS. 

We look forward to continued collaboration.

Sincerely,
Vitality Group

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Organization Name: Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS)
Comment:
On behalf of the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS), we are pleased to provide public comments on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP) Health Technology Ecosystem Request for Information (RFI). 

HIMSS is a global advisor, thought leader and member-based society committed to reforming the global health ecosystem through the power of information and technology. As a mission-driven non-profit, HIMSS offers an unique depth and breadth of expertise in health innovation, public policy, workforce development, research, and analytics to advise global leaders, developers, end users, patients, and influencers on best practices in health information and technology driven by health equity. Through our innovation engine, HIMSS delivers key insights, education and engaging events to healthcare providers, governments, and market suppliers, ensuring they have the right information at the point of decision. HIMSS serves the global health information and technology communities with focused operations across North America, Europe, the United Kingdom, the Middle East, and Asia Pacific. Our members include more than 127,000 individuals, 480 provider organizations, 470 non-profit partners, and 650 health services organizations. Our global headquarters is in Rotterdam, The Netherlands and our Americas headquarters is in Chicago, Illinois.

HIMSS's comments are in the attached document.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This response to CMS-0042-NC reflects the perspectives of Aegis Ventures and the Digital Consortium—an alliance of 11 leading, not-for-profit health systems across the United States—guided by the leadership of Dr. John Noseworthy, President and CEO Emeritus of Mayo Clinic.

At Aegis Ventures, we build companies that solve structural problems in healthcare. Our work focuses on care navigation, administrative simplification, and digital tools that work for patients and their caregivers. Through the Consortium, we co-develop solutions with health systems and patients, focusing on what works in real-world care delivery. We’ve built products that help patients manage chronic conditions, reduce unnecessary visits, and improve follow-through after hospital discharge—while addressing the operational barriers that slow adoption.

This gives us a close view into the gaps that patients, caregivers, and providers face every day. We understand the technical and policy infrastructure needed to scale digital tools across Medicare populations. And we understand what it takes to earn trust—among patients, providers, and caregivers alike.

The perspectives we share in this response reflect that vantage point. We welcome the opportunity to support CMS in building a digital ecosystem that works for everyone.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
On behalf of Hackensack Meridian Health (HMH), we thank you for the opportunity to comment on the Health Technology Ecosystem Request for Information (RFI) issued by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy (ASTP)/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) (ASTP/ONC). HMH strongly supports the goals outlined in the CMS and ASTP/ONC RFI on digital health, particularly its focus on leveraging innovation to enhance patient care, streamline administrative processes, and promote efficiencies. As a leading integrated health network actively deploying artificial intelligence (AI) and digital tools across clinical and operational settings, HMH recognizes the immense opportunity to improve outcomes for millions of Medicare beneficiaries. We believe that digital health innovations can be used to reduce provider burden and drive higher-quality, more personalized care. Our comments reflect real-world experiences in using AI and digital technologies to transform diagnostics, surgery, care coordination, and administrative workflows.
To unlock digital health’s full potential, HMH supports policies prioritizing seamless data interoperability and FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) expansion for secure information exchange. We also encourage investment in cloud-based platforms and APIs promoting scalable integration. Policymakers should expand Medicare coverage for clinically validated digital health technologies, simplify reimbursement pathways for providers, and promote the use of patient-centered design to ensure accessibility, especially for older adults. Additionally, supporting AI and predictive analytics is critical to delivering proactive, personalized care recommendations that drive better health outcomes. Our recommendations focus on four key priorities: (1) advancing patient-centered digital tools; (2) removing barriers to interoperable, accessible AI; (3) strengthening provider enablement and workflow integration; and (4) establishing robust frameworks for AI reimbursement, liability, and data privacy. Our full comments on RFI are attached.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As the author of the 1997 book, "Demanding Medical Excellence: Doctors and Accountability in the Information Age," I have long been an advocate for medicine using technology to put evidence and clinical experience into a digital form that can be used to consistently make care better, safe, more patient-centered and more cost effective.

In 2017, I addressed precisely the concern of this RFI, a health technology ecosystem, in an invited commentary for The BMJ (formerly the British Medical Journal) that was selected as an Editor's Choice because it laid out an important vision of the future. It drew positive comments both from eminent clinicians such as Dr. Tom Delbanco, who coined the term "patient-centered;" former JAMA editor Dr. George Lundberg; and technology visionary Dr. Eric Topol, in addition to patient activists and advocates.

In 2024, I updated that vision in an invited commentary for the blog of the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology and Bioethics at Harvard Law School. Its title was "Artificial intelligence plus data democratization requires new health care framework." It is attached.

Let me be clear: the radical changes in the relationship between doctors and patients enabled by artificial intelligence cannot be addressed through handing stewardship to the traditional care system, big tech companies and some patient representatives thrown in for good measure. We need the kind of paradigm shift that the "collaborative health" framework I propose represents. But only government has the power to propel our current health technology ecosystem into a more adaptive, patient-oriented, flexible and accountable one.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Organization Name: Association for Behavioral Health and Wellness (ABHW)
Comment:
Dear Administrator Oz and Assistant Secretary Keane; 

The Association for Behavioral Health and Wellness (ABHW) is pleased to respond to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP/ONC) Health Technology Ecosystem Request for Information (RFI). 

ABHW is the national voice for payers managing behavioral health insurance benefits. Our member companies provide coverage to 200 million people in the public and private sectors to treat mental health (MH), substance use disorders (SUDs), and other behaviors that impact health and wellness. 

Our organization aims to increase access, drive integration, support prevention, raise awareness, reduce stigma, and advance evidence-based treatment and quality outcomes. Furthermore, our policy work strives to ensure that physical and behavioral health care is integrated and coordinated. ABHW is focused on guaranteeing better outcomes for whole-person care for all individuals and communities. We believe access to comprehensive, evidence-based MH and SUD services is critical to enhancing patients’ health and overall well-being.

Our members recognize the power of digital behavioral health solutions to expand care access, increase providers' efficiency, and provide patients with tailored, data-driven insights. However, the widespread adoption and integration of these solutions still have challenges related to interoperability, member engagement, and measuring the evidence base. As a result, we are advocating for the reforms in our attached letter that will help foster collaboration between health insurers, providers, and technology developers. Some of these proposed changes are essential to fully realize the potential of digital behavioral health in improving care delivery and outcomes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
For answers to: PC2,3,5,8,10,11,12,13,14; PR2,3,4,5,6,7,8,11; PA1,2,3,4,5; TD1,2,4,5,6,7,9,13,14,16,17,18; VB3,7,12,13,15 please see attached file.
Today payment incentives strongly incent the consolidated delivery systems to block interoperability. They and their EHR vendors have a long history of preventing external interoperability though they support internal interoperability at vast scale. For political reasons these systems and their EHRs cannot totally refuse to interoperate so they engage in blocking tactics ranging from making mandated APIs difficult to access to claiming to support interoperability with platforms that do not support actual modern APIs. One current effort to prevent true interoperability while claiming to be interoperable is TEFCA. The Cures Act defines information blocking as limiting the access exchange and use of information. TEFCA is information blocking to prevent a modern digital health economy. TEFCAs brokers limit access, TEFCAs IHE protocols limit exchange and TEFCAs document payloads limit use. 
HHS should work on financial incentives for delivery systems to provide functioning APIs including enforcement of information blocking and antitrust laws. CMS should reset payment rates so that services which are digitally available are paid materially more. CMS should require changes in the CPT system to differentiate services with truly interoperable data from those which are not. Any service where the provider sees fit to share the detailed data in a proprietary system preventing true competition but not to the same level of detail and speed with an HIE (which competitors can access) should be paid materially less. Services with data hiding prevent shopping are less valuable.
PC10: Is there actual use of TEFCA as claimed? Are there actual examples where an app queries a QHIN which then using a single RLS query goes to another QHIN which queries that QHINs EHRs and then provides the record? TEFCAs claimed examples appear to be using other pre-existing QHIN transport mechanisms or an entirely different network such as Carequality. TEFCAs claims of moving to FHIR do not stand up to technical scrutiny.  
PC11: HIEs are extraordinary public resources allowing data to escape EHRs and to do so with public private governance. HIEs could serve as immunization registries. These should be merged into HIEs. There are a many high-performing HIEs including for the states of OK, NE, IN, MD, AZ and CO. HIEs as Health Data Utilities can serve as a valuable tool for patients wishing to change providers who can access their HIE records.  HIEs could be provided in states which do not have them for less cost than what CDC is spending on ineffective IT today. HIEs robust EMPIs would provide the CDC with longitudinal patient data. CDC funded data silos such as immunization registries, public health labs and ECR should be moved to HIEs where all clinicians could access this data. CDC would then have more rapid information about disease outbreaks like COVID where HIEs knew in hours which the CDC was not able to learn for months.
PR11: Requiring patient consent for TEFCA transmission including query would start to offset the fact that TEFCA is innately insecure and privacy breaching. TEFCA is insecure because instead of using modern zero trust principles, once someone is on TEFCA they can roam freely secured only by TEFCAs attestations. TEFCA also breaches privacy.  While data transmissions can be encrypted TEFCAs promise that a single query will return all records of a patient requires the RLS to know where every patient has been seen.  This can only be done by either requiring every provider to report every patient they have seen or querying all providers to ask if they have seen the patient.  Identify of the provider or querying agent is required e.g. Planned Parenthood, STD clinic, behavioral health clinic so the nature of a patients care is known throughout the system. Unlike the chart itself this query metadata cannot be encrypted because it is needed to find the record. Requiring explicit PKCE patient consent BEFORE the query and before the report goes to the QHIN would let the patient determine if they want information about their medical care to be globally available. Today absent individual consent or a 1:1 Business Associate Agreement with each party to the transaction all TEFCA transmissions are HIPAA Breaches since TEFCAs permitted use process has never been through the NPRM needed to rewrite privacy regulations.
TD13: Fully functioning APIs allowing patients to control their data are essential to promoting competition in the US healthcare system. It is hard to imagine making America great again if zero productivity growth in healthcare continues. Making America healthy again will require pervasive behavior changes. Digital enablement on cell phones powered by a combination of lifestyle data from phone sensors and clinical data from EHR APIs will be core to these behavior changes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
HealthEx Public comment on CMS-0042-NC; RIN 0938-AV68:

HealthEx appreciates the opportunity to provide input on CMS and ASTP's Request for Information on the Health Technology Ecosystem. Our response reflects our commitment to ensuring that individuals can securely and effectively access, manage, and share their health information—grounded in a vision of patient empowerment and interoperable infrastructure. 

Our full RFI response can be viewed in the attachments provided alongside our public comment. 

See here for a brief video on HealthEx: https://tinyurl.com/3etr8fmv
See here for a brief overview deck on HealthEx: https://tinyurl.com/yf2thj25
See here for our full RFI response (also attached to our comment): https://tinyurl.com/2jyjmmza

Who We Are:
HealthEx is a modern data rights management platform that enables secure, scalable, and compliant data access. Backed by General Catalyst and collaborating with major institutions such as MD Anderson, leading payers, state health information exchanges (HIEs), and accountable care organizations (ACOs), HealthEx has become a national leader in enabling Individual Access Services (IAS) under TEFCA. Our system is built with robust patient identity verification, digital consent, real-time data access and delivery, and endpoint discoverability. 

A Policy and Pilot Blueprint for CMS:
We propose a CMS-sponsored pilot project in which CMS partners with HealthEx to activate 100,000 Medicare beneficiaries to access and exchange their longitudinal clinical data across sites of care. This would enable CMS to close key care gaps that persist under claims-based infrastructure, understand the value of care provided, and alongside address fraud, waste, and abuse. Patients in turn are given the ability to access, retrieve, and direct access to their data to drive better care outcomes. The project would also highlight practical examples of issues patients run into while accessing their own data from the networks, and drive CMS-motivated change to resolve these. 

The pilot leverages existing TEFCA IAS protocols—including IAL2/AAL2 digital identity verification and digitally enforceable consent—and will work in concert with CMS tools such as BlueButton 2.0 and MyMedicare.gov. By aligning policy with innovation, this pilot can serve as a springboard for CMS’s digital health transformation goals, benefiting patients, providers, and plans alike.

CMS Policy Recommendations from HealthEx:
In support of patient-directed exchange and the CMS vision for a modernized ecosystem, we submit six key policy recommendations (originally shared publicly via HealthEx in May 2025 as part of a policy memo):

1. Incentivize or mandate TEFCA participation for CMS-regulated entities to ensure IAS availability at scale.

2. Mandate responses to IAS requests and presume TEFCA-compliant verification meets HIPAA identity and authorization requirements.

3. Reject additional identity burdens, such as requiring patient portal credentials, when IAS requests use IAL2/AAL2 tokens plus consent.

4. Grant safe harbor to organizations performing patient matching as part of IAS fulfillment.

5. Mandate publication of provider and payer endpoints in a CMS-backed directory for record location services. We are pleased to hear CMS has made a commitment to support this type of endpoint directory.

6. Extend IAL2 identity token validity with refresh tokens (similar to Patient Access APIs), so patients don’t need to repeat identity verification for each data access instance.

These recommendations are aimed at removing friction from consumer-directed exchange and enabling patients to act as effective stewards of their data. 

A Scalable Path Forward:
HealthEx stands ready to support CMS through both pilot implementation and policy collaboration. Our platform can serve as the foundation for scalable, secure, and standards-based interoperability that improves outcomes and equity. We look forward to working with CMS, ASTP, and stakeholders across the ecosystem to turn the promise of patient-directed exchange into a national standard.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
June 16, 2025
The Honorable Mehmet Oz
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health & Human Services
Re: Request for Information; Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0042-NC)

My name is Tomas Moran and I am a healthcare consultant.  I served as Senior Director of Quality and Planning at the Palo Alto Medical Foundation (PAMF) through 2009, where I managed the entire analytic workspace.  During that time, I was a national speaker at the American Medical Group Association’s annual conferences and chaired the then-newly-formed Quality Council in 2008.  Prior to that, I served as Associate Director of Quality at Stanford University Health System (1989-1999), where I also wrote the software for and managed one of the first clinical lab computer systems (1979-1989) in the United States.  Most recently, my Company ran a Health Information Exchange in the Kansas City region through 2017.   And from 2017 through the present, we designed and installed a value-based payment system for the Jackson County Mental Health Fund.  
As a engineering graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1976, I brought much of that discipline into healthcare operation, particularly in the area of healthcare information and quality improvement methodologies.  During my career in healthcare – going into my fifth decade – I have seen the promise of empowering the patient and the provider with timely and complete information fall flat on its face many times.  It is clear to me – as well as many of my colleagues – that the traditional approach to liberating health information has failed largely because the system, which includes the entire economic sphere of the health care industry, does not want it to work in that manner.  We have seen the pernicious effects of “data blocking”, a tactic used by health systems to make the flow of information more difficult if it is going outside of its “network”.
The promise that more advances in protocols such as FHIR – in all its flavors – will solve interoperability is not to be believed.  I was there when HL7, FHIR’s precursor, made the same promise.  Those of us who have worked in health systems or had to interact with the health insurance industry regarding data know that the problem will not be solved until the time that the one entity who cares most to bring interoperability to the medical record is allowed to control it:  the patient.
We are in a very opportune moment, when actions by CMS can lead to a real breakthrough in record interoperability.  The confluence of the passage of its Cures Act and the advent of large-language models open new avenues through which to pursue real portability of records, which was – at least theoretically – a goal of the HIPAA law that I helped to implement at PAMF.
Therefore, my request to you is simple:  that you pursue policies and make regulations that facilitate that any electronic document provided to a patient through a portal which forms part of the patient’s record will be recognized as a legal copy of such document provided that the integrity and provenance of such document can be established by standard security methods.
We have assembled a team of clinicians, informaticists, and patient advocates who can take it from there.  We are prepared to build an industry based on trust – akin to our financial institutions --  that will facilitate true innovation while preserving the individual patient’s right to control their own data.  
 We will be happy to provide a more detailed briefing to your staff if you are interested in our approach.
--
Tomas Moran
Principal
Tomas Moran & Associates LLC
TomasM@moran-associates.com
650-799-0008

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
ARCHANGELS has collaborated with states, communities, employers, and health systems nationwide to advance caregiver support using innovative technology solutions. The approach focuses on identifying caregivers, assessing their unique intensity of experience, and connecting them to tailored resources, all while integrating seamlessly into existing care environments. This work demonstrates that digital engagement can increase caregiver identification rates and drive meaningful connections to support, even among those who do not self-identify as caregivers.
Through these partnerships, measurable improvements have been observed in both caregiver well-being and care recipient outcomes. For example, digital interventions that include our brief, validated caregiver assessment (Caregiver Intensity Index) have achieved high completion rates (over 40% of caregivers getting their Intensity Score), with staff and clinicians reporting greater preparedness to address caregiving needs in clinical encounters. Additionally, caregivers using this tool report increased access to psychosocial support, which research shows is associated with improved mental health and reduced adverse outcomes for both caregivers and those they support.
There is an opportunity to share expertise on caregiver intensity and the strategies that have proven effective in diverse healthcare environments. By leveraging real-world data and cross-sector partnerships, solutions can be scaled that identify, validate, and empower caregivers at every level of the healthcare system. We have seen tremendous reception from States such as New York, Massachusetts, Michigan, Iowa and Indiana to name a few and health systems such as University of Michigan, Henry Ford, and others. We would welcome a conversation with you and your team at CMS to find examples where you see the greatest receptivity for piloting our program with CMS to solve the needs of caregivers across our nation.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Autonomous.Md appreciates the opportunity to comment on CMS‑0042‑NC, “Health Technology Ecosystem.” We submit the attached letter for the record; the brief highlights below summarize its key points.

1) Digital health tools represent a new care modality. They should be treated on par with in‑person, telehealth, and remote monitoring services and supported by payment and quality frameworks accordingly.

2) Interoperability first. CMS should strengthen open HL7 FHIR (including Bulk FHIR) requirements, expand Blue Button to include clinical data, and mandate broad TEFCA participation supplemented by a nationwide FHIR endpoint directory.

3) Eliminate residual information blocking. Tighten exceptions, enforce penalties, and raise implementation testing standards so that complete, timely data exchange becomes routine.

4) Adopt federated digital identity. Universal acceptance of Login.gov‑level credentials will simplify access, improve patient matching, and reduce portal sprawl.

5) Reduce provider burden while advancing value‑based care. Allow CMS to calculate quality measures from Bulk FHIR exports, automate prior authorization via standard APIs, and modernize ONC certification to include care‑coordination and population‑health modules.

We welcome continued collaboration to build an equitable, patient‑centric, data‑driven Medicare ecosystem. Please refer to the attached letter for full analysis and recommendations.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
We have attached our comment letter in full. Please see our general comments and key recommendations below.

MHDC supports effective and responsible technology adoption that can empower patients to make better decisions for their health and well-being. Since most healthcare services are local, we believe that public-private partnerships and the inclusion of representatives from all local stakeholders, such as providers, payers, regulators, and system developers, are crucial to creating an innovative and competitive marketplace that facilitates health data exchange while also granting the autonomy local markets require to build innovative solutions. National level solutions, e.g., TEFCA, are not purpose-built for commerce, the driving force behind creating a health data economy.

We address in this RFI the foundations of a robust healthcare technology ecosystem, namely: 
• Consumers need a new and innovative digital health economy where transparent, high-fidelity, real-time data fuels the technology innovation required to achieve major advances in clinical and cost effectiveness. 
• Innovation is essential to achieve data liquidity and establish a new digital healthcare ecosystem. This ecosystem will utilize open standards to exchange health data at scale and provide patients with information when and where they need it. 
• Current regulations are not advancing the health data economy sufficiently. CMS and ASTP/ONC must prioritize commerce as the engine of innovation, aligning priorities to minimize friction, reduce costs, and alleviate the burden associated with exchanging health data in the present. 
• Patients, providers, and payers must have access to clinical and claims data to reduce administrative burden, innovate risk-sharing contracts between providers and payers, and permit true value-based care. 
• The market needs a federated, standards-based digital identity framework. Existing efforts and methods to match patients within provider networks and their health plans are burdensome, expensive, and still prone to error.  
• CMS should accelerate the creation of national directory services that support full interoperability among healthcare stakeholders. 
• CMS should shift focus to incentivize or reward participation in state-based data-sharing initiatives and to realign national and regional initiatives (e.g., TEFCA, HIEs) to promote more payer-provider-patient interoperability. 
• CMS should enforce data blocking among patients, providers and payers with substantial financial penalties for those actors who engage in information-blocking practices.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
KuduCare RFI Submission - CMS-0042-NC

To Whom It May Concern:

I respectfully submit our response to CMS's Request for Information (CMS-0042-NC) regarding the modernization of digital health integration and care coordination reimbursement.

This submission draws upon both lived caregiving experience and product leadership in regulated SaMD environments. It outlines actionable, subregulatory opportunities to strengthen the RTM framework in support of mental health self-management, chronic condition stabilization, and family caregiver enablement.

We believe CMS has a critical role to play in:
- Clarifying that CBT-informed behavioral coaching can be delivered through RTM without requiring a mental health diagnosis;
- Encouraging interoperability via TEFCA, FHIR, and Blue Button 2.0 to reduce provider burden;
- Defining RTM as a monitoring-not treatment-pathway to avoid unnecessary regulatory barriers for SaMD innovators;
- And ensuring caregivers are included in the reimbursement-supported care continuum through compliant dyad models.

KuduCare stands ready to support CMS's vision for scalable, cost-effective, and human-centered care. We welcome the opportunity to further contribute to pilot design or technical documentation, should that support CMS's implementation roadmap.

Sincerely,
Anthony Como
Advisor

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Hackathons for In Basket Reduction

The comment ending in CMS-2025-0050-0236 by the Texas Medical Association called out a good point on in basket overload.
The in basket overload is not only happening to the clinicians, but also happening on the administrative/clerical side:
•	Licensed nurses
•	Medical assistants
•	Insurance verification specialists
•	Front desk staff

Phase 1: Strategic Planning & Coalition Building
•	Build cross-functional team: health IT, clinicians, data scientists, terminology experts
•	Define scope: Start with one or two domains (e.g., lab review, imaging triage)
•	Identify partners:
o	EHR Vendors: Epic, Cerner, MEDITECH
o	Tech: Nvidia, Microsoft, Google Cloud, Red Hat
o	Standards Orgs: HL7, SNOMED Intl, openEHR
o	Terminology Tools: Ontoserver, Snowstorm
o	FHIR Hackathon Platforms: Firely, Inferno, Simplifier, Smile CDR
Phase 2: Baseline Data Collection
•	Analyze current in-basket loads
•	Identify top message types (e.g., labs, imaging, patient messages)
•	Document bottlenecks and duplications
•	Interview users (MDs, nurses, admin)
Phase 3: Launch Hackathon Tracks 
Hackathon tracks
•	SMART on FHIR apps to prioritize/route messages
•	SNOMED CT triage rules
•	openEHR bundled contexts- bundle message per episode using openEHR templates
•	NLP plus FHIR- use NLP to summarize or route inbound free-text messages
•	Governance and metrics: dashboards to monitor overload reduction 
Clinician judging 
•	Prizes could be done for clinician usability, nursing usability, reduction impact
•	Use FHIR servers, openEHR sandbox, SNOMED CT API access
•	Synthetic inbox data sets
•	EHR test environments

Phase 4: Pilot Implementations
Hackathon prototypes in real environments (rural CAHs, CAQHs, FQHCs, rural health clinics)
Prioritize
•	Lab results triage
•	Imaging results triage
•	Team based task routing

Track means:
•	Inbox reduction
•	Clinician burnout
•	Patient message response times 

Phase 5: Policy and Standardization
•	Feed successful solutions into HL7 accelerators (Argonaut, Helios, Gravity)
•	Publish SNOMED CT value sets, FHIR profiles, and openEHR templates
•	Propose them for USCDI+ Clinical Workflow or FHIR implementation guides
•	Share results with CMS, ASTP/ONC, Sequoia
•	Share results with AHA, AMA, HIMSS, ACHE and affiliated state and local chapters

Co-sponsored hackathons using FHIR, CDA/CCDA, CCDA to FHIR could help in this endeavor with the specific theme of in basket reduction. To me, HIMSS state chapters could get involved in the promotion as well as bringing in FHIR experts to help in this. 

Showing which finalists actually reduce in basket messages and showing the use case to the clinicians and front line staff personally could be a game changer and could almost make the staff cry from alleviating such a heavy burden.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The monitoring of patients in the hospital (and at home) has not changed over the past 100 years. The current state of hospital care relies on manual, intermittent snapshots of vital sign information once every 4 - 6 hours by a healthcare workforce that is challenged by staffing shortages, which jeopardizes patient safety, and drives up the cost of care.  In the home setting, family caregivers are unreasonably burdened with the responsibility and cost of caring for loved ones yet have little means of recognizing the evolving complications associated with post-acute and/or chronic conditions.

In both settings, patient deterioration is commonly unrecognized until the patient “crashes,” triggering the rapid response team (RRT) in the hospital, or a call to 911 and an ambulance trip to the emergency room from home.  The inevitable consequences of this antiquated practice include transfers to the ICU, increased hospital mortality, increased hospital length of stay (LOS), increased healthcare workforce stress, burn-out, and labor expense, increased emergency room utilization, increased hospital readmissions, patient and family dissatisfaction, and skyrocketing increases in the total cost of healthcare to the US taxpayer and society.

A medical grade wearable for automated continuous patient monitoring is available today that solves each of these problems. The BioButton Continuous Patient Monitoring System provides timely, algorithmic-based alerts as an early warning of meaningful changes in a patient’s vital signs to save valuable staff time, allow for proactive clinical interventions and reduce the burden of manual charting. The BioDashboard clinical triage and intelligence system enables clinicians to receive near real-time trend analysis to help identify potential deterioration at an earlier time-frame. This system provides a comprehensive and scalable end-to-end remote care solution, to support rapid deployments across the healthcare continuum, from in-hospital to at-home.

This BioButton System for continuous patient monitoring is a vivid example of how technology-enabled care can significantly improve patient outcomes while dramatically reducing total cost of care.  If this system were to be installed in every hospital in the US today, it would net save multiple tens of $billions per year to the Medicare and Medicaid programs.  Furthermore, this can easily be implemented for any rural/critical access hospitals to address staffing shortages and keep beds open.  Lastly, family caregivers would no longer be burdened by the overwhelming and unaffordable responsibility of keeping their loved ones out of emergency rooms and hospitals.

Detailed review of patient outcomes data, including publications and costs, are available on request.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1a:
- Understand my loved one’s diagnosis and what they need in place for the highest quality of life
- Virtual, personal assistant to automate care coordination: handle the phone calls to doctors and resources to skip time on hold / playing phone tag
- Personal advocate in a pocket for my loved one: have an AI companion that can attend doctor’s appointments, ask questions on my behalf, synthesize the appointment and next steps

PC-1b:
Our patients ask for support in the following in order of frequency: finding and coordinating with vetted providers and resources (e.g. physical therapy, home care, specialists, meal delivery), managing their medications, Medicaid planning, understanding their benefits and medical bills, as well as getting key health documents in place (e.g. HCP, PoA).

PC-2b: 
- Accurate, aggregated medications (especially for patients admitted to the hospital)
- Facilitating care transitions (e.g., post-hospital discharge

PC-2c: 
It’s difficult to get clinical encounter notes or face sheets from PCPs. They don’t all integrate into HIEs but are the patient’s primary provider.

PC-5: 
Education on the value of care management. Many people do not know what this means and how it can be valuable but once they experience it, find it incredibly valuable.

PC-6: 
Intuitive interfaces with voice as a medium, large text options, and multilingual support.

PC-8a: 
Clinical data, particularly that’s gated behind EPIC. It is so difficult to integrate and they are by far the system of record for health data.

PC-11a:
HIE’s are great in theory but face challenges of limited participation, incomplete and inaccurate information, and lack support for new models of care (e.g. care navigation). 

PR-1: 
Allow for reimbursement of non-clinical staff and/or technology to provide care management services. Financial incentives and channels for awareness on what products exist. Unfortunately provider behavior is typically tied to financial outcomes.

TD-1:
Financial incentives for technology vs. solely fee for service codes for human labor.
