Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem
June 16, 2025

We are submitting for the Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem on behalf of Violet Services, Inc. (Violet Health). We support the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) efforts at increasing beneficiary access to effective digital capabilities needed to make informed health decisions, and increasing data availability for all stakeholders contributing to health outcomes. Our current healthcare data systems are deeply fractured, and we applaud the CMS and ASTP/ONC efforts to lead infrastructure progress.

PC-8., a. What data is valuable, but hard for patients and caregivers, or app developers and other technical vendors, to access for appropriate and valuable use (for example, claims data, clinical data, encounter notes, operative reports, appointment schedules, prices)?
At present moment, patients and caregivers have very limited access to provider skilling data–especially around the patient populations each provider is uniquely skilled at serving. When searching for a provider, it is difficult for patients to obtain accurate  data to understand which patient populations a provider has greater experience with and has completed a sizable amount of clinical education for. We are advocating for a standardized, unified benchmarking system to assess provider skilling in patient populations such as Rural communities and Veterans. This information would allow patients and caregivers to make better, more informed decisions on which providers to seek care from, with the care provided being of higher quality for their specific clinical needs. Additionally, care providers will see a lower rate of burnout as they attract and retain patients from the patient populations they are most passionate about. 


C-12. What are the most valuable operational health data use cases for patients and caregivers that, if addressed, would create more efficient care navigation or eliminate barriers to competition among providers or both?


For the aforementioned provider skilling data would allow for a more effective  mechanism for care navigation and improved access via an enhanced definition of network adequacy. The benchmarking data can be used to better match providers and patients from the patient population with which they have expertise. Routing patients to providers most suited for their care would allow the expansion of personalized care and would facilitate a person-centered approach to care matching. Additionally, comparing provider skills to patient populations across health plan services areas will improve access to care and build systems that incentivize greater transparency and personalization, yielding lower cost of care for all of us. 


In closing, we urge CMS to develop and implement more mechanisms for personalization of healthcare, including more in-depth provider skilling data, greater access to accurate provider directories, and care matching that connects patients to providers best suited for their care.


With regards,

Gaurang Choksi					Kay Nikiforova	
Founder & CEO					Head of Clinical and Research
Violet Services, Inc. 				Violet Services, Inc.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
At Moxe, we believe that interoperability’s moment is now, but getting it right requires more than compliance checklists and technology mandates. It requires smarter, more intentional collaboration between payers and providers, built on a foundation of shared data that’s actually usable and can be trusted.

We’ve seen firsthand that when clinical data is exchanged efficiently, transparently, and in ways that respect provider workflows and payer goals, the result is better care, reduced administrative burden, and stronger financial outcomes. Yet today’s ecosystem remains fragmented. Not just in its infrastructure, but in its incentives. Even the most advanced solutions cannot succeed and thrive if the underlying incentives don’t demand, or even support, sustainable alignment.

To truly modernize healthcare, CMS must go beyond policy directives and technical standards and instead foster conditions that reward the exchange and use of high quality clinical data. That means shifting the focus from technical eligibility to measurable impact. Impact on care, collaboration, and cost. 

While not experts in all aspects of health tech, our perspective is grounded in experience. By securely connecting with more than 100 health systems, the largest national and regional US health plans, and third-party requestors across the country, Moxe’s technology-first approach is fundamentally changing the way clinical data is shared for Payment and Operations use cases. We know what works and what it takes to improve the burdensome, fragmented, and costly state of healthcare data exchange for smarter interoperability grounded in real payer/provider collaboration.

We appreciate CMS’s commitment to advancing technology within the healthcare ecosystem and hope our responses offer practical insight into what it takes to make meaningful progress.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Organization Name: MCG Health, part of the Hearst Health network
Comment:
SECTION/QUESTION: 3. Technical Standards and Certification
TD-9. Regarding certification of health IT:
d. What policy changes could CMS make so providers are motivated to respond to API-based data requests with best possible coverage and quality of data?" 

COMMENT: MCG Health would recommend an incentive program for providers to motivate them to respond to API-based requests.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION/QUESTION: 3. Technical Standards and Certification
TD-11. As of January 1, 2024, many health IT developers with products certified through the ONC Health IT Certification Program are required to include the capability to perform an electronic health information export or “EHI export” for a single patient as well as for patient populations (45 CFR 170.315(b)(10)). Such health IT developers are also required to publicly describe the format of the EHI export. Notably, how EHI export was accomplished was left entirely to the health IT developer. Now that this capability has been in production for over a year, CMS and ASTP/ONC seek input on the following:
a. Should this capability be revised to specify standardized API requirements for EHI export? 

COMMENT: Yes. MCG Health technology experts agree this capability should be revised to specify standardized API requirements for EHI export.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION/QUESTION: 4. Data Exchange
TD-16. What are the tradeoffs of maintaining point-to-point models vs. shared network infrastructure?
a. Do current rules encourage scalable network participation? 

COMMENT: No. MCG Health technology experts do not believe there is currently sufficient industry motivation to utilize TEFCA.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

While not specific to only CMS, the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) authorization process has become overly burdensome, time-consuming, and costly, particularly for small and innovative technology companies. The lengthy timelines, redundant documentation requirements, and complex review procedures create significant barriers to entry and stifle competition. This is particularly acute in health care, where technology and innovation can significantly improve patient outcomes and reduce costs.

The current Administration’s FedRAMP 20x initiative is a promising step toward much-needed reform. By focusing on streamlining authorization pathways, embracing automation, and promoting greater reciprocity, this effort reflects a commitment to modernizing federal information technology (IT) procurement. We look forward to working with you and your team to advance a FedRAMP framework that better aligns with the pace of technological advancement and federal IT modernization goals.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am pleased to submit the attached response, based on my experience working with provider and payer organizations, HHS, and directly with Medicare beneficiaries, particularly dual enrollees, in various capacities over the past decade. I have focused my comments on the practical barriers those patients face when navigating and coordinating their care.
The single most important proposal below is to re-envision HealthCare.gov as the universal patient front door. By redesigning and rebranding the existing website so beneficiaries can (1) discover vetted digital-health tools, (2) authenticate once with a trusted credential such as Login.gov, and (3) grant downstream apps seamless access to payer and provider data, CMS can address the awareness and trust hurdles that currently frustrate patients and caregivers, when it comes to utilizing digital health products. All other patient- or caregiver-facing improvements—price-shopping, appointment scheduling, intake-form automation, and real-time care navigation—depend on that foundational step.
Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your continued efforts to modernize the health-technology ecosystem for America’s seniors and their families.

Sincerely,
Samir Unni

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Cover Statement for Public Comment Submission
RE: CMS–0042–NC – Request for Information: Health Technology Ecosystem

To Whom It May Concern,

On behalf of The Light Collective, a nonprofit organization dedicated to advancing health equity, privacy, and community-led innovation in digital health, we respectfully submit the attached comment in response to the Request for Information (RFI) titled Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS–0042–NC), published in the Federal Register on May 16, 2025.

Our response addresses key prompts across patient, provider, technology, and value-based care domains and offers recommendations to ensure that digital health policy advances trustworthy, equitable, and community-centered innovation. Drawing from direct lived experience, technical expertise, and current research, this comment outlines actionable strategies for incorporating patient-led governance models, improving interoperability, and promoting responsible AI use in healthcare.

We appreciate the opportunity to contribute to this critical dialogue and urge CMS and ONC to prioritize inclusive design, data stewardship, and patient co-leadership as foundational principles in shaping the future health technology landscape.

Sincerely,
Andrea Downing
Co-Founder, The Light Collective

Website: https://lightcollective.org

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The American Clinical Laboratory Association (ACLA) appreciates the opportunity to comment on the Request for Information; Health Technology Ecosystem. ACLA is the national trade association representing leading laboratories that deliver essential diagnostic health information to patients and providers by advocating for policies that expand access to the highest quality clinical laboratory services, improve patient outcomes, and advance the next generation of personalized care.

The ACLA responds to several questions in this RFI (See attached ACLA Response to CMS-ASTP-ONC RFI on Health Technology Ecosystem). ACLA urges the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to carefully consider the role of the laboratory in the larger health interoperability ecosystem.  Laboratories are often heavily dependent upon upstream actors (e.g., an ordering clinician) to provide information to the laboratory in order to be an efficient part of the system. As such, requirements applied to laboratories may be difficult to meet if ordering providers are not obligated to provide the laboratory with the underlying information necessary to meet the request. For example, laboratories may not have sufficient patient demographic information to fulfill other downstream obligations, such as public health reporting or direct patient communication of results.  To ensure that CMS obtains the efficiency it seeks when making changes to interoperability requirements, CMS should be careful in applying any specific requirement to laboratories (as compared to other actors with more direct patient interaction) and evaluate the laboratory’s ability to comply on a case-by-case basis.  In some instances, applying a regulation to the laboratory may necessitate additional requirements imposed on the upstream providers to ensure the laboratory has the necessary information to comply. 

We appreciate the  CMS and ASTP/ONC consideration of the ACLA response to help inform the agency’s efforts to lead infrastructure progress to cultivate this market, increase beneficiary access to effective digital capabilities needed to make informed health decisions, and increase data availability for all stakeholders contributing to health outcomes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Health IT Standards SME registry

CMS, ASTP/ONC, and NLM should jointly maintain a SME registry of subject matter experts, which would be beneficial to enhance the scalability, coordination, and implementation of health IT standards.

Federated SME registry could classify experts by:
•	Standards SMEs (e.g. openEHR, SNOMED CT, LOINC, FHIR, CDA, IDMP)
•	Clinical SMEs (e.g. oncology, behavioral health, public health, etc.)
•	Technical SMEs (e.g. developers, terminologists, etc.)

The profiles can contain:
•	Domain of expertise
•	Certifications
•	Contributions
•	Availability for projects, advisory boards

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Early Career Health Standards Fellowship Program

Jointly sponsored by CMS, ASTP/ONC, NLM and optionally by HIMSS, CAHIIM, AMIA, HL7 International, SNOMED International, Regenstrief Institute, openEHR International

Target audience
•	New graduates (health informatics, computer science, data science, nursing, medicine, etc.)
•	Career changers from clinical, technical, or research backgrounds
•	Interns, residents, and early career professionals

Program Components
•	Standards Implementation Microcredential Path
o	Level 1: Observer/Contributor (FHIR connectathon/hackathon participation)
o	Level 2 : Project role (for example terminology mapping, HL7 IG testing)
o	Level 3: regional implementation 
•	Policy Simulation
o	Mock responses to 
	HL7 IGs
	NLM terminology pilots 
•	Hackathon or Implementation Sprints
o	CCDA to FHIR 
o	IPS with rural health/behavioral health

The levels provide
•	Accredited CEUs / CME hours or CAHIIM recognized microcredentials
•	Mentorship from a senior SME

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Standards and Interoperability Scholars Program
Jointly sponsored by CMS, ASTP/ONC, NLM and optionally by HIMSS, CAHIIM, AMIA, HL7 International, SNOMED International, Regenstrief Institute, openEHR International, IHE International

CMS, ASTP/ONC and NLM could endorse the standards and interoperability scholars program. This program makes masters and PhD students co-creators of national health data infrastructure, rather than waiting to “earn” that access years later. It addresses the pipeline problem, the innovation gap, and the mentorship shortfall — while directly fueling progress on interoperability, terminology, and real-world implementation.
For masters and doctoral students in:
•	Health informatics/biomedical informatics
•	Computer Science
•	Data Science
•	Public Health
•	Medicine
•	Nursing
•	Health Policy or Law

Core Components:
1.	Applied Research and Implementation Labs
Participants are matched with real world challenges, such as:
•	TEFCA semantic alignment (such as USCDI+ vs existing data flows)
•	SNOMED CT concept gaps in behavioral health or maternal health
•	FHIR IG usability studies for underserved providers
Deliverables would be research to publish, policy briefs, implementable artifacts
This work can fulfill masters internship/practicum requirements or masters thesis.
This work can fulfill PhD preceptor, research and/or dissertation requirements.
2.	Standards Policy and Authoring Apprenticeship
a.	Students review IGs, SNOMED CT concept requests, or NLM value set definitions
b.	Students gain experience in:
i.	HL7 ballot comment response tracking
ii.	IHE profile development
iii.	USCDI+ domain prioritization and mapping
c.	Students are paired with standards SME 
3.	Accredited capstone plus national hackathon
a.	Students complete an interoperability capstone (openEHR archetype, CDA to FHIR, IPS, etc.)
b.	Join a hackathon team solving real problems together

Incentives
•	CAHIIM or HL7-endorsed microcredentials
•	Funding for capstone or dissertation through ONC, NLM, CDC grants
•	Priority access to internships or advisory board appointments
•	Invitation to standards stakeholder meetings (e.g., HITAC, HL7 WGM)

Rollout Path
•	Pilots could be launched via:
o	ONC LEAP or SHIEC initiatives
o	CDC fellowships (PHIFP, CSTE Applied Epi Fellowship)
o	NIH/NLM training grants
o	AMIA 10x10 programs modified with implementation focus

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
June 16, 2025 

Request for Information: CMS-0042-NC Health Technology Ecosystem 

Dear Administrator Dr. Oz: 

I appreciate the opportunity to respond to CMS’s Request for Information (RFI) on CMS-0042-NC “Health Technology Ecosystem”. As the Clinical Director at the Direct Supply Innovation & Technology Center in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and a dedicated partner within the senior healthcare sector, I fully support CMS's objective of leveraging digital health solutions to enhance patient care, streamline processes, and reduce redundancies. Technological advancements, particularly interoperability and artificial intelligence, offer significant potential to enhance outcomes, reduce administrative burdens, and improve efficiencies across the senior care continuum.  

Approximately 1.4 million Medicare beneficiaries receive care and live in nursing homes across the U.S. Given unprecedented demographic shifts, the population of older adults is projected to reach approximately 95 million individuals by 2060. Simultaneously, the workforce is not expanding proportionally. Census data indicates the ratio of workforce aged individuals to those over the age of 85 will shift from 31:1 today, to 12:1 by 2060. Demand for caregivers will far outpace the supply. 
Therefore, it is imperative to modernize nursing home regulations and align funding and incentives to support technology adoption, interoperability, and sustained utilization in support of workflow efficiencies, augmentation of the workforce, or workflow re-design to assure quality of care and services for Medicare beneficiaries, with fewer people to provide. 

Current nursing home reimbursement mechanisms inadequately address the substantial costs associated with technology adoption and maintenance. Facilities, especially those within older physical infrastructure, face significant financial and logistical challenges when integrating new technological systems. Addressing these systemic concerns is essential for improving technology access and utilization among Medicare beneficiaries.  

Failure to address technology gaps can lead to increased healthcare costs, reduced access to quality care, and poorer health outcomes. Specifically, inadequate interoperability results in inefficient care delivery, duplication of diagnostic efforts, increased hospital readmissions, and compromised patient safety.   

To mitigate these challenges, we recommend:  

1. Mandating and Funding Interoperable EHR Systems in Skilled Nursing Facilities (SNFs): Extend the CMS Interoperability and Patient Access Rule explicitly to SNFs, providing targeted federal funding and incentives to bridge significant interoperability gaps. (Addressing PT-1: Essential digital health tools for providers; PT-2: Barriers to provider adoption; PT-3: Strategies to encourage provider adoption)  

2. Revising Reimbursement Models: Crucially, reimbursement models must be revised to reflect the genuine costs of technology acquisition, infrastructure upgrades, installation, and ongoing support, especially in older buildings typical of long-term care environments. Incentivizing technology adoption through revised reimbursement structures and targeted grants can significantly accelerate digital transformation in nursing homes. (Addressing PT-2: Barriers to provider adoption)  

3.Incorporating SNFs into Broader CMS Initiatives: Explicitly include SNFs in CMS interoperability and quality initiatives, incentivizing measurable interoperability performance and positive outcomes. (Addressing TV-1: Barriers to technology development and adoption; TV-2: Strategies to encourage technology development)  

CMS responsiveness to improving access to technology for Medicare beneficiaries would benefit from prioritizing public/private partnerships engaging technology stakeholders in processes, access, governance, accountability, and affordability to ensure all Medicare beneficiaries can benefit.  

Ultimately, aligning regulations, incentives, and reimbursement mechanisms is essential for ensuring Medicare beneficiaries in nursing homes have equitable access to critical digital health technologies. Such systemic changes will foster improved patient outcomes, increased operational efficiencies, and more sustainable care environments and prepare these settings for future and improved technology applications. (Addressing PC-5: Encouraging patient and caregiver interest in digital health products; PC-6: Important features for accessibility and ease of use) 

The recommendations outlined above align closely with current best practices and standards set forth by key organizations in health information technology, including the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy/Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP/ONC).  

Sincerely,
Liz Jensen, PhD, MSN
Clinical Director
Direct Supply Innovation & Technology Center @MSOE
Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: Redox, Inc. appreciates the opportunity to respond to CMS’s Request for Information on the Health Technology Ecosystem and commends the Administration’s thoughtful approach to advancing interoperability. As a company solely focused on healthcare data exchange, Redox offers a secure, scalable platform that supports real-time, API-based connectivity across more than 10,000 healthcare organizations and 100+ EHR vendors. Our infrastructure is purpose-built to reduce integration burden, normalize data across disparate systems, and accelerate access to clinical and administrative information. With over 12,000 active integrations and certifications including HITRUST and SOC 2 Type II, Redox serves as an interoperability layer that supports standards like FHIR and simplifies the path to market for developers. We welcome the opportunity to share our experience and support CMS’s continued leadership in this important work.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As an integral part of Colorado’s health care and innovation ecosystem, Colorado Access appreciates the opportunity to submit comments on the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Technology Policy and Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ASTP/ONC) and Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), Request for Information (RFI), Heath Technology Ecosystem, CMS–0042–NC. We are submitting our comments in collaboration with two of our partner organizations in the Colorado health technology and health care access space, Community Managed Care Network/Community Health Provider Alliance (CCMCN/CHPA), a unified care network focused on improving patient outcomes, and Prime Health, a hub for accelerating health innovation and convening cross-sector partners. We each focus our comments on the health programs and systems questions posed by the RFI that fall within our intersecting or particular expertise and organizational experience. Our responses are grouped by the applicable question numbers from the RFI. To make our response quickly digestible and easily understood, we are providing our comments in bullet format within those questions and topics. Please see attached.

Key themes of this response:
• Past interoperability efforts have successfully opened the flow of data between Colorado Access and our partner organizations, facilitating improvements to care coordination and quality of care.
• Emerging interoperability challenges include the rising costs associated with redundant data storage and the frustrating proliferation of unique login requirements for our members.
• The benefits of interoperability have been limited to health care data exchange; fragmented social data regulations act as a damper on many use cases for social-health information exchange.
• Colorado Access is committed to developing innovative solutions for and with our members, in collaboration with our state agencies, provider network, and local and national partners. We welcome the opportunity to inform and participate in improving the health technology ecosystem.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Dear Health and Human Services Department (HHS):

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public comment on the Request for Information (RFI) regarding our Health Technology Ecosystem. We appreciate your time and consideration for the work we currently provide to Health Issuers, Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs) and other partner plan organizations. As an expert supplier in the filing space, specifically for Major Medical, Individual, Small Group, Commercial, and Licensure products, we are proud to support our clients become complaint, and maintain compliance in the Healthcare environment across all the respective states they participate in. 

With respect to the RFI that has been issued, we would like to comment on two sections of this where our work is relevant and crosses over, Payers and Technology Vendors, Data Providers, and Networks. 

PA-2. How can CMS encourage payers to accelerate the implementation and utilization of APIs for patients, providers, and other payers, similar to the Blue Button 2.0 and Data at the Point of Care APIs released by CMS?

There is opportunity to make API integration more accessible by suppliers and Issuers. Currently, filing work yields significantly more manual labor than should be warranted when working in systems such as the Health Insurance Oversight System (HIOS), Rates and Benefits Information System (RBIS), System for Electronic Rates and Form Filings (SERFF), and all other subsequent modules. Recognizing that in some instances APIs should not be used for certain access datapoints, at ClearFile, we believe this directly will enhance how payers can accelerate the implementation of this is to help participate with the SERFF Modernization committee chaired by the NAIC. We have been working diligently alongside their committees to optimize the front end and back-end API integration points but due to the currently proposed cost, payers have not been quick to fork over dollars. I recommend that we allocate a nominal increase to filing fees to payers to off-set the cost of opening APIs. This could be measured by filing type, number of plans, and I can estimate that there would be hundreds of thousands of hours saved across the 20,000+ users of SERFF from a carrier perspective. Measured return on investment can be financial or non-financial.
 
PA-3. How can CMS encourage payers to accept digital identity credentials (for example, CLEAR, ID.me, Login.gov) from patients and their partners instead of proprietary logins?

HHS may consider the action to evaluate when privacy and security rules are updated to understand where payers are in their legal life cycle. Using the ACA as an example, with our expertise I envision adoption challenges getting payers to accept these credentials for the simple reason that the majority of those members are within 100-500% of FPL (Federal Poverty Level) and may not have ample access to transportation and capabilities to do so, including finances, or access to obtain addition. To streamline the delivery of adoption for members and patients across all demographic circumstances, one recommendation would be to provide members an incentive, transportation or financial assistance, or ultimate reimbursement (savings) to obtain a digital ID, and delegate a standardized supplier to work with members and all plans to ensure consistent logins. We believe that standardization of credentialling is important, as long as it is sustainable for all patients in varying circumstances in their daily lives. 

We thank you for the time spent during your review and appreciate the opportunity to present two comments, and feedback to the broader RFI within our purview. We welcome all opportunities to showcase more breadth of our knowledge and expertise about how we support Health Plan, Issuer, and efficiencies within the industry.
Respectfully,

Joe Boyle
President, ClearFile

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Palantir Technologies Inc. (“Palantir”) is the developer of the Palantir Platform (or “the Platform”). The Platform is a commercial SaaS product with a FedRAMP-High authorization. The Platform has been deployed in support of hundreds of government and commercial customers across the U.S. and international markets. As of our most recent earnings report (PLTR), Palantir supports nearly 770 customers with configurations of the Palantir Platform. It is estimated that Palantir software manages nearly 30% of the hospital beds in the U.S. through our partnerships with customers such as Tampa General Hospital, Mount Sinai Health System, and HCA Healthcare. Our support of U.S. government customers — which began in 2010 — includes HHS operational divisions like NIH, CDC, ACF, ARPA-H, as well as VA. We also have a significant partnership with the UK’s NHS to modernize and centralize a Federated Data Platform in support of hospital operations. 

Since its inception, Palantir has understood that interoperability is a worthwhile effort and a critical challenge. Previous regulation has taken the U.S. healthcare industry closer to enabling data and system interoperability, but the intent of the regulation (e.g., 21st Century Cures Act and subsequent rules) has been challenging to implement and enforce. Palantir, with great effort and technological investment, has demonstrated the value of translating medical record data into valuable outcomes across US healthcare, which reinforces the potential opportunity of improved interoperability. 

Across our healthcare work, from our government work with various HHS OpDivs to our commercial work at health systems, we have witnessed, interrogated, and solved varied but overlapping problems. Broadly, at both the federal- and provider-level, it is difficult for healthcare providers to obtain timely, complete, and quality data that form a full picture of any patient’s health and medical history, as well as the operational context of the care that patient is receiving. Furthermore, our health system partners’ use of the Palantir Platform has proven that driving interoperable health systems with appropriate access to clinical, operational, and financial data can improve the health system’s ability to provide optimal care and equip providers to make better informed decisions. It has also shown significant gaps in the types of data and the significant barriers that slow down or prevent health systems from filling these gaps.

Unique and common learnings from commercial work and government work can help improve data access and interoperability for the U.S. healthcare system writ large. This experience and perspective includes:

• A breadth of Federal health experience that has given us knowledge and expertise in enabling our clients to obtain and harmonize public and private healthcare data from a number of sources. This work has given us insight into the challenges with data integration, how data can be centralized in a privacy preserving manner, and what infrastructure or logic can be reused to do so, as well as how to harmonize data from myriad, disparate sources into a standard data model.

• A breadth of commercial health experience supporting health systems in capacity management, discharge planning, clinician staffing and scheduling, revenue cycle, clinical research, and other areas.

• Both our federal and commercial health work has given us experience harmonizing data from many different sources to drive interoperability, creating a translational layer on top of the raw data that promotes intelligibility and efficacy and enables the use of accurate, timely data in analyses and operational applications. 

These combined learnings — what data is most useful for treatment and healthcare operations; where this data has gaps and how they can be filled; ways to streamline the integration of this data; and ways to improve data quality and interoperability — can be combined to help improve technical solutions for patients, providers, and payers. 

In our response to CMS’ RFI questions related to a modern Health Technology Ecosystem, we explicate challenges and advocate for solutions related to:

• The healthcare / health system data that is valuable but hard to access (for patient treatment, for claims processing, and for government institutions) and the changes required to improve access and interoperability. 
• The opportunities and challenges that exist in our current systems and policies, and the steps required to improve accessibility and interoperability of clinical data from various sources.
• The technology and policy needed to enable and encourage providers to utilize digital health applications and make quality data (including from the EHR) available for exchange, including:
   o Changes to data standards and reporting practices.
   o Policy changes including limiting information blocking.

ENFORCE.

My overall message to HHS is that this entire exercise will be a waste of breath and energy unless you ENFORCE regulations.  

Hospitals have strong commercial incentives not to make it easy for patients to take their business elsewhere, so it’s no surprise that hospitals do not commonly make it easy to download your case information and go elsewhere. (By far the greatest attention I’ve ever had on LinkedIn was when I did exactly that - downloaded my data and took my business elsewhere. https://www.linkedin.com/posts/epatientdave_patientautonomy-medicalrecords-patientcentric-activity-7026611151106908160-eaXr/ )

A related issue is that interop requires real work, so managers who are under financial pressure are motivated to resist doing that work. I understand this. But "It's too haaarrrrd" is not a morally acceptable reason to hold back on improving people's health.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As a digital health policy expert and parent to three children—including two sons with very different rare diseases—I bring a dual perspective to this comment. I have navigated the health system professionally and personally, and I’ve seen firsthand both the possibilities and failures of our current digital infrastructure. I urge CMS to lead the creation of a health technology ecosystem that centers patients and caregivers—not just as data subjects, but as active participants and contributors to healthcare outcomes.

I. Prioritize Enforcement through the National Provider Directory

To achieve true interoperability, we must go beyond enablement and prioritize enforcement. The National Provider Directory (NPD) is essential to this. A verified, centralized listing of FHIR API endpoints will make compliance auditable. Without it, we have no technical or policy mechanism to ensure providers meet existing mandates. At the June 3 ONC/ASTP Listening Session, I emphasized that enforcement is the true incentive. If a provider cannot be digitally reached, the system fails. CMS must treat the NPD not as infrastructure, but as accountability infrastructure.

II. Empower Consumers with Full EHI Access and Patient-Facing APIs

Patients are the only consistent node across fragmented systems. I’ve spent years manually collecting my children’s records from different hospitals, only to find that I still don’t have their full longitudinal history. We need functional, enforceable APIs that support full EHI export—far beyond USCDI elements. FHIR-based APIs must be the backbone of patient-mediated data aggregation, enabling consumers to manage and share their own comprehensive records.

III. Large Language Models Can Level the Playing Field

Even with data access, patients often face a wall of clinical jargon. LLMs like GPT-4 and Med-PaLM can interpret and summarize health records, allowing families like mine to prepare better questions, identify red flags, and collaborate meaningfully with clinicians. These tools are not optional; they are essential educational scaffolds that help balance the information asymmetry between patients and providers. They transform education from a one-time pamphlet into a continuous, contextual experience.

IV. Make Proxy Access a Non-Negotiable Requirement

Our infrastructure must reflect the reality that caregivers are often the most active health data users. I manage care for a non-verbal toddler with complex medical needs and a neurodivergent five-year-old with a rare blood disorder. Yet too often, I’m treated as a bystander because interoperability frameworks don’t account for proxies. Without caregiver inclusion, we’re designing a system for theoretical patients—not real families. Proxy access must be a baseline, not a feature.

V. Rare Disease Communities Are Not Edge Cases—We’re the Front Lines

Rare disease families like mine are already aggregating records, enrolling in registries, and using digital tools out of necessity. We are early adopters not because it’s easy, but because we have no other choice. CMS should pilot interoperability and AI initiatives within rare disease communities. We offer immediate, motivated feedback and can validate use cases under real-world pressure. If a digital tool works for us, it will likely work for broader populations, too.

VI. Recommendations

1. Require full EHI Export APIs and support patient-controlled data aggregation.

2. Fund and complete the National Provider Directory and tie participation to program compliance.

3. Ensure caregiver and proxy access are embedded in all interoperability rules and implementations.

4. Incentivize LLM integration into certified health apps to support ongoing patient education.

5. Expand TEFCA and bulk FHIR APIs to include consumer apps as nodes in the research ecosystem.

6. Use rare disease communities as early adopters to stress-test patient-centric infrastructure.

7. Enforce information blocking penalties where data access is impeded, especially across systems.

8. Prioritize full longitudinal health records, including narrative, genomic, and wearable data, not just structured elements.

Closing

This consumer-led transformation is not a trend—it’s an inevitable evolution. People are increasingly prepared to take ownership of their health outcomes. CMS has an opportunity to accelerate this trajectory by giving patients the tools and authority to act. I know this because I’ve lived it. I’ve had to build what the system failed to provide. I’ve watched algorithms explain what physicians overlooked. And I’ve learned that the future of healthcare depends on whether we recognize patients and caregivers as integral—not peripheral—to its success.

Respectfully,
James Cummings
Parent Advocate and Health IT Policy Expert
Participatory Health

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Establish openEHR-based pilots, leveraging SNOMED CT, as foundational data architecture for long-term interoperability.

To improve data quality, reduce vendor lock-in, and enable longitudinal care, CMS should fund pilot projects using openEHR as the persistence layer underneath HL7 FHIR-based exchange. openEHR’s archetype-based modeling enables semantically robust, clinician-driven structured data, and when combined with SNOMED CT for clinical terminology, it supports high-quality analytics, decision support, and AI readiness. This approach enables precise, computable care documentation and pathways. Paired with FHIR APIs for interoperability, openEHR and SNOMED CT together form a vendor-neutral, patient-centric clinical data infrastructure aligned with TEFCA, USCDI+, and Medicare’s quality and value-based care programs. CMS could partner with NLM, ONC, and NIH to evaluate this model through multi-institutional pilots that advance standards-based healthcare transformation.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
To: Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)
From: HiLabs, Inc.
Date: June 16, 2025

We thank CMS for the opportunity to submit public comments on their Health Technology Ecosystem Request for Information. CMS, as the nation's largest payer and regulatory authority, holds a unique and critical position to significantly enhance the healthcare experience for millions of patients and their caregivers. By strategically operationalizing foundational workflows and embracing the transformative potential of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology, specifically leveraging advanced AI models, CMS can ensure high-quality data, streamline operations, and foster true interoperability across the healthcare ecosystem. This response emphasizes how sophisticated AI, in synergy with existing and proposed CMS initiatives, can directly empower all stakeholders across the healthcare ecosystem: 1) patients and caregivers, 2) providers, 3) technology vendors, 4) payers, and 5) value-based care organizations in their daily health management and care coordination efforts, leading to improved access, transparency, and outcomes.

The opportunity to leverage advanced AI models, including agents, LLMs, VLMs, and sophisticated ML and NLP techniques, to fundamentally transform healthcare for all stakeholders is immense. By proactively addressing data fragmentation, championing interoperability, and establishing robust AI governance, CMS can cultivate an environment where individuals are empowered with actionable health information, enabling them to make informed decisions, coordinate care effectively, and ultimately achieve better health outcomes. This proactive approach will not only enhance the patient and caregiver experience but also drive greater efficiency and equity throughout the entire healthcare system.

HiLabs as a healthcare technology vendor can support CMS’s efforts in ensuring greater care efficiency and equity through our MCheck Provider Product Suite and MCheck Clinical Product Suite. The former offers a comprehensive Provider Network Lifecycle Management solution, whereas the latter offers a complete  Clinical Data Management solution. Both have been proven through partnerships with national and regional health plans across all 50 states and lines of business (Medicare, Medicaid, and Commercial). Our technology, regulatory expertise, and client collaboration automate upstream processes (e.g., roster ingestion and clinical file ingestion) to improve and enable downstream operations, including by resolving inaccurate provider data across 260+ elements and processing ~3.6B clinical records.

Our Provider Data Accuracy solution is based on our proprietary AI algorithm (R3: Reliability, Relevance, Recency), featured in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) article which was also mentioned in the June 2024 Medicare Payment Advisory Commission’s (MedPAC) report to Congress. This algorithm scores record confidence from thousands of sources, achieving 90%+ accuracy for trusted automation, well above the 52% industry average. HiLabs' NetworkIQ Module provides advanced network coverage calculation and high-performing provider identification. Our market-leading Roster Automation Module delivers a true end-to-end processing experience. Our Contracts AI solution automates provider contract configuration for claims pricing and supports compliance monitoring through AI-driven contextual reasoning of contractual outcomes, contract language comparison, across both fee-for-service (FFS) and Value-Based Care agreements. It also enables contract standardization, change management, longitudinal analysis and generates compliance report aligned with PADU and other regulatory frameworks. In short, our MCheck Provider solutions ensure compliance, significantly reduce regulatory risk and improve patient access. 

Our MCheck Clinical is an AI-powered data harmonization solution that revolutionizes healthcare data through automating the classification and transformation of clinical files (i.e. Excel, CSV, CCDA, etc.) with 90% accuracy and accelerating external data onboarding. For example, our SmartOCR solution extracts unstructured data from medical charts twice as fast as traditional tools with high precision, even when the clinical terms are abbreviated or aliased. CodEx, our AI-powered clinical code extractor, significantly increases throughput and improves coding accuracy from 91% to 99%. Finally, our Term Mapping Engine standardizes clinical terms into vocabularies like ICD-10, SNOMED, and LOINC, creating clean, interoperable datasets for enhanced research, analytics, and care coordination.

HiLabs’ integrated data management approach, spanning both provider and clinical data, delivers an unparalleled, comprehensive perspective across the healthcare ecosystem. This singular advantage fosters enhanced care delivery and equitable outcomes for every participant, from patients to healthcare organizations and insurers.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
While there have been impressive strides made with improving interoperability standards with the growing adoption of FHIR, bolstered by TEFCA, my concern is that these pushes for interoperability don't address an essential need we have to improve health literacy.  HHS published a report 6 years ago which found 88% of Americans have low health literacy. This negatively impacts quality of life and health outcomes. We have more data but we don't know what to do with it.

While the trusted relationship between doctor and patient is sacred, there are opportunities for technology to alleviate existing pain points. There is better health data transparency with the passing of the Information Blocking, however,  patients often receive results before their care team has reviewed. To try to understand results before the conversation with their physician, patients may instead go to resources that are not evidenced-based. 

Instead, we should be doing more with the data to help patients and their care giver /loved ones facilitate higher impact conversations with their clinical team.

Digital products could help patients navigate conversations on test results  
Understand how these results measure against “normal” in the literature
Understand the baseline/normal for the patient,  based on historical values, with helpful trends reports 
Be available in the patients preferred language 

Digital tools could offer the patient the ability to document and ask questions,  ahead of the conversation with their physician.

A personal assistant tool could also help here, clarifying results using factual resources, helping patients with care navigation (finding available clinicians, scheduling appts, and transportation to health facilities), and support price transparency (understanding estimated costs based on insurance coverage status). Patients could be better informed decisions and have more fruitful discussions with their doctor.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1. What health management or care navigation apps would help you understand and manage your (or your loved ones) health needs, as well as the actions you should take?

There are few clear, simple ways to understand available Medicare benefits, nor guidance on how certain benefits may improve outcomes rather than cycling through more expensive benefits (for example SNF utilization vs home health utilization). 

When Medicare benefits are difficult to understand, usage is driven by emergency, ignorance, lack of support and guidance, rather than preventative interventions which could reduce hospitalization and other significant health costs. 
When caregivers are included in access to Medicare benefits information, they can help Medicare beneficiaries access lower-cost benefits and prevent high-cost future interventions. 

This also applies to providers. Providers can benefit from not only access to patient data, but also direction on use of Medicare benefits to reduce costs. For example, understanding eligibility requirements for home health, tied to correct timing of a home health intervention, could significantly reduce utilization volume and cost while managing disease and outcomes, especially for chronic complex patients. 

RubyWell’s data models are designed to do just this - interpret patient data - both self-reported, claims, and EHR data - to predict the need for home health as a cost-reduction strategy, and to guide physicians in making these referrals, taking into consideration the eligibility criteria for home health compared to other more expensive interventions. We also work with family caregivers to professionalize them as healthworkers to support care delivery as a member of a home-based care team.  

PC-2. Do you have easy access to your own and all your loved ones' health information in one location (for example, in a single patient portal or another software system)?

Were there particular data types, such as x-rays or specific test results, that were unavailable? What are the obstacles to accessing your own or your loved ones' complete health information electronically and using it for managing health conditions or finding the best care (for example, limitations in functionality, user friendliness, or access to basic technology infrastructure)?

One of the most critical limitations with regards to claims data is the significant lag in reporting. This is true for both BlueButton 2.0 and EHR aggregators. Until claims data is able to be reflected in real time (even if classified as submitted/paid/denied), there are significant blind spots for all members of a care team in using the data reliably, from diagnoses, to testing, to treatment, particularly when a patient moves from one provider to another. The claims data reporting lag can be from weeks to months, meaning at any given time the patient’s health record is incomplete, ensuring that it cannot be viewed as a single source of truth for the patient’s condition at any given moment in time. 

RubyWell depends on a combination of self-reported data/conditions/symptoms, caregiver-reported data, and claims data to create a more accurate and up-to-date profile of the Medicare beneficiary at any time, that can be validated by the patient’s physician, and can fill in any gaps in the claims data. This type of health record is intended to provide the caregiver with an understanding of benefits that could most effectively address the Medicare beneficiary’s needs, provide pathways to in-home care (as appropriate), with a focus on cost-reduction and overall system utilization.

PC-4. What features are missing from apps you use or that you are aware of today?

RubyWell manually aggregates information on provider network adequacy and quality metrics, built from both CMS databases and individual provider outreach given the paucity of data publicly available about the vast majority of home health providers. Having this data in a more accurate and up-to-date database, that includes STAR Ratings, would be invaluable. 

Bulk data capabilities for population health insights (again, something we are building internally for our population from our own data) and social determinants of health data integration into claims data would both provide significant value to both developers and the quality of information available to users. 

b. What set of workflows do you believe CMS is uniquely positioned to offer?

1) Provider network adequacy and quality metrics
2) Bulk data capabilities for population health insights
3) Social determinants of health data integration into claims data.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-5. What can CMS and its partners do to encourage patient and caregiver interest in these digital health products?

RubyWell is committed to engaging family members, training them as Medicare-certified healthworkers, and placing them at the center of the Medicare beneficiary’s care team.  This, coupled with our technology, is intended to significantly reduce 90-day hospital readmission rates and drive decline in emergency room usage. 

Effective use of data to tell a useful story that caregivers can use to guide care, contextualizing available benefits in the context of care at home, and predicting the timely intervention for home health services can reduce Medicare spend by 25-59% on medically comparable patients. Families and providers use our tools to make care-based decisions that are best for their loved ones and that reduce overall Medicare spend. 

Central to our offering is the combination of data that tells a story AND access to training and paid work - engaging caregivers as healthworkers, in a professionalized environment with appropriate supervision and care plan guidance, is central to improving outcomes, addressing the care crisis, and building capability for care in the home. 

PC-6. What features are most important to make digital health products accessible and easy to use for Medicare beneficiaries and caregivers, particularly those with limited prior experience using digital tools and services?

The caregiving market to-date has focused on building apps that require digital competency to download, that connect payment methods or digital wallets, require the user to type in information, to invite friends/physicians, to track medications, etc. 

It is critical to meet users where they are, especially those in rural areas, or with poor online access. RubyWell’s technology centers on voice enablement, increased real-time interaction with existing hardware solutions (either in the home or wearable), surveys and questionnaires completed online or in dialogue with support (by phone), and peer-to-peer community-building. Data that RubyWell collects, analyzes, and interprets is available to users via a secure portal.

PC-8. In your experience, what health data is readily available and valuable to patients or their caregivers or both?

a. What data is valuable, but hard for patients and caregivers, or app developers and other technical vendors, to access for appropriate and valuable use (for example, claims data, clinical data, encounter notes, operative reports, appointment schedules, prices)?

Access to claims data via Blue Button 2.0 can be burdensome for both beneficiaries and caregivers, and as described above, the data is rarely current, limiting its application. 

Also, navigating PHI and HIPAA between caregivers and beneficiaries requires each entity to develop its own solution to permissions for access; there appears to be little appetite to solve the data-sharing problem between beneficiaries and caregivers at its source because of privacy and HIPAA concerns. However, millions of beneficiaries,  can’t access their data without the support of a friend or family member. 

This is also true of real-time EHR data, which can be invaluable in predicting care. RubyWell helps beneficiaries and caregivers access this data by scheduling a call with a person for support, or by following instructions on a video. 

This is an area where permissions efficiency for CMS-approved partners would be highly valuable. This may include different data views depending on what person or entity is accessing the data. 

PC-9. Given that the Blue Button 2.0 API only includes basic patient demographic, Medicare coverage, and claims data (Part A, B, D), what additional CMS data sources do developers view as most valuable for inclusion in the API to enable more useful digital products for patients and caretakers?

While interoperability for Medicare Advantage plans may be required, because there is no central repository available to beneficiaries and their healthcare partners, as with BB 2.0, access to that claims data is an extremely burdensome task and can exclude beneficiaries from services because of the very large number of integrations that would be required to access data for patients, where, in any given state there may be many plans. Having a central repository for all claims data that includes Part C (BB 3.0?) would be invaluable to service providers that serve both FFS and MA Medicare beneficiaries.

c. Is there non-CMS data that should be included in the API?

Medicare Advantage claims data.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PR-1. What can CMS and its partners do to encourage providers, including those in rural areas, to leverage approved (see description in PC-5) digital health products for their patients?

It is critical to meet users where they are, especially those in rural areas, or with poor online access. RubyWell’s technology centers on voice enablement, increased real-time interaction with existing hardware solutions, surveys and questionnaires completed online or in dialogue with support (by phone), and peer-to-peer community-building. Data that RubyWell collects, analyses, and interprets is available to users via a secure portal.

In addition to voice enablement technology, we believe that leaning into simple, existing technologies - for example, texting, since messages can be sent with very little connectivity - are central to good communication between care teams and families.  

All that said, the most important pathway to adoption is aligned incentives with the needs of the providers in remote areas. Solutions should address their pain points - reaching far-flung patients, communicating with care teams in real time while they are scattered over a large geographic area, low-connectivity solutions - and they should be rewarded for tech adoption that improves outcomes and creates efficiencies.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: CMS, ASTP/ONC, and NLM should establish a formal collaborative agreement with OHDSI to leverage its standardized OMOP Common Data Model, open-source analytic tools, and extensive research network. Integrating OHDSI’s capabilities into TEFCA would enhance nationwide data interoperability, enable robust large-scale observational research, and improve evidence generation to support public health decision-making and policy development.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: OMIM, curated by Johns Hopkins, offers the gold-standard resource for gene-disease relationships, enabling clinical decision support and structured diagnosis of Mendelian conditions. HPO provides a standardized, computable vocabulary for phenotypic abnormalities, making deep phenotyping possible across institutions and critical for rare disease detection. GA4GH, on the other hand, delivers the secure, global interoperability frameworks—like Phenopackets, Passports, and Beacon—that allow genotype and phenotype data to be shared responsibly across networks. If CMS, ASTP/ONC, and NLM were to establish collaborative agreements with each of these groups and integrate their assets into TEFCA, it would unlock a future where structured genomics, phenotypic data, and diagnostic knowledge flow seamlessly between providers, researchers, and public health systems. That level of interoperability would not just solve long-standing challenges—it would fundamentally reshape how we diagnose, treat, and study disease.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: If TEFCA were to integrate OMIM, HPO, and GA4GH through formal collaborations with Johns Hopkins Medicine, the Monarch Initiative, and GA4GH leadership, it would mark a historic milestone in biomedical interoperability. OMIM offers the most trusted source for gene-disease relationships, HPO provides a globally adopted ontology for phenotypic abnormalities, and GA4GH delivers secure, internationally recognized APIs and data-sharing frameworks. The convergence of these standards into a trusted national exchange infrastructure would enable structured genotype–phenotype data exchange across QHINs, empowering rare disease diagnosis, clinical decision support, research, and public health analytics. This is the kind of architecture the global bioinformatics community has long hoped for—where data is not only interoperable, but semantically rich, clinically relevant, and equitably accessible. Achieving this would not just make technical progress—it would fulfill the ethical promise of precision medicine.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
As the leading value-based care (VBC) enablement platform, Reveleer unifies retrieval, clinical intelligence, risk adjustment, quality improvement, and member management into a single, AI-powered system. Our experience working with health plans and provider organizations nationwide gives us a unique perspective on the challenges and opportunities in advancing health data interoperability, digital health innovation, and value-based care transformation.

Our Recommendation to CMS
Mandate and incentivize open, standards-based APIs to provide comprehensive, real-time access to all permissible structured, semi-structured, and unstructured patient data across the healthcare continuum. Data is the fuel that powers modern information technology. Aligning all participants to transmit and receive clean, accurate data will ensure that the patient and member can feel confident that their experience with healthcare is accurate, personalized, and dependable—regardless of which part of the ecosystem they engage with to seek the care or clarity they need. Establishing a solid foundation of data for all parties will allow stakeholders to adopt value-based care models more effectively and quantifiably. This alignment will also facilitate the optimization or elimination of administrative processes, expedite the integration of advanced digital health and healthcare technology solutions, and enhance the quality of care for patients and members within the US healthcare system.

Key Points Supporting Our Recommendation
Unified Data Access
Patients, providers, and VBC organizations need to be able to access and contribute to a single, longitudinal view of health data including claims, clinical, and operational data to effectively serve the health care user with the most accurate and reliable guidance. Currently, data silos and inconsistent API standards create inefficiencies at scale as stakeholders seek to bring accurate information to the right stage in the healthcare workflow that ultimately hinders value-based care delivery and outcomes.
AI-Driven Insights and Automation
Reveleer’s platform demonstrates how OCR, NLP, Data Science and advanced AI solutions including GenAI can extract actionable intelligence from both structured and unstructured data, dramatically improving coding accuracy, gap closure, and workflow efficiency. Deployed at various stages in the VBC continuum, AI can be used to predict care to guide high value patient interactions at the point of care and be used to accurately and automatically verify the care received to ensure the most appropriate reimbursement. While we have proven and continue to advance these capabilities through an ever-modernizing AI landscape, broadly available standardized data access would be a massive accelerant for these capabilities as it would significantly reduce hallucinations and errors that emerge from conflict.
Reducing Administrative Burden from Providers and Payers
There are several inefficiencies that create work and abrasion for payers and providers alike in the value-based care world. Automating data acquisition, retrieval, and reconciliation through standard pipelines while embedding clinical quality APIs into existing EHR workflows can reduce manual effort and administrative overhead, freeing teams to focus on patient care and key outcomes. Many leading health plans and providers today use Reveleer’s state-of-the-art data acquisition technology, chart retrieval, and reconciliation processes to ensure the right and most accurate data is captured to support these workflows. 
Enabling Patient-Centric Innovation
At the end of the day, healthcare is about making sure people can be as healthy as possible in an economically viable healthcare system. Open, standardized APIs will foster a vibrant ecosystem of digital health products that empower patients and caregivers with timely, holistic access to their health information, supporting informed decision-making and improved health management.
Strengthening Compliance and Transparency
Standardized, API-driven data exchange ensures regulatory compliance, supports accurate reimbursement, and builds trust through transparent, auditable processes.
Suggested Actionable Steps for CMS
•	Require all certified health IT products to support comprehensive, FHIR-based APIs — including whole-chart and unstructured data access.
•	Incentivize adoption of open standards by linking them to reimbursement, certification, and quality program participation.
•	Strengthen enforcement against information blocking by clarifying and tightening requirements for API responsiveness, data completeness, and usability.
By prioritizing open, comprehensive data access and interoperability, CMS will lay the groundwork for a truly patient-centric, efficient, and innovative healthcare system — one that delivers on the promise of value-based care for all Medicare beneficiaries.

Our comments apply to both health plans and providers.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Comment on RFI CMS-0042-NC
By Mark Kapengut. Mark18spring@gmail.com

This proposal represents significant betrayal of Robert F Kennedy MAHA and health freedom voters. Many objectives as presented are pointing in the wrong direction. CMS and HHS should go back to the drawing board. 

Our voters are very picky in their choices of applications they may use. They place extra value on individual health choice and control of their data. Attempts on one-size-fits-all solutions wouldn’t work for our people, whether VBC models or single PHI data location. 

PC-1a. 
This objective is undesirable. Patients PHI should not be exchanged without explicit patients consent. Everyone should be able to know everyone who may have access to my PHI. I would like to be able to ascertain that control, which is now missing. To that event, every entity in possession of PHI must be required to report to the person whose data it is their status on an annual basis. A patient should have ability to withdraw consent and assured deletion of such records. 

PC-2. 
There is little to no value of having all my PHI data in a single online location. I would like to be able to download all data about myself on a USB and share it with other providers in a way that ensures my control. 

PC-4. 
Pricing information is currently missing or is hard to obtain. If would also be helpful for HHS to facilitate a provider review and rating system, similar to yelp or healthgrades. The benefit of such USG service would be in scale.  

PC5. 
CMS should not put a finger on this scale and force this direction, and let market adopt solutions with proven value.

PC-11
Wrong objective. I prefer to exclude my information from HIE. In the rare events when I need outside care, the siloed level of access to PHI has proved sufficient to support adequate care.   

PC-12. 
We encourage CMS and HHS to loosen EHR requirements. Costs of EHR has proven to induce provider consolidation, reduced competition and healthcare availability. 

PC-14a. 
Wrong objective. There is no need for patients to use centralized identity credentials. It provides merely marginal benefit, and a major inconvenience when something in the digital credentialing chain doesn’t work right on the back end, and it’s very difficult to trace and fix. 

PR-3
Wrong objective. We encourage CMS and HHS instead to loosen EHR requirements and expanding paper records. Costs of EHR has proven to induce provider consolidation, reduced competition and healthcare availability. 

PR-10. 
Wrong objective. Adoption of DigitalID is contrary to views of most MAGA and MAHA voters. 

PR-10b. TD-2
Use of DIC would reduce access to healthcare of many of us, because patient would be reluctant to use them. 

PR-12. 
Wrong objective. Blocking of patient information protects them. HHS should not enforce any anti-blocking provisions beyond required and expand rather than limit the exceptions.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1 a. An AI-generated Plain Language description summarizing the patient's problem list, including a description of the treatment plan, patient compliance, and prognosis.

PC-2 Yes (KP portal)

PC-2 a. Quick review of lab and imaging results.

PC-2 b. c. For many people, like my mother, the sign-in and password protections can be difficult and frustrating to manage. For her, a phone call to request a printed version sent to her email would be much more accessible.

PC-4 b. see PC-1 a.

PC-7 Polling random potential end users.

PC-8 Lab data.

PC-8 a., b. estimated cost data
    
PC-9 c. range of cost within care setting region

PC-10 g. Direct patient access via certified EHR FHIR APIs 

PC-14 a. "Password/login fatigue", poor past experiences with digital logins, Poor Patient UX, especially for elderly patients, Concerns about government tracking digital footprint.

PA-5. 1. Limit the measures to a fixed number and Adopt a promotion and relegation system. Periodically evaluate the net impact on patient outcomes for each measure and relegate the bottom performer(s) before promoting a new measure(s).

TD-4: Open standards-based APIs need to be as polished, reliable, and well-supported as proprietary software; otherwise, they will always remain niche products. Therefore, ONC should focus on these aspects, recognizing the costs and how they would be maintained.

TD-5 Its value will need to be weighed against other priorities. To fully realize its benefits, a nationwide provider directory must be publicly available and free of charge to maximize its utility and adoption. However, since the taxpayer would bear the cost, offsetting cuts would need to be made to avoid adding to the nation's staggering debt.

TD-6 a. Direct patient access via certified EHR FHIR APIs 

TD-7 As the lead editor of US Core over 10 years, I am in a unique position to comment on the evolution of USCDI. Its initial set of core elements (CCDA) provided a solid foundation for exchanging data and represented data that systems captured. Subsequently, the process for expanding USCDI has increasingly prioritized policy over whether health information systems capture a data element, and whether its exchange has been empirically proven to benefit patient care. As a result, the USCDI data elements are underdefined and require interpretation at the specification level. Therefore, it has been a challenge to create technical specifications that meet both the regulatory intent and industry needs. For example, we developed a general framework for assessments to meet multiple overlapping USCDI Health Status Assessments Data elements. In my opinion, it would  have been simpler and more interoperable to enumerate a list of 10-20 commonly used observations.

I recommend:

1. Thoroughly document the ASTP Evaluation criteria for each new data element following the documented USCDI ONDEC criteria before promoting a new data element.
2. Adopt a promotion and relegation system. Periodic evaluation of the net impact on patient care for each data class/ element and relegate the bottom performer(s).
3. Consider explicit capture (in addition to exchange) requirements for USCDI elements.

TD-7 a,b,c. see above

TD-7 d. yes.

TD-9 c. US Core already addresses this via its clinical notes section.

Other:  Eliminate remaining COVID-19 reporting requirements

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Data Access and Integration

Clinical data (including diagnosis and prescriptions), encounter data and appointment schedules from health systems and PCPs are incredibly difficult to access in a timely fashion. HIE integration takes over 3 months and are constrained by the engineering capacity of the HIE providers, making it hard for startups to move quickly. The current process to get latest diagnoses and medication lists from a patient’s care team involves faxing back and forth multiple HIPAA release forms, calling to request efaxing of lists, following up when faxing falls through the crack (unreliable means of communication), emailing physicians to confirm whether the medication list and lab results are up to date.

Also would be valuable to have pricing data of non-clinical providers, which often takes up a bigger share of a Medicare patient’s care cost. For example, right now it takes ~20 calls to find an affordable home care provider for a patient because pricing isn’t transparent.


HIE

HIE integration timelines are long (12+weeks) and are constrained by the engineering team capacity of the HIE providers.  We would recommend turning it into an open API endpoint that allows technology developers to integrate with in a self-service way (with HIPAA compliance guardrail). 


Operational Use Cases for Patients and Caregivers to eliminate barrier

Patients need an easier way to book with and review quality metrics on non-clinical providers (e.g. homecare, in-home physical therapy, in-home mental health visits). This can be unlocked via a centralized non-clinical provider database including insurance coverage, pricing, availability. There is an increasing effort to increase interoperability of these data for clinical providers, but a huge gap in usable data in the non-clinical space. If we want to shift more patients to age in place and in community, we have to build a more interoperable database for providers caring for patients in community, to make “finding me an in home physical therapist for zip code 10001 that takes Original Medicare” a click of a button vs 20 phone calls.


Encouraging Digital Health Apps via tech-first payment models

Tech products are often paid by usage or engagement, which is slightly different from the current healthcare payment model. We advocate for a more flexible, tech-forward payment models that are based on user engagement or usage, or efficiency metric (e.g. time to appts), or based on tasks completed (e.g. $0.01 per appt scheduled). FFS is too expensive in a world where technology can automate lots of the repetitive, low-complexity human labor such as care coordination; and current value-based arrangements are too complex and costly for payers to calculate.
This will stimulate developer interest in building digital health products that actually successfully engage patients in areas that save costs for CMS, such as medication adherence, but are hard to measure payments under traditional VBC model.


Technical Standards and Certification

Given the development of LLM technology, we as developers are interested in easier data access and coverage even if it means more unstructured data.
