Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1. What health management or care navigation apps would help you understand and manage your (or your loved ones) health needs, as well as the actions you should take?
I would like to manage my health records with an app that would allow me to store all of my records in a decentralized system so that I can access all of my records through a secure software or hardware wallet and grant or deny access to any part of my records by providers, payers, researchers, and public health authorities. I would like it to give me the ability to withdraw previously granted access to all or part of my records at any time. I would like the process of granting and withdrawing access to be seamlessly integrated with provider EHRs, so that when I grant access to all or part of my records, they will be accessible through the provider’s EHR. I would also like to be able to delete my records that have been stored in the decentralized cloud. 

I would like the ability to select data sets from my health records by type and application. For example, I would like to be able to select and share all data relevant to cancer screening or cardiovascular health but select and exclude or delete all social determinants of health data in my records. I would like to be able to grant providers the ability to upload data such as notes, test results, diagnoses, prescriptions, etc. to my health records but only access them if I grant access via my digital wallet. 

PC-4. What features are missing from apps you use or that you are aware of today?
The ability to control access to my medical records and consumer health data not through consent forms but through a granular level of built-in controls and the ability change the status of access or delete stored information. 
a. What apps should exist but do not yet? Why do you believe they do not exist yet?
An app that finds all health-related data about me that has been collected, stored, shared, sold, or used by online entities and data brokers, and then allows me to acquire rights to the data at no cost or have the data deleted.
Digital wallets that offer individuals full, granular control over storage of and access to their own personal health information.

PC-8c. What specific opportunities and challenges exist to improve accessibility, interoperability and integration of clinical data from different sources to enable more meaningful clinical research and generation of actionable evidence?
The ability for individuals to own and control access to their own health data, and receive financial incentives for its use.

PC-11. How are health information exchanges (HIEs) currently helping to advance patient access to health information in the real world?
b. What changes would you suggest?
Give individuals granular control over their health data stored by HIEs, instead of all-or-nothing consent forms for data sharing, including the right to remove some or all data from the HIE. Revise the HIPAA privacy rule exception for public health authorities so that individuals can withdraw their personal health information from being accessible to the government via HIEs without their knowledge or consent. 

PC-14. Regarding digital identity credentials (for example, CLEAR, Login.gov, ID.me, other NIST 800-63-3 IAL2/AAL2 credentialing service providers (CSP)):
a. What are the challenges today in getting patients/caregivers to sign up and use digital identity credentials?
Use of digital identity credentials for access to health information should be optional. Neither digital ID nor biometric forms of identification should be required for access to medical records or care.
b. What could be the benefits to patients/caregivers if digital identity credentials were more widely used?
c. What are the potential downsides?
The privacy and security risks of linking an individual’s personal health information to an unchangeable identity credential are obvious. Requiring use of digital IDs for access to medical records and care also opens the door to misuse of personal health information outside of the realm of healthcare, such as in the case of personal-information-related requirements being inappropriately issued by public or private authorities and enforced by linking digital IDs to relevant health records.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Xealth appreciates and is grateful for the opportunity to respond to CMS’ RFI for Health Technology Ecosystem (CMS-0042-NC). We are feel that as an organization with over two dozen health system customers, ranging from large Integrated Delivery Networks (IDNs) and academic medical centers to regional health systems, we have an unique perspective on how patients interact with digital health tools, gain or are restricted of access to tools, and how health systems, vendors, and health plans can work together to drive a healthier America. 

Xealth Digital Care enables the automation and streamlining of the ordering, delivery, and monitoring of a health system’s digital health apps, content, products, and services across their organization. Xealth is the driving force behind digital health programs at many of the nation’s largest health systems, bringing digital health vendors, programs, therapeutics and tools into clinical and patient workflow. When combined with Xealth’s custom data and analytics, health systems can track, analyze and evaluate everything through their digital health integration platform. To date, Xealth has sent more than 25 million digital assets and tools to over 6 million patients across many of the largest U.S. health systems. 

Xealth’s comments are based on its expertise as related to the healthcare technology space, specifically with how digital health apps and tools can benefit patients, clinicians, and health systems. With this perspective, Xealth has addressed a subset of the questions, as attached.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
PC-1 

For me, apps that would be useful are those that would note health problems (not just collect lots of data) by analyzing information and providing a notification to take a specific action, go to a specific provider, or send a notice to my doctor.  The app need to recognize important data and where to get it, not me.  For example, getting my "Blue Button 2" data does not provide me much guidance on what needs to be done.  Providers or care teams should get the alerts.

PC-5

CMS should be working with data vendors by publishing use cases and functions that a good digital health product should have, then allow the vendors to submit that app for some sort of certfication that it meets specific use cases.  The vendors can then advertise that their app takes care of the use cases.  CMS could publish the use cases and list apps that meet them.  This would allow patients to select the apps that are most appropriate for them, their caregivers, and their providers.

PC-12

Most of the examples given are for basic adminstrative functions, which are nice but not necessarily very different or valuable.  Apps should handle use cases for specific diseases, provide patient and or provider alerts for significant issues, and assist patients with their individual care plans (pill reminders, therapy exercises, individual diet suggestions.)

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Public Comment on Health Technology and Care Coordination
Submitted by: Kristy Shell, RN, BCPA
Founder, Haven Healthcare Advocates

As a registered nurse, board-certified patient advocate, and professional care manager with over 20 years of experience, I work directly with individuals and families to help them understand their healthcare and navigate a fragmented system. Despite the original promise that electronic health records (EHRs) would make healthcare more cohesive, organized, and efficient, the current reality is far from that vision.

Health technology—particularly EHR systems—needs to better support the coordination of care across providers, systems, and geographies. I respectfully submit the following concerns and recommendations based on my experience in clinical and advocacy roles:

Lack of Interoperability:
Patients’ health information is routinely scattered across multiple portals tied to different health systems. These portals do not communicate with one another, which creates silos that hinder providers from seeing the full picture. This fragmentation often leads to delays in care, duplicated testing, and increased risk of medical error.

Barriers to Caregiver Access:
Family caregivers and professional advocates frequently encounter challenges accessing patient portals. Even when patients willingly share log-in credentials—something they should not have to do—dual authentication and security barriers make consistent access difficult or impossible. A more flexible, caregiver-inclusive access model is urgently needed.

Information Gets Lost in the Gaps:
When data is spread out across systems without integration, it becomes nearly impossible to "connect the dots." Critical information such as medication changes, new diagnoses, or test results can easily fall through the cracks, especially during transitions of care.

Lack of Portability for Mobile Populations:
I serve many clients in Florida who split their time between states. Snowbirds, for example, often see specialists in both regions. Continuity of care suffers when providers in different states can’t access each other's records, and patients must act as the go-between with incomplete or outdated information.

Dispersed Families, Disconnected Systems:
In today’s world, families are geographically spread out. Adult children may live across the country—or even the globe—from their aging parents. Coordinating care becomes exponentially harder when health records are locked in non-communicative systems, leaving caregivers without access to timely, accurate information.

Recommendations:

Accelerate efforts to ensure EHR interoperability across systems and vendors.

Create caregiver-friendly access frameworks that allow authorized individuals to view and manage health information easily.

Support the development of a universal, longitudinal patient health record that follows the individual across providers and locations.

Prioritize technology solutions that support mobile populations and remote caregiving, ensuring families can stay connected to loved ones’ care no matter where they live.

Thank you for the opportunity to contribute.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Health care is a personal choice for each citizen of the U.S.  Decisions about doctor choice, treatments and testing are made by individuals.  Therefore, the government’s responsibility is to respect those rights and stay out of the decision-making process.  
The following are my criteria for a person’s health care technology and providers.  When children are the patient, these apply to their parents:

-	no digital ID requirement
-	no requirement for biometric data 
-	no mandatory wearable technology 
-	patient decides what to do with personal data garnered by health care provider

The bottom line is NO REQUIREMENT for any kind of data or technology.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Scene Health Public Comment on CMS RFI (CMS–0042–NC)
Re: Health Technology Ecosystem | Submitted by emocha Mobile Health, dba Scene Health

CMS spends billions of dollars each year on medications that never fulfill their clinical promise. Net spending, after rebates, on Medicaid prescription drugs rose to $43.8 billion in 2022, an increase largely attributed to high-cost specialty drugs. Medicare Part D spends ~$180 billion on gross drug spending, while Part B costs tens of billions for provider-administered drugs. This is not because these medications are ineffective, but rather because they are not taken – or not taken properly. The issue of medication adherence is not a fringe problem; it is the most fundamental, preventable failure in our healthcare system.

At least 50% of patients with chronic diseases don’t take their medication properly, which leads to exorbitant, avoidable costs and waste, in addition to widespread pain and suffering. As Surgeon General Koop stated in the 1980s, “Drugs don’t work in people who don’t take them.” A 2018 study put the annual cost of medication nonadherence in the U.S. at more than $528 billion. Moreover, nonadherence is responsible for over ~125,000 preventable deaths and up to 25% of hospitalizations each year.

***SEE ATTACHED FILE FOR FULL COMMENT***

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide input about the necessity and possibilities to leverage the nation’s existing and ever evolving digital health ecosystem to improve the health and wellbeing of adults, children and the population.  I am writing with specific emphasis on the following:
1.	Opportunities to advance a digital health ecosystem that meaningfully and productively engages patients/families (using personal data they own and choose to share) and communities (using population data they can own and analyze) in ways that implement behavioral economics principles to achieve much needed leaps in health outcomes 
2.	Possibilities to establish a digital health ecosystem that enables individual and population-based data sharing both within health care settings (vertical integration) and across the many community-based services and public health programs (horizontal integration) that are essential to address the many psychosocial, behavioral, environmental and practical daily support needs that drive poor outcomes and diminished well-being.
Given the word limit for this comment, I am attaching a document with links to brief videos and overview documents that further illustrate an example of an innovation that addresses the two priorities.  In this brief comment, I illustrate possibilities to achieve the goals listed above by briefly sharing about the evidence-based Cycle of Engagement (COE) patient-facing, personalized digital health Well Visit Planner approach anchored to the nation’s Bright Futures Guidelines and the related national system’s transformation Engagement In Action (EnAct!) Framework that was created through Congressional language in 2017 to advance a national model for creating statewide integrated health systems that promote the healthy development of children.  The COE and EnAct! framework enable a “Through Any Door” approach and centers the use of digital health technologies that enable personalized, whole person care and details the many leadership, cultural, technical and policy issues involved in advancing a health care system aiming to foster whole health and wellbeing.  Doing so innately requires partnerships across systems, reductions in data collection/sharing burden and a focus on the whole person/family/child/youth where they are engaged to identify and partner to address their personal goals, needs, priorities and context.  While created for children and families, the COE approach is relevant for all ages and health issues (it was recognized by ONC in 2012 as such and in the recent NASEM Launching Lifelong Health study).  While this RFI focuses on Medicare, we respectfully share about this work as an example since it is relevant for all ages and health issues.  See the attached document with links to videos and short documents for more information.  To summarize, The Cycle of Engagement Well Visit Planner approach (COE/WVP) is specifically designed to:
1.	Engage patients using a brief, time saving pre-visit digital health tool produces a guidelines-based, whole person profile of health, risks, needs, goals and priorities. 
2.	Use of an autogenerated Clinical Summary that is digitally shared with providers and families providing an at-a-glance view (patients also get this) with resource links that enables “Personalized Connected Encounters” that implement best practice engagement, education, shared decision making and behavior change strategies with time to focus on resource sharing and linkages.  
3.	Provides a validated post-visit quality of care tool the periodically generates actionable quality reports to improve care and respond to value based care incentive programs.
4.	Provides population-based data for identifying needs and planning systems
5.	Features a data sharing platform patients can agree providers use to share their Clinical Summary and care plan across their care team and with others 
6.	Has been/can be fully integrated with existing EHR systems but is not scaled due to lack of incentives and focus on patient engagement, whole person care focused on prevention (and in our case, children).
With the United States ranking among the lowest in health and wellbeing for adults and children (roots of adult health) it is urgent to leverage strategies that build trust and relationships with patients and families in ways that effectively activate personal, family and community agency and will to be well and to gain skills and connect with available resources and supports to prevent illness and promote wellbeing, even amid illness or risks.  Putting power into the hands of patients to self-assess, pick priorities, identify their needs and share that information across their care team in a way that ensures it is based on best practice guidelines and will be honored and responded to is important and possible.  Patient facing digital health tools are important. but are not integrated into existing EHRs, especially for prevention and children.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
summary of my comments

National Interoperability Acceleration Framework
Thank you for the opportunity to comment. I urge CMS to prioritize not only standards adoption but also implementation capacity across the health IT ecosystem. Interoperability cannot succeed without aligned programs that support real-world uptake. I offer the following recommendations:
1. Launch CMS-Sponsored FHIR Hackathons
CMS should partner with ONC, ASTP, and NLM to fund national and regional FHIR hackathons focused on:
•	Cancer, behavioral health, public health, and quality reporting (USCDI+ domains)
•	C-CDA to FHIR and CCD to IPS transformation
•	Advance directives and aging population use cases (e.g., Medicare, MA plans)
•	Emergency medicine, telehealth, and rural care delivery
These events can serve as real-time implementation labs to test standards, develop scalable tools, and build workforce experience.
2. Develop an Interoperability Workforce Pipeline
Create a national SME Registry in partnership with ONC, NLM, and ASTP to:
•	Recruit and credential experts in FHIR, SNOMED CT, LOINC, IPS, and openEHR
•	Align with accreditation bodies (e.g., CAHIIM) and offer microcredentials
•	Establish early career tracks for Master’s and PhD students in informatics, public health, and data science
This would address the national shortage of implementers and standards SMEs and ensure we can scale health IT innovation equitably.
3. Build Public-Private Innovation Coalitions
CMS should support collaborative agreements with organizations like the Monarch Initiative, HIMSS, and Sequoia Project to accelerate semantic infrastructure development. A "NVIDIA-like" coalition model could fuel adoption of AI-ready, standards-aligned health data infrastructure.
4. Ensure Equity in Implementation Support
CMS must ensure rural hospitals, FQHCs, behavioral health providers, and underserved regions are not left behind. Support could include:
•	Discounted interoperability tools and Ontoserver deployment
•	TEFCA onboarding and terminology validation services
•	State-level partnerships to train local provider orgs

Closing:
To realize the promise of interoperability, CMS must lead not only with regulation, but with implementation strategy. A national approach that combines standards, infrastructure, training, and testing environments will ensure scalable, equitable impact.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Organization Name: Deloitte Consulting LLP and Thrive Global
Comment: Please see attached for Deloitte and Thrive Global’s comments on the CMS Health Technology Ecosystem Request for Information. Our response draws on our significant combined policy, regulatory, data infrastructure, digital health, and wellness expertise to share our recommendations for advancing the use of digital technology to improve health and well-being for the Medicare population and their caregivers. Our recommendations include revamping the Silver Sneakers program with modern AI tools and behavioral science insights to empower a more technologically savvy generation of seniors, and offering a CMS certification for the highest quality digital health apps. We also recommend expanding the definition of health data to include data on daily behaviors – and finding ways to combine or allow others to combine these data sources to improve care coordination and better understand the return on prevention. To increase technology adoption and innovation, we recommend creating new reimbursement pathways for providers, potential premium reductions/other incentives for beneficiaries and their caregivers, and streamlining regulatory approvals for app developers. Together, these CMS actions can support a shift toward a modern digital technology ecosystem tailored to the needs of Medicare beneficiaries and their caregivers.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Dear CMS,

This request is for a radiology imaging interpretation app.

Patients could really use Cms' help with obtaining accurate Cat scans, MRIs, other test interpretations. 

The reports are really inaccurate, omitting the findings I need noted to get medical treatment. 

Doctors often give the wrong reason for the test, so the test is set up wrong to address the fake symptoms, then the interpretation (if something is reported) aligns with the fake symptoms or reason, making it implausible or invalid. Doctors don't listen when you question this undermining practice. 

My family and I would love to have an AI radiology interpretation ap integrated with the rlectronic record alongside the hospital reading. It has to be stored together or it will be ignored by doctors. The app would allow me to enter my symptoms and describe abnormalities in detail, also compare with the most useful past tests, and list possible diagnoses. This would save a lot of money because it would help enable timely diagnosis, preventing chronic illness. It would also prevent repeated testing and unnecessary visits to the ER.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
Dear Deputy Administrator Carlton and Acting Assistant Secretary Posnack: 

Aligning for Health appreciates the opportunity to respond to CMS and ONC’s Request for Information on building a more sustainable and effective health technology ecosystem. As a coalition focused on aligning health and human services to improve outcomes and drive system-wide efficiency, we support the direction outlined in this RFI and applaud CMS and ONC’s commitment to removing barriers, supporting innovation, and advancing a more connected, patient-centered infrastructure.

We believe this is a pivotal moment to strengthen data exchange across sectors, invest in local digital infrastructure, and support platforms already in use by government and community-based partners. Interoperability and smart use of data are foundational. The priorities identified in the RFI, including the expansion of FHIR APIs, adoption of USCDI v3, and maturation of TEFCA, are aligned with that vision. However, meaningful progress will require ensuring these tools also work for community-facing providers and platforms that manage care coordination and service delivery outside of traditional clinical settings. The following are recommendations from Aligning for Health in response to CMS’s Health Technology RFI, reflecting the organization’s experience supporting cross-sector data integration, funding alignment, and whole-person care delivery.

Title: Comment on CMS_FRDOC_0001-4103
Comment:
a. What are the top things you would like to be able to do for you or your loved ones' health that can be enabled by digital health products?

24/7 -Telehealth Primary Care A.I. Patient Visits for Non-Emergent Patient Care by Mobile phone

a. Registration and paperwork- facial recognition ID for the care visit, insurance/medical history pulled in from patient EHR, consent forms-electronic signature-NPP-HIPAA, consent to treat, consent to be recorded during A.I. patient care visit, etc.

b. Initial Assessment by A.I. --Basic screening questions- patient states age, gender, known disease, and reason for the patient care visit,- A.I. review of medical history and family history confirmed and pulled in from patient EHR-gather details from patient if needed, discussion of current concerns and/or symptoms, review of medications and lifestyle (diet, exercise, sleep)- current medication list pulled in from patient EHR--confirmed at visit-medication reconciliation, and A.I. pulls in/links in any home monitoring patient tools --heart monitor, O2 sat, etc.

c. A.I. Primary Care Visit after initial assessment of patient with non-emergent care need (non-emergent care examples: medication refill and management, health screening exams ordered before PCP visit to discuss results face to face with provider, diabetes care management, asthma/COPD check- ups, thyroid disorder check-up, arthritis care management, wound care management-follow- up care/questions, mental health management, minor colds/sinusitis, allergies, urinary symptoms(UTI without fever), gastrointestinal complaints-mild reflux/constipation, musculoskeletal pain, headache-non-severe/no neuro symptoms, post hospital follow up care check in/questions, weight management care plan follow up, travel medicine/vaccine consultation, minor wound/injury follow up, sleep related issue, smoking cessation support, etc.) A.I. is able to prescribe medication-order goes to patient pharmacy of choice, order medical imaging exams/procedures/laboratory testing/respiratory testing/physical therapy/EKG/etc.- order goes to patient hospital/clinic/care facility of choice, orders referral to specialist, and post visit care plan is developed- A.I. tool discusses patient next steps/action items/follow up care- A.I. schedules for next primary care visit with a provider--A.I. links patient to next scheduled appointment (in office visit to go over test results, and for management of ongoing conditions if not resolved).

Rural communities often face significant challenges related to a lack of primary care providers (PCPs). Patients may wait weeks and months before getting into a PCP.  Patient anxiety builds, fears of waiting, unfamiliarity with procedures/providers, dislikes long wait times, lack of information, and the patient feels pushed aside/like they are not being heard/their issue is not important.

With implementing technology like a 24/7 Telehealth Primary Care A.I. Patient Visit for Non-Emergency Patient Care by Mobile phone the patient will feel more empowered and connected to healthcare.
 
A.I. Patient Care visit would be recorded and the recording linked to the patient's EHR as a mobile office visit for the provider's review of the note.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment: Hello, The remote digital direct supervision provision was invaluable to allow remote supervision of all sorts of procedures that are mostly safe but required synchronous direct supervision. We have developed a FDA approved, HIPPA compliant platform that allows even synchronous physical exam in addition to audio/video the net result is allowing most to safely perform for example remote stress testing, re-habilitation etc. greatly improving how quick patients get their test by not having to require in-person supervision. This was allowing quicker diagnosis and treatment therefore improving clinical outcomes.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
The United States healthcare system has reached the absolute limit of what a compliance-driven, market-led approach to interoperability can achieve. The persistent failures of the past decade—the superficial adoption of standards, the entrenchment of data-hoarding business models, the stagnation of innovation, and the constrained potential of AI—are not incidental bugs in the system. They are predictable features of a market that structurally rewards the creation of data silos. Continuing down this path with more incremental rules and voluntary frameworks will only yield more of the same frustrating results.
A fundamental strategic pivot is required. The only viable path forward is for the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, in its role as the nation's largest payer and most influential market actor, to lead the deliberate construction of a national health data infrastructure. This is not a call for more regulation in the traditional sense, but for the establishment of essential public utilities—the digital roads, registries, and common languages that a 21st-century healthcare system requires to function.
The 11-point blueprint detailed in this report provides a cohesive and actionable framework for building this infrastructure. By mandating FHIR as the universal standard for all data reporting, access, and quality measurement, CMS can create a powerful forcing function for data quality. By establishing national utilities for terminology and provider endpoint discovery, it can solve the semantic and logistical barriers that currently make nationwide exchange impossible. By mandating FHIR for price transparency and fostering a marketplace for digital quality measures, it can empower consumers and reorient the system toward proactive improvement. And by demanding transparency in data quality and AI assessment, it can rebuild the trust necessary for widespread adoption.
Taken together, these mandates are designed to achieve a singular strategic objective: to neutralize proprietary control over data as a source of market power. This is the key to unlocking the EHR duopoly, reducing vendor lock-in, and unleashing the forces of competition and innovation that have been suppressed for far too long.
The Request for Information on the Health Technology Ecosystem presents a critical window of opportunity. It is a clear signal that federal leaders recognize the current approach is insufficient. This report offers a bold but necessary response. It is a call for CMS, ONC, and all industry stakeholders to abandon the failed paradigm of the past and seize the mandate to build the modern, open, and equitable healthcare infrastructure that Americans deserve. The goal is no less than the final realization of a healthcare system that is truly connected, intelligent, and capable of learning.

Title: Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Comment:
This document is submitted by FHIR IQ in response to the Request for Information (RFI) regarding the health technology ecosystem. As a health information technology company with extensive experience in developing and implementing FHIR-based solutions, we have a direct and informed perspective on the current state of healthcare interoperability.

Our experience has shown that the United States has reached the limit of what a compliance-driven, market-led approach can achieve. The persistent failures superficial standards adoption, entrenched data-hoarding business models, and stagnant innovation are not incidental bugs. They are predictable features of a market that structurally rewards the creation of data silos.

A fundamental strategic pivot is required. This RFI presents a critical opportunity to move beyond incremental rules and toward the deliberate construction of a national health data infrastructure. We offer the following analysis, structured as direct responses to the questions posed in the RFI, and a cohesive set of recommendations to aid CMS and ONC in this essential work.
